Some [[Hispanic]]s and film critics criticized the casting of Ben Affleck in the role of Mendez, who is of Mexican ancestry on his father's side.<ref>Amanda Hess, [http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2012/10/16/ben_affleck_in_argo_why_is_a_white_guy_playing_tony_mendez.html Ben Affleck Is No Tony Mendez], ''[[Slate (magazine)]]'', October 16, 2012</ref><ref>Ruben Navarrette Jr, [http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/09/opinion/navarrette-argo-affleck-latino Latino should have played lead in 'Argo'], ''[[CNN]]'', January 10, 2013</ref><ref>Eduardo Perez, [http://screenpicks.com/2012/10/perez-why-a-latino-not-ben-affleck-should-have-played-argo-lead-role/ Why a Latino — not Ben Affleck —Should Have Played 'Argo' Lead Role], ''ScreenPicks.com'', October 29, 2012</ref><ref>Moctesuma Esparza, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2013/feb/08/argo-hollywood-latino-hero Argo plays to Hollywood's worst traditions by erasing a Latino hero], ''[[The Guardian]]'', February 8, 2013</ref> [[Mexican-American]] actor and director [[Edward James Olmos]] considered Affleck's casting as Mendez a \"mistake\", and that the actor \"had no sense of the cultural dynamic of the character he was playing\".<ref>[http://www.latinrapper.com/edward-james-olmos-interview-5-4-2013.html Interview with Edward James Olmos], ''LatinRapper.com'', May 4, 2013</ref> However, Mendez himself has said that he was unconcerned about the casting, and noted he does not identify as Hispanic.<ref>[http://nbclatino.com/2013/01/10/argos-real-tony-mendez-im-not-hispanic/ Argo's real Tony Mendez: \"I'm not Hispanic\"], ''NBC Latino'', January 10, 2013</ref> Actor [[Fouad Hajji]], who played Komiteh, is of Moroccan descent.{{fact
* ''[[Escape from Iran: The Canadian Caper]]'', a 1981 television film about the \"[[Canadian Caper]]\".
* ''[[On Wings of Eagles]]'', a 1983 novel by [[Ken Follett]], about [[Ross Perot]]'s successful rescue of several of his employees from Iran just after the revolution.
* [https://www.npr.org/2013/02/22/172600588/affleck-on-argo-and-the-1979-hostage-crisis Radio interview] with Ben Affleck regarding ''Argo'', on NPR's ''[[Fresh Air]]'' (28 mins, 2013)

column2: thriller]] film directed by [[Ben Affleck]]. Screenwriter [[Chris Terrio]] adapted the screenplay from the book by the U.S. [[Central Intelligence Agency]] operative [[Tony Mendez]], ''The Master of Disguise'', and the

column1: [[Joshuah Bearman]], \"The Great Escape: How the CIA Used a Fake Sci-Fi Flick to Rescue Americans from Tehran\".<ref name=\"Bearman\">{{cite journal
column5: title=How the CIA Used a Fake Sci-Fi Flick to Rescue Americans from Tehran
column8: date=April 24, 2007}}</ref> The latter deals with the \"[[Canadian Caper]]\",<ref name=\"Bearman\"/> in which Mendez led the rescue of six U.S. diplomats from [[Tehran]], Iran, under the guise of filming a science fiction film during the 1979–1981 [[Iran hostage crisis]].<ref name=\"IBT(13 Oct 2012)\">{{cite news
column11: title='Argo' Review: Ben Affleck Pinches Himself In Stranger-Than-Fiction CIA Story

column1: The film, starring Affleck as Mendez, and [[Bryan Cranston]], [[Alan Arkin]], and [[John Goodman]] in supporting roles, was released in the United States on October 12, 2012. It was produced by [[Grant Heslov]], Affleck and [[George Clooney]].

''Argo'' was praised for the acting (particularly Arkin and Goodman's), Affleck's direction, Terrio's screenplay, the editing, and Desplat's score. The film received seven nominations at the [[85th Academy Awards]] and won three, for [[Academy Award for Best Picture
column2: Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay
column3: Best Adapted Screenplay]], and [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing
column4: Best Film Editing]]. The film also earned five [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations: it won [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama
column5: Best Motion Picture – Drama]] and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Director
column6: Best Director]], and was nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture
column7: Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture]] for Alan Arkin. It won [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture
column8: Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]] at the [[19th Screen Actors Guild Awards]], and Arkin was nominated for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role
column9: Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role]]. It also won [[BAFTA Award for Best Film
column10: Best Film]], [[BAFTA Award for Best Editing
column11: Best Editing]] and [[BAFTA Award for Best Direction
column12: Best Director]] at the [[66th British Academy Film Awards]], and [[Hochi Film Award
column13: 37th Hochi Film Award]] for Best International Picture.

column1: Despite its praise, ''Argo'' has been criticized for some specific inaccuracies, in particular for minimizing the role of the Canadian embassy in the rescue, for falsely showing that the Americans were turned away by the British and New Zealand embassies, and for exaggerating the danger the group faced during events preceding their escape from the country.

column2: Islamists]] storm the [[Embassy of the United States, Tehran
column3: United States embassy in Tehran]] in retaliation for President [[Jimmy Carter]] giving the [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi
column4: Shah]] asylum in the U.S. during the [[Iranian Revolution]]. Sixty of the embassy staff are taken as hostages, but six avoid capture and are sheltered in the home of Canadian ambassador [[Kenneth D. Taylor
column5: Ken Taylor]]. With the escapees' situation kept secret, the [[United States Department of State
column6: U.S. State Department]] begins to explore options for [[Extraction (military)
column7: exfiltrating]] them from Iran. [[Tony Mendez]], a U.S. [[Central Intelligence Agency]] exfiltration specialist, is brought in for a consultation. He criticizes the proposals but is at a loss when asked for an alternative. While on the phone with his son, he is inspired by watching [[Battle for the Planet of the Apes
column8: ''Battle for the Planet of the Apes'']] and begins plans for creating a cover story for the escapees: that they are Canadian filmmakers who are in Iran scouting exotic locations for a science-fiction film.

column2: John Chambers]], a Hollywood make-up artist who had previously worked for the CIA. Chambers puts Mendez in touch with film producer Lester Siegel. Together, they set up a phony film production company, publicize their plans, and successfully establish the pretense of developing ''Argo'', a \"science fantasy adventure\" in the style of [[Star Wars (film)
column3: ''Star Wars'']], to lend credibility to the cover story. Meanwhile, the escapees grow restless. The revolutionaries reassemble embassy photographs shredded before the takeover and finally realize that some personnel are unaccounted for.

column1: Posing as a producer for ''Argo'', Mendez enters Iran under the alias Kevin Harkins and meets with the six escapees. He provides them with [[Canadian passports]] and fake identities. Although afraid to trust Mendez's scheme, they reluctantly go along, knowing that he is risking his own life too. A scouting visit to the [[Grand Bazaar, Tehran
column2: bazaar]] to maintain their cover story takes a bad turn when they are harassed by a hostile shopkeeper, but their Iranian culture contact hustles them away from the hostile crowd.

column1: Mendez is told that the operation has been canceled to avoid conflicting with a [[Operation Eagle Claw
column2: planned military rescue of the hostages]]. He pushes ahead anyway, forcing his boss Jack O'Donnell to hastily re-obtain authorization for the mission and confirm their tickets on a [[Swissair]] flight. Tensions rise at the airport, where the escapees' ticket reservations are confirmed at the last minute, and the head guard's call to the fake production company in Hollywood is answered only at the last second. The group boards the airliner, which takes off just as the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps
column3: Revolutionary Guards]] at the airport are informed of the ruse and try to stop them.

column1: To protect the hostages remaining in Tehran from retaliation, all U.S. involvement in the rescue is suppressed, and full credit is given to the Canadian government and its ambassador (who shuts down the embassy and leaves Iran with his wife as the operation is underway). The ambassador's Iranian housekeeper, who had known about the Americans and lied to the revolutionaries to protect them, escapes to [[Ba'athist Iraq
column2: Iraq]]. Mendez is awarded the [[Intelligence Star]], but due to the mission's classified nature, he receives the medal in secret and has to return it afterward. The award is restored to him after the [[Canadian Caper]] is declassified in 1997.

column3: Actor, producer, and director Ben Affleck.]]

column1: * [[Kyle Chandler]] as [[Hamilton Jordan]] ([[White House Chief of Staff]])
* [[Bob Gunton]] as [[Cyrus Vance]] ([[United States Secretary of State
* Ashley Wood as Space Lab Nurse
* [[Barry Livingston]] as David Marmor, CIA official
* Karina Logue as Elizabeth Ann Swift

''Argo'' is based on the \"Canadian Caper\" that took place during the [[Iran hostage crisis]] in 1979 and 1980. [[Chris Terrio]] wrote the screenplay based on Joshuah Bearman's 2007 article \"How the CIA Used a Fake Sci-Fi Flick to Rescue Americans from Tehran,\" which was published in ''[[Wired (magazine)
In 2007, the producers [[George Clooney]], [[Grant Heslov]] and [[David Klawans]] set up a project based on the article. Affleck's participation was announced in February 2011.<ref>{{cite journal
column11: archivedate=November 9, 2012 }}</ref> The following June, Alan Arkin was the first person cast in the film.<ref name=\"First\">{{cite journal
column21: archivedate=November 9, 2012 }}</ref> After the rest of the roles were cast, filming began in [[Los Angeles]]<ref>{{cite web
column25: accessdate=February 25, 2013}}</ref> in August 2011. Additional filming took place in [[McLean, Virginia]]; [[Washington, D.C.]]; and [[Istanbul]].<ref name=\"upi\">{{cite news
column27: title=Affleck starts shooting 'Argo' film in LA
column29: date=September 12, 2011}}</ref> The scene in which Mendez drives up to and walks into the CIA headquarters lobby was filmed with permission at the CIA's original headquarters building in Virginia; all other scenes set at the CIA were filmed in the basement of the [[Los Angeles Times Building]].<ref>{{cite news
column32: title=Contender – Director of Photography Rodrigo Prieto, Argo

column1: As a historical piece, the film made use of archival news footage from [[American Broadcasting Company
column2: ABC]], [[CBS]] and [[NBC]]; and included popular songs from the era, such as \"[[Little T&A]]\" by [[The Rolling Stones]] (an anachronism, as it was not released until the following year), \"[[Sultans of Swing]]\" by [[Dire Straits]], \"[[Dance the Night Away (Van Halen song)
column3: Dance the Night Away]]\" by [[Van Halen]] and \"[[When the Levee Breaks]]\" by [[Led Zeppelin]].<ref>[http://www.soundtrack.net/movie/argo Argo (2012) – Soundtrack.net]</ref> For its part, Warner Bros. used its 1972–1984 title featuring the \"Big W\" logo designed by [[Saul Bass]] for [[Warner Communications]] to open the film and painted on its studio lot's famed water tower the logo of The Burbank Studios (the facility's name during the 1970s and 1980s when Warner shared it with [[Columbia Pictures]]).<ref>{{cite journal
column7: title=OSCARS: Re-Creating The Look Of The '70s For 'Argo'

column1: The screenplay used by the CIA to create their cover story was an adaptation of [[Roger Zelazny]]'s 1967 novel ''[[Lord of Light]]''.  Producer Barry Geller had spearheaded an earlier attempt to produce the film using the original title. After that production attempt failed, the screenplay was renamed ''Argo'' and used by the CIA.<ref name=\"Bearman\"/><ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Odd Hollywood History Behind Ben Affleck's 'Argo'

column1: According to Tony Mendez, Studio Six—the phony Hollywood production office he helped create at the core of the CIA plan—proved so convincing that even weeks after the rescue was complete and the office had folded, 26 scripts were delivered to its address, including one from [[Steven Spielberg]].<ref name=Lane>{{cite journal

column2: VICE]]'', based on documents received under the Freedom of Information Act, revealed that the CIA was involved in the production of the 2012 ''Argo'',<ref name=\"news.vice.com\">{{cite web
column5: title=The CIA Helped Produce an Episode of 'Top Chef'
column12: title=CIA's Work With Filmmakers Puts All Media Workers at Risk
column16: accessdate=December 12, 2016}}</ref> as it was in a number of American entertainment productions (such as the well-established case of the 2012 film ''[[Zero Dark Thirty]]''<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Tequila, Painted Pearls, and Prada — How the CIA Helped Produce 'Zero Dark Thirty'

column1: <!--Track lengths are taken from iTunes. May vary ±00:04.-->
[[File:First Lady Michelle Obama announces the Best Picture Oscar to Argo.jpg
column5: First Lady]] [[Michelle Obama]] announces the winner of [[85th Academy Awards
column6: Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Picture
column7: Best Picture]], ''Argo'', live from the [[Diplomatic Reception Room (White House)
column8: Diplomatic Room]] of the [[White House]], February 24, 2013.]]

column1: ''Argo'' was acclaimed by critics, praising Ben Affleck's direction, the cast (especially Arkin and Goodman), the script and the editing. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film an approval rating of 96%, based on 351 reviews, with an [[weighted mean
column2: average]] rating of 8.39/10. The website's critical consensus reads, \"Tense, exciting and often darkly comic, ''Argo'' recreates a historical event with vivid attention to detail and finely wrought characters.\"<ref name=\"rt\">{{cite web
column7: accessdate=February 21, 2020}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 86 out of 100, based on 45 reviews, indicating \"universal acclaim\".<ref name=\"meta\">{{cite web
column12: accessdate=February 27, 2018}}</ref> [[CinemaScore]] reported that audiences gave the film a rare \"A+\" grade.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=18 of the Most Loved or Hated Movies: Films That Got A+ or F CinemaScores (Photos)

column1: Naming ''Argo'' one of the best 11 films of 2012, critic [[Stephen Holden]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote: \"Ben Affleck's seamless direction catapults him to the forefront of Hollywood filmmakers turning out thoughtful entertainment.\"<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=The Year of the Body Vulnerable
column8: accessdate=December 14, 2012}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Times]]'' said it felt \"like a movie from an earlier era — less frenetic, less showy, more focused on narrative than sensation,\" but that the script included \"too many characters that he doesn't quite develop.\"<ref>Peter Suderman, [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/oct/11/movie-review-argo/ Movie Review: 'Argo'], ''[[The Washington Times]]'', October 11, 2012</ref>

column1: Writing in the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', [[Roger Ebert]] said,

column2: The craft in this film is rare. It is so easy to manufacture a thriller from chases and gunfire, and so very hard to fine-tune it out of exquisite timing and a plot that's so clear to us we wonder why it isn't obvious to the Iranians. After all, who in their right mind would believe a space opera was being filmed in Iran during the hostage crisis?<ref name=\"ebert\" />}}Ebert gave the film 4/4 stars, calling it \"spellbinding\" and \"surprisingly funny,\" and chose it as the best film of the year, the last film he would choose for this honor before his death in 2013.<ref name=ebert>Ebert, Roger (10 October 2012). [http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121010/REVIEWS/121019999 Argo]. ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''. Retrieved January 16, 2013.</ref>

column1: Literary critic [[Stanley Fish]] says that the film is a standard [[caper film]] in which \"some improbable task has to be pulled off by a combination of ingenuity, training, deception and luck.\" He goes on to describe the film's structure: \"(1) the presentation of the scheme to reluctant and unimaginative superiors, (2) the transformation of a ragtag bunch of ne'er-do-wells and wackos into a coherent, coordinated unit and (3) the carrying out of the task.\"<ref name=\"fish\"/>
Although he thinks the film is good at building and sustaining suspense, he concludes,

column2: This is one of those movies that depend on your not thinking much about it; for as soon as you reflect on what's happening rather than being swept up in the narrative flow, there doesn't seem much to it aside from the skill with which suspense is maintained despite the fact that you know in advance how it's going to turn out. ... Once the deed is successfully done, there's really nothing much to say, and anything that is said seems contrived. That is the virtue of an entertainment like this; it doesn't linger in the memory and provoke afterthoughts.<ref name=\"fish\">{{cite news

column1: [[Abolhassan Banisadr]], foreign minister and then president during the incident, argued that the movie does not take into account the fact that most of [[Interim Government of Iran (1979)
column2: the cabinet members]] advocated freeing all the American personnel quickly.<ref>{{cite news
column9: date= March 7, 2013}}</ref> [[Jian Ghomeshi]], a Canadian writer and radio figure of Iranian descent, thought the film had a \"deeply troubling portrayal of the Iranian people.\" Ghomeshi asserted \"among all the rave reviews, virtually no one in the mainstream media has called out [the] unbalanced depiction of an entire ethnic national group, and the broader implications of the portrait.\" He also suggested that the timing of the film was poor, as American and Iranian political relations were at a low point.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Argo is crowd-pleasing, entertaining – and unfair to Iranians
column16: accessdate=November 5, 2012}}</ref> University of Michigan history professor [[Juan Cole]] had a similar assessment, writing that the film's narrative fails to provide adequate historical context for the events it portrays, and such errors of omission lead all of the Iranian characters in the film to be depicted as ethnic stereotypes.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=\"Argo\" as Orientalism and why it Upsets Iranians
column23: accessdate=February 26, 2013}}</ref> A November 3, 2012 article in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' claimed that the film had received very little attention in Tehran, though [[Masoumeh Ebtekar]], who was the spokesperson of the students who took the hostages and called only \"Tehran Mary\" in the film's credits, said that the film did not show \"the real reasons behind the event.\"<ref>{{cite news
column27: title=U.S. film 'Argo' not getting any buzz in Iran

column1: Bootleg DVDs have become popular and are estimated at \"several hundreds of thousands\" of copies. Interpretations of the film's popularity in Iran have varied, ranging from the fact that the movie portrays the excesses of the revolution and the hostage crisis, which had been long glorified in Iran, to Iranians viewing it as a reminder of what caused the poor relations with America and the ensuing cost to Iran, decades after the embassy takeover.<ref name=\"Kamali\">{{cite web
column3: title=Why Argo is hard for Iranians to watch
column7: accessdate=February 25, 2013}}</ref> The high DVD sales suggests a form of silent protest against the government's ongoing hostility to relations with America.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Professional reviewers ranked the film with other releases for 2012, as follows:
The film earned $136,024,128 in North America, and $96,300,000 in other countries, for a worldwide total of $232,324,128.<ref name=\"Mojo\"/>
The film was released in North America on February 19, 2013 on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc]].<ref>{{cite web

column2: List of accolades received by Argo (2012 film)}}

column1: The film was nominated for seven [[Academy Award]]s and won three, for [[Academy Award for Best Picture
column2: Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Writing (Adapted Screenplay)
column3: Best Adapted Screenplay]] and [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing
column4: Best Film Editing]]. Affleck was not nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Director
column5: Best Director]], and following the announcement of the nominations, [[Bradley Cooper]], who was nominated for his [[Academy Award for Best Actor
column6: leading performance]] in ''[[Silver Linings Playbook]]'', declared: \"Ben Affleck got robbed.\" This opinion was shared by the ceremony's host [[Seth MacFarlane]]<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Ben Affleck's Oscars Snub: Bradley Cooper, Seth MacFarlane Think Argo Director Was Robbed
column14: date=January 10, 2013}}</ref> and [[Quentin Tarantino]], whose film ''[[Django Unchained]]'' was nominated in several categories.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Quentin Tarantino thinks Ben Affleck's Oscar snub was worse than his

column2: Standing in the Golden Globe pressroom with his directing trophy, Affleck acknowledged that it was frustrating not to get an Oscar nod when many felt he deserved one. But he's keeping a sense of humor. \"I mean, I also didn't get the acting nomination,\" he pointed out. \"And no one's saying I got snubbed there!\"<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title=The Oscars / 2013: Eyes on the Prize

column1: After the film was previewed at the [[2012 Toronto International Film Festival]],<ref name=\"Evans2012\">{{Cite journal
column7: accessdate=January 19, 2013}}</ref> many critics said that it unfairly glorified the CIA's role and minimized the [[Government of Canada
column8: Canadian government]]'s role (particularly that of Ambassador Taylor) in the extraction operation.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Argo: Iran hostage crisis film fiddles with the facts | CTV British Columbia News
column13: accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref> ''[[Maclean's]]'' asserted that \"the movie rewrites history at Canada's expense, making Hollywood and the CIA the saga's heroic saviours while Taylor is demoted to a kindly concierge.\"<ref name=\"Macleans\">{{cite news
column20: date=September 12, 2012}}</ref> The postscript text said that the CIA let Taylor take the credit for political purposes, which some critics thought implied that he did not deserve the accolades he received.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=TIFF 2012: How Canadian hero Ken Taylor was snubbed by Argo
column31: df=mdy }}</ref> In response to this criticism, Affleck changed the postscript text to read: \"The involvement of the CIA complemented efforts of the Canadian embassy to free the six held in Tehran. To this day the story stands as an enduring model of international co-operation between governments.\"<ref name=\"KnelmanTorStar2\">{{cite news
column34: title=Ken Taylor's Hollywood ending: Affleck alters postscript to 'Argo'
column38: date=September 19, 2012}}</ref> The ''[[Toronto Star]]'' wrote, \"Even that hardly does Canada justice.\"<ref>{{cite news
column41: title='Argo': Former ambassador Ken Taylor sets the record straight

column4: People welcoming the six American diplomats back to the United States and expressing thanks to Canada, 1980]]

column1: In a CNN interview, former U.S. president [[Jimmy Carter]] addressed the controversy:

column2: 90% of the contributions to the ideas and the consummation of the plan was Canadian. And the movie gives almost full credit to the American CIA. And with that exception, the movie is very good. But Ben Affleck's character in the film was... only in Tehran a day and a half. And the main hero, in my opinion, was [[Kenneth D. Taylor
column3: Ken Taylor]], who was the Canadian ambassador who orchestrated the entire process.<ref>{{cite news
column10: date=February 22, 2013}}</ref>}}Taylor noted, \"In reality, Canada was responsible for the six and the CIA was a junior partner. But I realize this is a movie and you have to keep the audience on the edge of their seats.\"<ref name=KnelmanTorStar2 /> In the film, Taylor is shown threatening to close the Canadian embassy. This did not happen, and the Canadians never considered abandoning the six Americans who had taken refuge under their protection.<ref name=KnelmanTorStar2 />

column2: Because we say it's based on a true story, rather than this is a true story, we're allowed to take some dramatic license. There's a spirit of truth .... the kinds of things that are really important to be true are—for example, the relationship between the U.S. and Canada. The U.S. stood up collectively as a nation and said, \"We like you, we appreciate you, we respect you, and we're in your debt.\"... There were folks who didn't want to stick their necks out and the Canadians did. They said, \"We'll risk our diplomatic standing, our lives, by harbouring six Americans because it's the right thing to do.\"  Because of that, their lives were saved.\"<ref name=Macleans />}}

column1: Upon its release in October 2012, the film was criticized for its suggestion that [[United Kingdom
column2: British]] and [[New Zealand]] embassies had turned away the American refugees in Tehran. Neither the British nor the New Zealand embassies had turned the refugees away. Both embassies, along with the Canadians, helped them. The British took immense risks,{{cn
column3: date=April 2020}} having initially hosted the American refugees. However, the location was deemed unsafe as the British embassy itself had been targeted and surrounded by mobs and all involved officials from the various nations believed the Canadian ambassador's residence to be a safer location. New Zealand diplomatic ambassadors also took huge risks: organizing a place for the refugees to hide if they needed to change their location,<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Opinion: Ben Affleck must apologise to NZ for Argo's deception
column7: date=February 27, 2013}}</ref> and driving the Americans to the airport when they made their escape from Tehran.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=NZ's role in Iran crisis tainted in Affleck's film 'Argo' – Story – Entertainment
column11: accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> British diplomats also assisted other American hostages beyond the escaped group of six.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Ben Affleck's new film 'Argo' upsets British diplomats who helped Americans in Iran
column16: accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Bob Anders, the U.S. consular agent played in the film by [[Tate Donovan]], said, \"They put their lives on the line for us. We were all at risk. I hope no one in Britain will be offended by what's said in the film. The British were good to us and we're forever grateful.\"<ref name=\"Telegraph UK review\">{{cite news
column19: title=Ben Affleck's new film 'Argo' upsets British diplomats who helped Americans in Iran

column2: Sir John Graham]], the then-[[List of diplomats of the United Kingdom to Iran

My immediate reaction on hearing about this was one of outrage. I have since simmered down, but am still very distressed that the film-makers should have got it so wrong. My concern is that the inaccurate account should not enter the mythology of the events in Tehran in November 1979.\"<ref name = \"Telegraph UK review\"/>}} The then-British [[chargé d'affaires]] in Tehran said that, had the Americans been discovered in the British embassy, \"I can assure you we'd all have been for the high jump.\"<ref name = \"Telegraph UK review\"/> [[Martin Williams (diplomat)
column3: Martin Williams]], secretary to Sir John Graham in Iran at the time, was the one who found the Americans, after searching for them in his own British car (the only [[Austin Maxi]] in Iran) and first sheltered them in his own house.{{cn

column1: Affleck is quoted as saying to ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'': \"I struggled with this long and hard, because it casts Britain and New Zealand in a way that is not totally fair. But I was setting up a situation where you needed to get a sense that these six people had nowhere else to go. It does not mean to diminish anyone.\"<ref name = \"Telegraph UK review\" />
On March 12, 2013, the [[New Zealand House of Representatives]] censured Affleck by  unanimously agreeing to the following motion, initiated by [[New Zealand First]] leader [[Winston Peters]]:

column2: ... this House acknowledge[s] with gratitude the efforts of former New Zealand diplomats Chris Beeby and Richard Sewell in assisting American hostages in Tehran during the hostage crisis in 1979, and express[es] its regret that the director of the movie'' Argo ''saw fit to mislead the world about what actually happened during that crisis when, in reality, our courageous diplomats' inspirational actions were of significant help to the American hostages and deserve the factual and historical record to be corrected.''<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Motions—Iran Hostage Crisis—Fictional Representation of Role of New Zealand Diplomats

column1: In the film, the diplomats face suspicious glances from Iranians whenever they go out in public, and appear close to being caught at many steps along the way to their freedom. In reality, the diplomats never appeared to be in imminent danger.<ref name=\"Macleans\"/><ref name=\"KnelmanTorStar2\"/><ref name=\"BBC News - Argo\"/> Rather than the team having to withstand scrutiny while buying tickets, Taylor's wife bought three sets of plane tickets from three different airlines ahead of time, without any issues.<ref name=\"Macleans\"/><ref name=\"KnelmanTorStar2\"/>

* The film depicts a dramatic last-minute cancellation of the mission by the Carter administration and Mendez declaring he will proceed with the mission. Carter delayed authorization by only 30 minutes, and that was before Mendez had left Europe for Iran.<ref name=\"CIA history\">{{cite journal
column3: title=CIA Goes Hollywood: A Classic Case of Deception

column1: * The film portrays a tense situation when the crew tries to board the plane, and their identities are nearly discovered. No such confrontation with security officials took place at the departure gate.<ref name=\"CIA history\"/><ref name=\"TN\">{{cite news
column3: title=Diplomats in Iranian hostage crisis discuss Argo: Spoiler alert: Hollywood fudged the facts
column10: quote=Wednesday night's conversation between former diplomats Robert Anders and Michael Shenstone, hosted by the U.S. Consulate and the University of Toronto International Relations Society, was an exercise in displaying Hollywood's manipulation of historical reality.

column1: * The film has a dramatic chase sequence as the plane takes off; this did not occur.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Tony Mendez, clandestine CIA hero of Ben Affleck's 'Argo,' reveals the real story behind film smash
column7: accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> As Mark Lijek described it, \"Fortunately for us, there were very few Revolutionary Guards in the area. It is why we turned up for a flight at 5.30 in the morning; even they weren't zealous enough to be there that early. The truth is the immigration officers barely looked at us and we were processed out in the regular way. We got on the flight to Zurich and then we were taken to the US ambassador's residence in Bern. It was that straightforward.\"<ref name=\"BBC News - Argo\">{{cite web
column11: title=Argo: The true story behind Ben Affleck's Globe-winning film

column1: The film contains other historical inaccuracies:

* The screenplay has the escapees—Mark and Cora Lijek, Bob Anders, Lee Schatz, and Joe and Kathy Stafford—settling down to enforced cohabitation at the residence of the Canadian ambassador Ken Taylor. In reality, after several nights, the group was split between the Taylor house and the home of another Canadian official, [[John Sheardown]] and his wife [[Zena Sheardown]].<ref name=\"BBC News - Argo\"/><ref>{{cite news
column4: title=John Sheardown, Canadian Who Sheltered Americans in Tehran, Dies at 88

column1: * \"It's not true we could never go outside. John Sheardown's house had an interior courtyard with a garden and we could walk there freely,\" Mark Lijek says.<ref name=\"BBC News - Argo\"/>
* Lester Siegel, played by [[Alan Arkin]], is not a real person. His name and some contribution are based on Robert Sidell's while his personality is based on Jack Warner's.<ref>{{cite web

* In the depiction of a frantic effort by CIA headquarters, in Langley, to get President Jimmy Carter to re-authorize the mission so that previously purchased airline tickets would still be valid, a CIA officer is portrayed as getting the [[White House]] telephone operator to connect him to Chief of Staff [[Hamilton Jordan]] by impersonating a representative of the school attended by Jordan's children. In reality, Jordan was unmarried and had no children at the time.<ref>{{cite news
* The film depicts Mendez discovering the script with the title of ''Argo''. In reality the script was titled ''Lord of Light'', based on the [[Lord of Light
column2: book of the same name]] by [[Roger Zelazny]]. The CIA changed the title to ''Argo.''<ref name=\"Bearman\"/><ref name=\"Higgins\">Higgins, Bill; Kit, Borys. \"Argo's odd Hollywood history.\" ''Hollywood Reporter''. October 5, 2012: 64. eLibrary. March 1, 2013.</ref>

column1: * Comic book artist [[Jack Kirby]] did not do his storyboard work for the fabricated CIA film production. He created these when there was an attempt to produce ''Lord of Light'' a few years before the Iranian hostage situation.<ref name=\"Bearman\"/><ref name=\"Higgins\"/>

* The [[Hollywood Sign]] is shown dilapidated as it had been in the 1970s. The sign had been repaired in 1978, two years prior to the events described in the film.<ref>[http://www.hollywoodsign.org/the-history-of-the-sign/1978-a-sign-is-reborn/ 1978: A Sign Is Reborn]. The Hollywood Sign. Retrieved on 2014-05-22.</ref>

* The [[Swissair]] flight that took Mendez and the hostage group out of Tehran is shown operated with a [[Boeing 747]]-300, a type which entered service in 1983, and is painted in a livery that Swissair introduced in 1980. In real life, the group departed Iran on a Swissair [[Douglas DC-8]].<ref>{{cite web

Some [[Hispanic]]s and film critics criticized the casting of Ben Affleck in the role of Mendez, who is of Mexican ancestry on his father's side.<ref>Amanda Hess, [http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2012/10/16/ben_affleck_in_argo_why_is_a_white_guy_playing_tony_mendez.html Ben Affleck Is No Tony Mendez], ''[[Slate (magazine)]]'', October 16, 2012</ref><ref>Ruben Navarrette Jr, [http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/09/opinion/navarrette-argo-affleck-latino Latino should have played lead in 'Argo'], ''[[CNN]]'', January 10, 2013</ref><ref>Eduardo Perez, [http://screenpicks.com/2012/10/perez-why-a-latino-not-ben-affleck-should-have-played-argo-lead-role/ Why a Latino — not Ben Affleck —Should Have Played 'Argo' Lead Role], ''ScreenPicks.com'', October 29, 2012</ref><ref>Moctesuma Esparza, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2013/feb/08/argo-hollywood-latino-hero Argo plays to Hollywood's worst traditions by erasing a Latino hero], ''[[The Guardian]]'', February 8, 2013</ref> [[Mexican-American]] actor and director [[Edward James Olmos]] considered Affleck's casting as Mendez a \"mistake\", and that the actor \"had no sense of the cultural dynamic of the character he was playing\".<ref>[http://www.latinrapper.com/edward-james-olmos-interview-5-4-2013.html Interview with Edward James Olmos], ''LatinRapper.com'', May 4, 2013</ref> However, Mendez himself has said that he was unconcerned about the casting, and noted he does not identify as Hispanic.<ref>[http://nbclatino.com/2013/01/10/argos-real-tony-mendez-im-not-hispanic/ Argo's real Tony Mendez: \"I'm not Hispanic\"], ''NBC Latino'', January 10, 2013</ref> Actor [[Fouad Hajji]], who played Komiteh, is of Moroccan descent.{{fact
* ''[[Escape from Iran: The Canadian Caper]]'', a 1981 television film about the \"[[Canadian Caper]]\".
* ''[[On Wings of Eagles]]'', a 1983 novel by [[Ken Follett]], about [[Ross Perot]]'s successful rescue of several of his employees from Iran just after the revolution.
* [https://www.npr.org/2013/02/22/172600588/affleck-on-argo-and-the-1979-hostage-crisis Radio interview] with Ben Affleck regarding ''Argo'', on NPR's ''[[Fresh Air]]'' (28 mins, 2013)

column2: cover      = 7 Things (Miley Cyrus single - cover art).png
alt        = A three-quarter portrait of a female teen facing left. Her eyes look toward the viewer and her hand is placed on the top of her curly, dark brown hair.

column1: \"'''7 Things'''\" is a song by American singer [[Miley Cyrus]]. The song was co-written by Cyrus, [[Antonina Armato]] and [[Tim James (music producer)
column2: Tim James]], and produced by [[John Fields (producer)
column3: John Fields]]. It was released on June 17, 2008 by [[Hollywood Records]] as the [[lead single]] from the first [[Breakout (Miley Cyrus album)
column4: studio album]] released by Cyrus with no ties to her character [[List of Hannah Montana main characters
column5: Hannah Montana]] from the [[Disney Channel]] comedy series [[Hannah Montana
column6: of the same name]]. Also registered as \"Seven Things I Hate About You\", Cyrus developed the song during the [[Best of Both Worlds Tour]] while feeling numerous emotions for an ex-boyfriend, mainly anger. The song's release brought allegations that it was about [[Nick Jonas]] of the [[Jonas Brothers]], which Cyrus neither confirmed nor denied. Musically, \"7 Things\" bears aspects of both [[country music
column7: country]] and [[pop punk]], while the lyrics in the song's refrain list seven traits Cyrus hates about an ex-boyfriend.

column1: \"7 Things\" received mixed to positive reviews from music critics and enjoyed worldwide commercial success, becoming a top ten hit on charts in Australia, Japan, Norway, and the United States. The single was [[Music recording sales certifications
column2: certified gold]] by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), while its appearance on the [[Japan Hot 100]] made \"7 Things\" Cyrus' first song to chart in an Asian country. The song's accompanying [[music video]] was directed by [[Brett Ratner]] and features Cyrus performing the song with a back-up band as many teenage girls lipsync along. The girls clutch a variety of props, such as [[love letter]]s and [[snow globe]]s, inspired by personal items Cyrus' ex had given her. The video was nominated for an [[MTV Video Music Award]] at both the 2008 and 2009 award shows. Cyrus promoted the song through several venues including her world tours, the [[Wonder World Tour (Miley Cyrus)
column3: Wonder World Tour]] and the [[Gypsy Heart Tour]].

column2: legal title]] of \"Seven Things I Hate About You\", as registered by [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] (BMI).<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=7 Things }}</ref> Like most of the songs on ''Breakout'', Cyrus conceived \"7 Things\" while traveling on the [[Best of Both Worlds Tour]] from October 2007 to January 2008.<ref name=\"onair\">{{cite interview

column2: \"I was locked up in the bus the entire time. And it was, like, such a great time for me to have a minute for myself, which I never get. So it was awesome to get to do that and just kinda go through all the different stages of what's been going on the last couple of years. And I just thought it'd be fun to just kinda. I didn't even mean for it to be for, you know, the record or for anything. It was just like 'just start writing this'. I got into it and I played some of it for my sister and she was like, 'dude, that's awesome'. And it was just so much fun to have, like, a good, little therapy moment for me, just to be able to go through everything. It was awesome. It was so much fun to write.\"<ref name=\"onair\" />}}

column1: Cyrus says \"7 Things\" was inspired by an [[ex-boyfriend]].<ref name=\"7video\" /> In an interview with [[Ryan Seacrest]], Cyrus said that she was \"going through [...] nine-hundred different emotions while trying to write the song\" and that her use of the word \"hate\" demonstrated how furious she was.<ref name=\"onair\" /> When Seacrest asked if she was worried the song's subject would hear it and be upset, Cyrus responded that while she was slightly worried, \"I want him to be upset. That was my point.\"<ref name=\"onair\" /> She showed her draft to co-songwriters and producers Tim James and Antonia Armato, who suggested adding it to ''Breakout''.<ref name=\"onair\" /> Originally, \"7 Things\" was more \"soft and nice\" but Cyrus says she \"went nuts\" during the recording process and gave the song a harder sound.<ref name=\"soundcheck\">{{cite web
column10: df= }}</ref> Cyrus had initially chosen \"[[Fly on the Wall (song)
column11: Fly on the Wall]]\" as the [[lead single]] from ''Breakout'', but replaced it with \"7 Things\" because she felt it was a \"better introduction\" to the album.<ref name=\"mtvfly\">{{cite web
column13: title=Miley Cyrus Spoofs Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' Video -- Swapping Zombies For Paparazzi

column5: alt=A three-quarter portrait of a male teen looking forward. He has dark, curly hair, wears a black leather jacket, and strums a guitar hung over his shoulder.
column6: The release of \"7 Things\" was followed by allegations that it was about [[Nick Jonas]] of the [[Jonas Brothers]].]]

column1: Allegations that \"7 Things\" was about [[Nick Jonas]], lead singer of the [[Jonas Brothers]], arose soon after the song's premiere on the May 13, 2008 broadcast of the ''[[Elvis Duran and the Morning Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column11: df= }}</ref> Cyrus and Jonas had dated for two and a half years before breaking up in late 2008.<ref name=\"datesnick\">{{cite web
column13: title=Miley: Nick Jonas and I 'Were In Love'
column23: url-status=live }}</ref> Cyrus claimed, \"Nick and I loved each other\" and that after the breakup she \"bawled for a month straight\" while trying to rebel \"against everything Nick wanted [her] to be\".<ref name=\"datesnick\" />

column2: Paste]]'' described \"7 Things\" as \"the list of reasons she hates an ex-boyfriend (who just might be lead Jonas Brother, Nick)\" and her \"concern [...] that all of this hatred only leads them to love Maybe-Nick [...] all the more\".<ref name=\"paste\">{{cite web
column9: title=Miley Cyrus' \"7 Things\" vs. 10 Things I Hate About You
column14: url-status= live}}</ref> Blogger Molly Lambert, quoted in ''[[The New York Times]]'' said, \"[Cyrus] had recently broken up with her first serious boyfriend — a fellow Disney celebrity, Nick Jonas, of the Jonas Brothers, who was also her arena-concert tour mate during their secret two-year affair. In the video for '7 Things' she wears Nick’s diabetes dog tags while singing about how his vanity and insecurity undermined their relationship.\"<ref name=\"lambert\">{{cite web
column26: People]]'' similarly points out the necklace and the fact that Jonas, \"who split with Cyrus in late 2008 after two-and a half years of dating – has [[Type 1 diabetes]] and is a spokesperson for awareness of the disease.\"<ref name=\"people\">{{cite web
column28: title=Miley's '7 Things' Is About Nick Jonas, Says Director
column35: publisher=[[Time Inc]]}}</ref> When asked if the allegations were true, Cyrus said,

column2: \"[W]ith '7 Things,' I think a lot of people do, you know, think it’s about Nick Jonas, and if they think it is, that’s fine, or whoever they think it’s about. But mostly that song is about who, um, they want it to be to. Like mostly, it’s if a girl hates her current, or ex-boyfriend—for me it’s an ex-boyfriend—so I think, you know, like, Nick is someone that was really important in my life, but I don’t hate him. It’s a good song and it’s fun.\"<ref name=\"popstar\" />}}

column1: Jonas responded to the allegations with, \"I think it's funny. Honestly, I'm not insecure, my friends are cool—so it can't be about me!\"<ref name=\"popstar\">{{cite web
column3: title=Miley on Nick, Nick on Miley
column10: archivedate=August 19, 2010 }}</ref> According to ''[[Tiger Beat]]'' magazine, when Cyrus' best friend Mandy Jiroux was asked if \"7 Things\" was about Jonas; she responded, \"yes\".<ref name=\"tigerbeat\">{{cite web

column2: description=The uptempo refrains of Miley Cyrus' \"7 Things\" are [[pop rock]] influenced.
pop]] song with a length of three minutes and 33 seconds.<ref name=\"allmusicrev\">{{cite web
column12: last=Phares}}</ref> According to Sal Cinquemani of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'', the song's verses are tinged with [[country pop
column13: country]] while its refrains bear [[pop punk]] aspects.<ref name=\"slant\" /> The song is set in [[common time]] and has moderate rock [[tempo]] of 108 [[beats per minute]]. It is written in the key of [[E major]] while Cyrus' vocals span two [[octaves]], ranging from C#<sub>3</sub> to C#<sub>5</sub>.<ref name=\"sheet\">{{cite web
column15: title=Digital sheet music - Miley Cyrus - 7 Things
column20: archivedate=January 11, 2009}}</ref> Fraser McAlpine of the [[BBC]] called the song \"a three-[[tempo]] patchwork quilt\".<ref name=\"chartblog\">{{cite web
column22: title=Miley Cyrus Counts Up To Four..
column29: introduction]], the band begins to strum acoustic guitars<ref name=\"latimes\">{{cite web
column36: title=Miley Cyrus' '7 Things': Is it time to take her seriously?
column37: date=June 29, 2008}}</ref> at a moderate tempo while Cyrus chants \"sha\".<ref name=\"sheet\" /> The tempo continues as Cyrus begins the first [[Verse (music)
column40: chorus]], \"7 Things\" speeds up dramatically and Cyrus' vocals become aggressive and forceful;<ref name=\"aboutrev\" /> Chris Willman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' described the transition as \"from sensitive breakup song in the strummy verses to punky-pop kiss-off in the double-time choruses.\"<ref name=\"ewr\" /> McAlpine noted the stress Cyrus places on vowels in the song: \"'yerw' instead of 'you', 'erw' instead of 'oh', and so on...\".<ref name=\"chartblog\" />

column1: The song's lyrics are written in [[second person narrative
column2: second person]], a message from the singer to her ex-boyfriend detailing the hurt he caused her while they were dating. The refrain is a list of the seven traits the singer \"hates\" most about her ex, with the seventh item being her frustration that despite his flaws, he makes her love him.<ref name=\"latimes\" /> Ben Ratliff of ''The New York Times'' noted that the list actually \"runs to 8 to 11 things, depending on how you parse it\".<ref name=\"nytimes\" /> Henry Freedland of ''Paste'' magazine compared it to a similar list featured as a poem in the 1999 film ''[[10 Things I Hate About You]]''.<ref name=\"paste\" /> In one verse, Cyrus asks for a sincere apology and states, \"If you [[Text message
column3: text]] it, I'll delete it\", which Molly Lambert of ''The New York Times'' said \"perfectly captur[es] our confusing age of technologically mediated courtship.\"<ref name=\"lambert\" /> The song concludes with a variation of the refrain, in which Cyrus names the seven things she likes the most about her ex, again concluding with \"you make me love you\".<ref name=\"nytimes\" />

column5: alt=A female teen in a black leather hotpants suit sings into a microphone on a blue-hued stage. Behind her, two electric guitarists and a drummer play their instruments.
column6: Cyrus performing \"7 Things\" on the [[Wonder World Tour (Miley Cyrus)

column1: \"7 Things\" received mixed reviews from critics. Fraser McAlpine of the [[BBC]] called the song \"smashing\", complimenting Cyrus' \"punker attitude all wrapped up in an immaculate gloss\".<ref name=\"chartblog\" /> Todd Martens of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that while he wished the song had played up Cyrus' frustration rather than concluding with the kind final verse, \"the winning, full-on chorus -- and Miley's exuberance -- are enough to make it a success.\"<ref name=\"latimes\" /> Ben Ratliff of ''The New York Times'' said \"7 Things\" \"lists with talky insecurity what she hates about a guy\" and calls \"the seven things she likes [...] a shameless Disney ending\".<ref name=\"nytimes\">{{cite news
column9: date=July 21, 2009}}</ref> Heather Phares of [[Allmusic]] contended, \"7 Things\" is a twangy, clever piece of love-hate pop that feels descended from [[Shania Twain]]'s flirty mix of rock and country\" and marked it as one of the best tracks on ''Breakout''.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web
column17: accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref> Chris Willman of ''Entertainment Weekly'' called it one of ''Breakout''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s \"best tunes\" because it \"let Cyrus be feisty without graduating to Avril-like levels of petulance\"<ref name=\"ewr\">{{cite web
column26: last=William}}</ref> while Josh Timmermann of [[PopMatters]] finds it \"appealing\".<ref>{{cite web

column1: Mordechai Shinefield of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' described the song as \"hooky and catchy enough\", but warned that \"it's only a step away from warmed-over [[emo]] platitudes\".<ref>{{cite web
column12: archivedate=December 13, 2009 }}</ref> Sarah Rodman of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' claimed \"[[Avril Lavigne
column13: [Avril] Lavigne]]'s brand of pop-punk snarl creeps into '7 Things'.\"<ref name=\"boston\">{{cite web
column15: title=With her new CD, Miley Cyrus breaks out -- a little
column21: publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}}</ref> [[Robert Christgau]] labeled \"7 Things\" and \"Breakout\" the best songs on ''Breakout''.<ref>{{cite web
column28: last=Christgau}}</ref> Chris Richards of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' claimed the album's \"overproduction is apparent on the chorus of the album's first single, \"7 Things,\" an avalanche of guitars and rushed syllables.\"<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=A Disney Star's 'Breakout', Minus the Blast
column36: accessdate=December 22, 2009}}</ref> Sal Cinquemani of Slant Magazine called the single \"rather annoying\" and not \"a worthy follow-up to '[[See You Again (Miley Cyrus song)
column48: df= }}</ref> while Bill Lamb of [[About.com]] said the \"winning performance\" demonstrated that \"Miley Cyrus does not intend to simply be a TV-generated phenomenon in the pop music world. She is a compelling pop artist in her own right.\"<ref name=\"aboutrev\">{{cite web

column1: On the week ending June 21, 2008, \"7 Things\" debuted at number 85 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column6: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> The song ascended to number seventy the week ending July 5, 2008 before jumping to number 10 in its third week due to sales of 130,000 digital downloads.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Katy Perry Scores 1,000th No. 1 Hit Of Rock Era
column14: title=Chart Beat: Katy Perry, Kathy Griffin, Miley Cyrus
column21: url-status=live }}</ref> \"7 Things\" moved up to number nine on the week ending July 26, 2008, surpassing \"See You Again\" and becoming Cyrus' best charting effort on the Hot 100.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=Katy Perry Starts Fourth Week Atop Hot 100
column40: df= }}</ref> The single managed to spend fifteen weeks on the Hot 100, and was ranked at #92 in the Year-End in 2008. \"7 Things\" also peaked at number 14 on the now-canceled [[Pop 100]] chart.<ref name=\"allmusiccharts\">{{cite web
column45: title=Hannah Montana > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles
column48: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> In Canada, the song debuted at number 40 on the week ending July 5, 2008 and peaked at number 13 on the week ending July 26, 2008.<ref name=\"acharts\" /><ref name=\"billboard\" />   As of June 2013, \"7 Things\" has sold 1,686,000 copies in the United States.<ref name=\"sales2013\">{{cite news
column50: title= Week Ending June 9, 2013. Songs: Pretty Fly For A White Guy

column1: \"7 Things\" was also a success in Australia and New Zealand. The song made its debut on the [[Australian Singles Chart]] at number 38 on August 17, 2008.<ref name=\"aus\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> After five weeks, \"7 Things\" reached its peak on the chart at number ten.<ref name=\"aus\" /> The song has been certified gold by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) for shipping over 35,000 copies.<ref name=\"auscerti\">{{cite web
column14: url-status= live}}</ref> \"7 Things\" debuted at number 27 on the [[New Zealand Singles Chart]] on August 17, 2008 and, after eight weeks on the chart, reached number 24.<ref name=\"nz\">{{cite web
column18: publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]]
column19: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> \"7 Things\" also became Cyrus' first song to chart in an Asian country: On the week ending September 27, 2008, \"7 Things\" debuted at number 81 on the [[Japan Hot 100]];<ref name=\"acharts\" /> it reached number nine on the week ending October 17, 2008 and reached its peak at number eight on the week ending October 24, 2008.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In the [[UK Singles Chart]], \"7 Things\" made its entry at number 87 on September 13, 2008 and reached its peak at number 25 on December 13, 2008.<ref name=\"acharts\" /><ref name=\"uk\">{{cite web
column3: title=The Official Charts Company - Miley Cyrus - 7 Things
column5: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> In mainland Europe, the song peaked at number 44 on [[Eurochart Hot 100 Singles]] and at number 14 in Austria.<ref name=\"billboard\" /><ref name=\"austria\">{{cite web
column11: language=German}}</ref> \"7 Things\" debuted and peaked at number eight on the [[Norwegian Singles Chart]] on August 19, 2008.<ref name=\"norway\">{{cite web
column16: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> The song experienced similar commercial outcomes throughout the rest of Europe; it charted within the top 40 of charts in Belgium (Flanders and Wallonia), Germany, and Switzerland.<ref name=\"norway\" />

column5: alt=A brunette female teen faces forward with hear mouth open; she wears a necklace. Behind her are two guitar players and a white background.
column6: Cyrus wears her ex-boyfriend's [[medical identification tag]] in the \"7 Things\" music video.]]

column1: Cyrus invited [[Brett Ratner]], director of the \"7 Things\" [[music video]], to her home to tell him how much the song meant to her and what it was about.<ref name=\"7video\">{{cite web
column3: title=Miley Cyrus' '7 Things' Is About Nick Jonas, Director Brett Ratner Seemingly Reveals
column13: url-status= live}}</ref> After proposing numerous ideas to each other, they decided to make the video \"simple with a white backdrop\".<ref name=\"onair\" /> Cyrus said that neither she nor Ratner wanted the video to be \"all about [her]\" because the song's message was universal; \"almost every girl in America could say they hate their ex or current boyfriend,\" claimed Cyrus.<ref name=\"onair\" /> As a result, the video features numerous [[adolescence
column14: adolescent girls]] including actresses [[Nicola Peltz]], [[Liana Liberato]], and [[Maiara Walsh]].<ref name=\"onair\" /><ref>{{cite journal
column18: pages=33–34}}</ref> During the planning session, Cyrus showed Ratner a collection of personal items her ex had given her, such as photographs and his dirty socks, which she had stowed away beneath her bed.<ref name=\"7video\" /> They decided to include some of these items as props in the music video. For example, the necklace Cyrus wears in the video was her ex-boyfriend's [[medical identification tag]], which he received because of his [[diabetes mellitus]].<ref name=\"7video\" />

column1: The video was shot on May 30, 2008 in [[Los Angeles, California]]. Unexpectedly, several girls began crying during the shoot; Cyrus attributed this to the emotions in the song.<ref name=\"onair\" /> Ratner was impressed with Cyrus' instinct and ability to address emotional issues while making them \"fun at the same time\".<ref name=\"people\" /> Ratner compared her to [[Madonna (entertainer)
column2: Madonna]], saying, \"she can be hanging out and laughing, and then you put the camera on her and it's like, 'Holy shit!'\"<ref name=\"7video\" /> The effervescence made editing more difficult for the director.<ref name=\"7video\" /> He said, \"It was the hardest video I've ever edited because every moment was great. Every moment that she was on camera, she was amazing. She's got an incredible quality about her. She gets the camera, and that's what it takes to make a great music video.\"<ref name=\"7video\" /> Cyrus commented that she felt the video was \"more honest than [the] song\" and that she was \"singing out to [...] that special person\".<ref name=\"onair\" />
close-up shots]] of Cyrus' face as she counts in the backup band behind her. For a moment, she is replaced by a different girl holding a small [[stuffed animal
column3: stuffed monkey]]. Cyrus then reappears, holding onto her necklace and wearing a multicolored [[sequin]] [[sundress]] designed by Sass & Bide,<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Miley Cyrus wants sass and bide Harlequin frock for new video
column9: accessdate=March 12, 2010}}</ref> black [[Chuck Taylor All-Stars]], and [[leg warmers]]. Her wavy hair styled loose and in front of her shoulders. As Cyrus continues to sing, she is replaced by more girls holding different items, including [[teddy bears]], stuffed animals, [[snow globes]], and love letters. As the song approaches its chorus, Cyrus and the girls start dancing and jumping. Cyrus continues singing as she holds a [[white rose]] and a girl deletes a [[text message]] from her boyfriend. At one point, Cyrus holds a photograph of her and an ex-boyfriend with black curly hair, his face obscured by a [[doodle]] on a piece of notebook paper. At the end of the video, Cyrus blows the camera a kiss, mouths \"I love you,\" and turns away.

column1: The video premiered on June 28, 2008 on [[American Broadcasting Company
column4: title=Disney Announces Lineup for Summer Music Madness
column8: accessdate=December 21, 2009}}</ref> It was the most watched music-related video on [[YouTube]]<ref>{{cite web
column19: url-status= live}}</ref> until it was surpassed by [[Lady Gaga]]'s \"[[Bad Romance]]\" music video in Spring 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Top-5 most popular YouTube videos of all-time
column29: df= }}</ref> Todd Martens of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' was disappointed with the video's special effects and production values, adding that it looked \"as if it were filmed with one camera on a [[tripod]] in a single-bulb basement\".<ref name=\"latimes\" /> However, he complimented how they \"show[ed] off Miley's universal appeal\".<ref name=\"latimes\" /> Henry Freeland of ''Paste'' magazine said, \"Cyrus wiggles to and fro, mugging for the camera like her face is fighting gravity and barely winning.\"<ref name=\"paste\" /> A Pop Cultured review from [[MTV]] described the video as [[Rated PG#Ratings
column38: author=Pop Cultured}}</ref> The review continued that it was mildly angry, comparing Cyrus to \"a watered-down version of [[Avril Lavigne]]'s kid sister, and [[Lindsay Lohan]]'s pseudo-rebellious character in ''[[Freaky Friday (2003 film)
column39: Freaky Friday]]'' — minus the eyeliner\".<ref name=\"buzz\" /> Leigh Holmwood of ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented, \"Miley's new music vid, reminds me, creepily enough, of early [[Britney Spears
column47: author=Holmwood, Leigh}}</ref> Molly Lambert of the ''New York Times'' described Cyrus as the video's \"charismatic center\" and writes, \"When she flashes Nick’s dog tags and a picture of the two of them together, she seems so vindictive and so embarrassingly vulnerable, just like . . . a 15-year-old suffering her first serious heartbreak, basically.\"<ref name=\"lambert\" /> The video received a nomination for [[MTV Video Music Award for Best New Artist]] at the [[2008 MTV Video Music Awards]], but lost to [[Tokio Hotel]]'s music video for \"[[Übers Ende der Welt
column53: title=2008 MTV Video Music Awards - Winners
column56: url-status= live}}</ref> At the [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards]], the video received a nomination for [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Editing]], but lost to [[Beyoncé Knowles]]' music video for \"[[Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)]]\".<ref>{{cite web
column61: title=2009 MTV Video Music Awards l Winners

column1: Cyrus first live performance of \"7 Things\" took place on May 17, 2008 at the 2008 [[Zootopia]], an annual summer concert put on by radio station [[WHTZ
column7: title=Jonas Brothers, New Kids on the Block, Miley Cyrus Earn Fans' Shrieks at Zootopia
column13: accessdate=September 27, 2009}}</ref> Later that summer, she promoted the song at outdoor concerts hosted by ''[[Good Morning America]]''<ref name=\"gma\">{{cite web

column31: accessdate=June 17, 2010}}</ref> and while hosting the 2008 [[Teen Choice Awards]].<ref>{{cite web
column39: title=Miley Cyrus, Jonas Brothers, Chris Brown, 'Gossip Girl' Win Big At Teen Choice Awards}}</ref> Cyrus began promotion for \"7 Things\" in Europe in fall 2008, performing the track on the United Kingdom breakfast TV show [[GMTV]], the French television show ''Le Grand Journal'' and the British singing competition ''[[The X Factor (UK)
column40: The X Factor]]'' among other venues.<ref>{{cite web
column46: date=November 29, 2009}}</ref> She performed the song twice on ''[[FNMTV]]''; once on August 1, 2008,<ref>{{cite web
column48: title=FNMTV: Miley Cyrus performs; video debuts from Hawthorne Heights, All Time Low, David Banner

column56: title=Miley Cyrus Will Help 'FNMTV' Ring Out 2008 -- From A Fan's Bedroom!

column2: Apple Store]]. These performances were recorded and sold exclusively by the United Kingdom [[iTunes Store]] as a live [[extended play]] titled ''iTunes Live from London''.<ref name=\"livefromlondon\">{{cite web
column11: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On June 7, 2009, Cyrus performed the song at twentieth annual A Time for Heroes Celebrity Carnival, an outdoor carnival supporting the [[Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Miley Cyrus - A Time for Heroes Celebrity Carnival

column32: df= }}</ref> \"7 Things\" was also included in the set list of Cyrus' first world tour, the [[Wonder World Tour (Miley Cyrus)
column33: Wonder World Tour]]; Cyrus performed the song in a black leather ensemble paired with a silver [[rosary]] while overhead video screens projected a [[conflagration]].<ref name=\"wwt2\">{{cite web

column4: title=Review: Miley Cyrus Rocks the Rose Garden as She Kicks off Tour in Portland
column11: archivedate=January 11, 2010}}</ref> Melinda M. Thompsen of ''[[The Oregonian]]'' said Cyrus' performance of \"7 Things\" the September 14 concert in Portland, Oregon at the [[Rose Garden (arena)
column12: Rose Garden Arena]] \"showed what a powerhouse she can be using her voice and influence to get her message out\".<ref name=\"wwt2\" /> The song's performance in the September 22 concert in Los Angeles, California at the [[Staples Center]] was referred to as \"aggressive athleticism\" by Lael Loewenstein of ''[[Variety (magazine)
column13: Variety]]'' and as a \"tween-rock gem\" and \"up-tempo highlight\" by Mikael Wood of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]''.<ref name=\"variety\">{{cite web
column24: title=Live review: Miley Cyrus' 'Wonder World' concert at Staples Center
column30: publisher=[[Tribune Company]]}}</ref> She later performed the song at the [[Rock in Rio#Rock in Rio Lisboa & Madrid (2010)
