column1: \"'''7 Things'''\" is a song by American singer [[Miley Cyrus]]. The song was co-written by Cyrus, [[Antonina Armato]] and [[Tim James (music producer)
column2: Tim James]], and produced by [[John Fields (producer)
column3: John Fields]]. It was released on June 17, 2008 by [[Hollywood Records]] as the [[lead single]] from the first [[Breakout (Miley Cyrus album)
column4: studio album]] released by Cyrus with no ties to her character [[List of Hannah Montana main characters
column5: Hannah Montana]] from the [[Disney Channel]] comedy series [[Hannah Montana
column6: of the same name]]. Also registered as \"Seven Things I Hate About You\", Cyrus developed the song during the [[Best of Both Worlds Tour]] while feeling numerous emotions for an ex-boyfriend, mainly anger. The song's release brought allegations that it was about [[Nick Jonas]] of the [[Jonas Brothers]], which Cyrus neither confirmed nor denied. Musically, \"7 Things\" bears aspects of both [[country music
column7: country]] and [[pop punk]], while the lyrics in the song's refrain list seven traits Cyrus hates about an ex-boyfriend.

column1: \"7 Things\" received mixed to positive reviews from music critics and enjoyed worldwide commercial success, becoming a top ten hit on charts in Australia, Japan, Norway, and the United States. The single was [[Music recording sales certifications
column2: certified gold]] by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), while its appearance on the [[Japan Hot 100]] made \"7 Things\" Cyrus' first song to chart in an Asian country. The song's accompanying [[music video]] was directed by [[Brett Ratner]] and features Cyrus performing the song with a back-up band as many teenage girls lipsync along. The girls clutch a variety of props, such as [[love letter]]s and [[snow globe]]s, inspired by personal items Cyrus' ex had given her. The video was nominated for an [[MTV Video Music Award]] at both the 2008 and 2009 award shows. Cyrus promoted the song through several venues including her world tours, the [[Wonder World Tour (Miley Cyrus)
column3: Wonder World Tour]] and the [[Gypsy Heart Tour]].

column2: legal title]] of \"Seven Things I Hate About You\", as registered by [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] (BMI).<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=7 Things }}</ref> Like most of the songs on ''Breakout'', Cyrus conceived \"7 Things\" while traveling on the [[Best of Both Worlds Tour]] from October 2007 to January 2008.<ref name=\"onair\">{{cite interview

column2: \"I was locked up in the bus the entire time. And it was, like, such a great time for me to have a minute for myself, which I never get. So it was awesome to get to do that and just kinda go through all the different stages of what's been going on the last couple of years. And I just thought it'd be fun to just kinda. I didn't even mean for it to be for, you know, the record or for anything. It was just like 'just start writing this'. I got into it and I played some of it for my sister and she was like, 'dude, that's awesome'. And it was just so much fun to have, like, a good, little therapy moment for me, just to be able to go through everything. It was awesome. It was so much fun to write.\"<ref name=\"onair\" />}}

column1: Cyrus says \"7 Things\" was inspired by an [[ex-boyfriend]].<ref name=\"7video\" /> In an interview with [[Ryan Seacrest]], Cyrus said that she was \"going through [...] nine-hundred different emotions while trying to write the song\" and that her use of the word \"hate\" demonstrated how furious she was.<ref name=\"onair\" /> When Seacrest asked if she was worried the song's subject would hear it and be upset, Cyrus responded that while she was slightly worried, \"I want him to be upset. That was my point.\"<ref name=\"onair\" /> She showed her draft to co-songwriters and producers Tim James and Antonia Armato, who suggested adding it to ''Breakout''.<ref name=\"onair\" /> Originally, \"7 Things\" was more \"soft and nice\" but Cyrus says she \"went nuts\" during the recording process and gave the song a harder sound.<ref name=\"soundcheck\">{{cite web
column10: df= }}</ref> Cyrus had initially chosen \"[[Fly on the Wall (song)
column11: Fly on the Wall]]\" as the [[lead single]] from ''Breakout'', but replaced it with \"7 Things\" because she felt it was a \"better introduction\" to the album.<ref name=\"mtvfly\">{{cite web
column13: title=Miley Cyrus Spoofs Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' Video -- Swapping Zombies For Paparazzi

column5: alt=A three-quarter portrait of a male teen looking forward. He has dark, curly hair, wears a black leather jacket, and strums a guitar hung over his shoulder.
column6: The release of \"7 Things\" was followed by allegations that it was about [[Nick Jonas]] of the [[Jonas Brothers]].]]

column1: Allegations that \"7 Things\" was about [[Nick Jonas]], lead singer of the [[Jonas Brothers]], arose soon after the song's premiere on the May 13, 2008 broadcast of the ''[[Elvis Duran and the Morning Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column11: df= }}</ref> Cyrus and Jonas had dated for two and a half years before breaking up in late 2008.<ref name=\"datesnick\">{{cite web
column13: title=Miley: Nick Jonas and I 'Were In Love'
column23: url-status=live }}</ref> Cyrus claimed, \"Nick and I loved each other\" and that after the breakup she \"bawled for a month straight\" while trying to rebel \"against everything Nick wanted [her] to be\".<ref name=\"datesnick\" />

column2: Paste]]'' described \"7 Things\" as \"the list of reasons she hates an ex-boyfriend (who just might be lead Jonas Brother, Nick)\" and her \"concern [...] that all of this hatred only leads them to love Maybe-Nick [...] all the more\".<ref name=\"paste\">{{cite web
column9: title=Miley Cyrus' \"7 Things\" vs. 10 Things I Hate About You
column14: url-status= live}}</ref> Blogger Molly Lambert, quoted in ''[[The New York Times]]'' said, \"[Cyrus] had recently broken up with her first serious boyfriend — a fellow Disney celebrity, Nick Jonas, of the Jonas Brothers, who was also her arena-concert tour mate during their secret two-year affair. In the video for '7 Things' she wears Nick’s diabetes dog tags while singing about how his vanity and insecurity undermined their relationship.\"<ref name=\"lambert\">{{cite web
column26: People]]'' similarly points out the necklace and the fact that Jonas, \"who split with Cyrus in late 2008 after two-and a half years of dating – has [[Type 1 diabetes]] and is a spokesperson for awareness of the disease.\"<ref name=\"people\">{{cite web
column28: title=Miley's '7 Things' Is About Nick Jonas, Says Director
column35: publisher=[[Time Inc]]}}</ref> When asked if the allegations were true, Cyrus said,

column2: \"[W]ith '7 Things,' I think a lot of people do, you know, think it’s about Nick Jonas, and if they think it is, that’s fine, or whoever they think it’s about. But mostly that song is about who, um, they want it to be to. Like mostly, it’s if a girl hates her current, or ex-boyfriend—for me it’s an ex-boyfriend—so I think, you know, like, Nick is someone that was really important in my life, but I don’t hate him. It’s a good song and it’s fun.\"<ref name=\"popstar\" />}}

column1: Jonas responded to the allegations with, \"I think it’s funny. Honestly, I’m not insecure, my friends are cool—so it can’t be about me!\"<ref name=\"popstar\">{{cite web
column3: title=Miley on Nick, Nick on Miley
column10: archivedate=August 19, 2010 }}</ref> According to ''[[Tiger Beat]]'' magazine, when Cyrus' best friend Mandy Jiroux was asked if \"7 Things\" was about Jonas; she responded, \"yes\".<ref name=\"tigerbeat\">{{cite web

column2: description=The uptempo refrains of Miley Cyrus' \"7 Things\" are [[pop rock]] influenced.
pop]] song with a length of three minutes and 33 seconds.<ref name=\"allmusicrev\">{{cite web
column12: last=Phares}}</ref> According to Sal Cinquemani of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'', the song's verses are tinged with [[country pop
column13: country]] while its refrains bear [[pop punk]] aspects.<ref name=\"slant\" /> The song is set in [[common time]] and has moderate rock [[tempo]] of 108 [[beats per minute]]. It is written in the key of [[E major]] while Cyrus' vocals span two [[octaves]], ranging from C#<sub>3</sub> to C#<sub>5</sub>.<ref name=\"sheet\">{{cite web
column15: title=Digital sheet music - Miley Cyrus - 7 Things
column20: archivedate=January 11, 2009}}</ref> Fraser McAlpine of the [[BBC]] called the song \"a three-[[tempo]] patchwork quilt\".<ref name=\"chartblog\">{{cite web
column22: title=Miley Cyrus Counts Up To Four..
column29: introduction]], the band begins to strum acoustic guitars<ref name=\"latimes\">{{cite web
column36: title=Miley Cyrus' '7 Things': Is it time to take her seriously?
column37: date=June 29, 2008}}</ref> at a moderate tempo while Cyrus chants \"sha\".<ref name=\"sheet\" /> The tempo continues as Cyrus begins the first [[Verse (music)
column40: chorus]], \"7 Things\" speeds up dramatically and Cyrus' vocals become aggressive and forceful;<ref name=\"aboutrev\" /> Chris Willman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' described the transition as \"from sensitive breakup song in the strummy verses to punky-pop kiss-off in the double-time choruses.\"<ref name=\"ewr\" /> McAlpine noted the stress Cyrus places on vowels in the song: \"'yerw' instead of 'you', 'erw' instead of 'oh', and so on...\".<ref name=\"chartblog\" />

column1: The song's lyrics are written in [[second person narrative
column2: second person]], a message from the singer to her ex-boyfriend detailing the hurt he caused her while they were dating. The refrain is a list of the seven traits the singer \"hates\" most about her ex, with the seventh item being her frustration that despite his flaws, he makes her love him.<ref name=\"latimes\" /> Ben Ratliff of ''The New York Times'' noted that the list actually \"runs to 8 to 11 things, depending on how you parse it\".<ref name=\"nytimes\" /> Henry Freedland of ''Paste'' magazine compared it to a similar list featured as a poem in the 1999 film ''[[10 Things I Hate About You]]''.<ref name=\"paste\" /> In one verse, Cyrus asks for a sincere apology and states, \"If you [[Text message
column3: text]] it, I'll delete it\", which Molly Lambert of ''The New York Times'' said \"perfectly captur[es] our confusing age of technologically mediated courtship.\"<ref name=\"lambert\" /> The song concludes with a variation of the refrain, in which Cyrus names the seven things she likes the most about her ex, again concluding with \"you make me love you\".<ref name=\"nytimes\" />

column5: alt=A female teen in a black leather hotpants suit sings into a microphone on a blue-hued stage. Behind her, two electric guitarists and a drummer play their instruments.
column6: Cyrus performing \"7 Things\" on the [[Wonder World Tour (Miley Cyrus)

column1: \"7 Things\" received mixed reviews from critics. Fraser McAlpine of the [[BBC]] called the song \"smashing\", complimenting Cyrus' \"punker attitude all wrapped up in an immaculate gloss\".<ref name=\"chartblog\" /> Todd Martens of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that while he wished the song had played up Cyrus' frustration rather than concluding with the kind final verse, \"the winning, full-on chorus -- and Miley's exuberance -- are enough to make it a success.\"<ref name=\"latimes\" /> Ben Ratliff of ''The New York Times'' said \"7 Things\" \"lists with talky insecurity what she hates about a guy\" and calls \"the seven things she likes [...] a shameless Disney ending\".<ref name=\"nytimes\">{{cite news
column9: date=July 21, 2009}}</ref> Heather Phares of [[Allmusic]] contended, \"7 Things\" is a twangy, clever piece of love-hate pop that feels descended from [[Shania Twain]]'s flirty mix of rock and country\" and marked it as one of the best tracks on ''Breakout''.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web
column17: accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref> Chris Willman of ''Entertainment Weekly'' called it one of ''Breakout''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s \"best tunes\" because it \"let Cyrus be feisty without graduating to Avril-like levels of petulance\"<ref name=\"ewr\">{{cite web
column26: last=William}}</ref> while Josh Timmermann of [[PopMatters]] finds it \"appealing\".<ref>{{cite web

column1: Mordechai Shinefield of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' described the song as \"hooky and catchy enough\", but warned that \"it's only a step away from warmed-over [[emo]] platitudes\".<ref>{{cite web
column12: archivedate=December 13, 2009 }}</ref> Sarah Rodman of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' claimed \"[[Avril Lavigne
column13: [Avril] Lavigne]]'s brand of pop-punk snarl creeps into '7 Things'.\"<ref name=\"boston\">{{cite web
column15: title=With her new CD, Miley Cyrus breaks out -- a little
column21: publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}}</ref> [[Robert Christgau]] labeled \"7 Things\" and \"Breakout\" the best songs on ''Breakout''.<ref>{{cite web
column28: last=Christgau}}</ref> Chris Richards of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' claimed the album's \"overproduction is apparent on the chorus of the album's first single, \"7 Things,\" an avalanche of guitars and rushed syllables.\"<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=A Disney Star's 'Breakout', Minus the Blast
column36: accessdate=December 22, 2009}}</ref> Sal Cinquemani of Slant Magazine called the single \"rather annoying\" and not \"a worthy follow-up to '[[See You Again (Miley Cyrus song)
column48: df= }}</ref> while Bill Lamb of [[About.com]] said the \"winning performance\" demonstrated that \"Miley Cyrus does not intend to simply be a TV-generated phenomenon in the pop music world. She is a compelling pop artist in her own right.\"<ref name=\"aboutrev\">{{cite web

column1: On the week ending June 21, 2008, \"7 Things\" debuted at number 85 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column6: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> The song ascended to number seventy the week ending July 5, 2008 before jumping to number 10 in its third week due to sales of 130,000 digital downloads.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Katy Perry Scores 1,000th No. 1 Hit Of Rock Era
column14: title=Chart Beat: Katy Perry, Kathy Griffin, Miley Cyrus
column21: url-status=live }}</ref> \"7 Things\" moved up to number nine on the week ending July 26, 2008, surpassing \"See You Again\" and becoming Cyrus' best charting effort on the Hot 100.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=Katy Perry Starts Fourth Week Atop Hot 100
column40: df= }}</ref> The single managed to spend fifteen weeks on the Hot 100, and was ranked at #92 in the Year-End in 2008. \"7 Things\" also peaked at number 14 on the now-canceled [[Pop 100]] chart.<ref name=\"allmusiccharts\">{{cite web
column45: title=Hannah Montana > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles
column48: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> In Canada, the song debuted at number 40 on the week ending July 5, 2008 and peaked at number 13 on the week ending July 26, 2008.<ref name=\"acharts\" /><ref name=\"billboard\" />   As of June 2013, \"7 Things\" has sold 1,686,000 copies in the United States.<ref name=\"sales2013\">{{cite news
column50: title= Week Ending June 9, 2013. Songs: Pretty Fly For A White Guy

column1: \"7 Things\" was also a success in Australia and New Zealand. The song made its debut on the [[Australian Singles Chart]] at number 38 on August 17, 2008.<ref name=\"aus\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> After five weeks, \"7 Things\" reached its peak on the chart at number ten.<ref name=\"aus\" /> The song has been certified gold by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) for shipping over 35,000 copies.<ref name=\"auscerti\">{{cite web
column14: url-status= live}}</ref> \"7 Things\" debuted at number 27 on the [[New Zealand Singles Chart]] on August 17, 2008 and, after eight weeks on the chart, reached number 24.<ref name=\"nz\">{{cite web
column18: publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]]
column19: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> \"7 Things\" also became Cyrus' first song to chart in an Asian country: On the week ending September 27, 2008, \"7 Things\" debuted at number 81 on the [[Japan Hot 100]];<ref name=\"acharts\" /> it reached number nine on the week ending October 17, 2008 and reached its peak at number eight on the week ending October 24, 2008.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In the [[UK Singles Chart]], \"7 Things\" made its entry at number 87 on September 13, 2008 and reached its peak at number 25 on December 13, 2008.<ref name=\"acharts\" /><ref name=\"uk\">{{cite web
column3: title=The Official Charts Company - Miley Cyrus - 7 Things
column5: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> In mainland Europe, the song peaked at number 44 on [[Eurochart Hot 100 Singles]] and at number 14 in Austria.<ref name=\"billboard\" /><ref name=\"austria\">{{cite web
column11: language=German}}</ref> \"7 Things\" debuted and peaked at number eight on the [[Norwegian Singles Chart]] on August 19, 2008.<ref name=\"norway\">{{cite web
column16: accessdate=December 20, 2009}}</ref> The song experienced similar commercial outcomes throughout the rest of Europe; it charted within the top 40 of charts in Belgium (Flanders and Wallonia), Germany, and Switzerland.<ref name=\"norway\" />

column5: alt=A brunette female teen faces forward with hear mouth open; she wears a necklace. Behind her are two guitar players and a white background.
column6: Cyrus wears her ex-boyfriend's [[medical identification tag]] in the \"7 Things\" music video.]]

column1: Cyrus invited [[Brett Ratner]], director of the \"7 Things\" [[music video]], to her home to tell him how much the song meant to her and what it was about.<ref name=\"7video\">{{cite web
column3: title=Miley Cyrus' '7 Things' Is About Nick Jonas, Director Brett Ratner Seemingly Reveals
column13: url-status= live}}</ref> After proposing numerous ideas to each other, they decided to make the video \"simple with a white backdrop\".<ref name=\"onair\" /> Cyrus said that neither she nor Ratner wanted the video to be \"all about [her]\" because the song's message was universal; \"almost every girl in America could say they hate their ex or current boyfriend,\" claimed Cyrus.<ref name=\"onair\" /> As a result, the video features numerous [[adolescence
column14: adolescent girls]] including actresses [[Nicola Peltz]], [[Liana Liberato]], and [[Maiara Walsh]].<ref name=\"onair\" /><ref>{{cite journal
column18: pages=33–34}}</ref> During the planning session, Cyrus showed Ratner a collection of personal items her ex had given her, such as photographs and his dirty socks, which she had stowed away beneath her bed.<ref name=\"7video\" /> They decided to include some of these items as props in the music video. For example, the necklace Cyrus wears in the video was her ex-boyfriend's [[medical identification tag]], which he received because of his [[diabetes mellitus]].<ref name=\"7video\" />

column1: The video was shot on May 30, 2008 in [[Los Angeles, California]]. Unexpectedly, several girls began crying during the shoot; Cyrus attributed this to the emotions in the song.<ref name=\"onair\" /> Ratner was impressed with Cyrus' instinct and ability to address emotional issues while making them \"fun at the same time\".<ref name=\"people\" /> Ratner compared her to [[Madonna (entertainer)
column2: Madonna]], saying, \"she can be hanging out and laughing, and then you put the camera on her and it's like, 'Holy shit!'\"<ref name=\"7video\" /> The effervescence made editing more difficult for the director.<ref name=\"7video\" /> He said, \"It was the hardest video I've ever edited because every moment was great. Every moment that she was on camera, she was amazing. She's got an incredible quality about her. She gets the camera, and that's what it takes to make a great music video.\"<ref name=\"7video\" /> Cyrus commented that she felt the video was \"more honest than [the] song\" and that she was \"singing out to [...] that special person\".<ref name=\"onair\" />
close-up shots]] of Cyrus' face as she counts in the backup band behind her. For a moment, she is replaced by a different girl holding a small [[stuffed animal
column3: stuffed monkey]]. Cyrus then reappears, holding onto her necklace and wearing a multicolored [[sequin]] [[sundress]] designed by Sass & Bide,<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Miley Cyrus wants sass and bide Harlequin frock for new video
column9: accessdate=March 12, 2010}}</ref> black [[Chuck Taylor All-Stars]], and [[leg warmers]]. Her wavy hair styled loose and in front of her shoulders. As Cyrus continues to sing, she is replaced by more girls holding different items, including [[teddy bears]], stuffed animals, [[snow globes]], and love letters. As the song approaches its chorus, Cyrus and the girls start dancing and jumping. Cyrus continues singing as she holds a [[white rose]] and a girl deletes a [[text message]] from her boyfriend. At one point, Cyrus holds a photograph of her and an ex-boyfriend with black curly hair, his face obscured by a [[doodle]] on a piece of notebook paper. At the end of the video, Cyrus blows the camera a kiss, mouths \"I love you,\" and turns away.

column1: The video premiered on June 28, 2008 on [[American Broadcasting Company
column4: title=Disney Announces Lineup for Summer Music Madness
column8: accessdate=December 21, 2009}}</ref> It was the most watched music-related video on [[YouTube]]<ref>{{cite web
column19: url-status= live}}</ref> until it was surpassed by [[Lady Gaga]]'s \"[[Bad Romance]]\" music video in Spring 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Top-5 most popular YouTube videos of all-time
column29: df= }}</ref> Todd Martens of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' was disappointed with the video's special effects and production values, adding that it looked \"as if it were filmed with one camera on a [[tripod]] in a single-bulb basement\".<ref name=\"latimes\" /> However, he complimented how they \"show[ed] off Miley's universal appeal\".<ref name=\"latimes\" /> Henry Freeland of ''Paste'' magazine said, \"Cyrus wiggles to and fro, mugging for the camera like her face is fighting gravity and barely winning.\"<ref name=\"paste\" /> A Pop Cultured review from [[MTV]] described the video as [[Rated PG#Ratings
column38: author=Pop Cultured}}</ref> The review continued that it was mildly angry, comparing Cyrus to \"a watered-down version of [[Avril Lavigne]]'s kid sister, and [[Lindsay Lohan]]'s pseudo-rebellious character in ''[[Freaky Friday (2003 film)
column39: Freaky Friday]]'' — minus the eyeliner\".<ref name=\"buzz\" /> Leigh Holmwood of ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented, \"Miley's new music vid, reminds me, creepily enough, of early [[Britney Spears
column47: author=Holmwood, Leigh}}</ref> Molly Lambert of the ''New York Times'' described Cyrus as the video's \"charismatic center\" and writes, \"When she flashes Nick’s dog tags and a picture of the two of them together, she seems so vindictive and so embarrassingly vulnerable, just like . . . a 15-year-old suffering her first serious heartbreak, basically.\"<ref name=\"lambert\" /> The video received a nomination for [[MTV Video Music Award for Best New Artist]] at the [[2008 MTV Video Music Awards]], but lost to [[Tokio Hotel]]'s music video for \"[[Übers Ende der Welt
column53: title=2008 MTV Video Music Awards - Winners

\"'''The Man'''\" is a song by American singer-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]]. The song was serviced to US [[Hot adult contemporary
column3: pop]] radio formats on January 27 and 28, 2020 as the fourth single from Swift's seventh studio album, ''[[Lover (album)
column4: Lover]]'' (2019)''.'' Swift wrote and produced the song with [[Joel Little]]. It is a [[synth-pop]] song which features flashy harmonies and murky synths. Over an uptempo production, Swift imagines the media's treatment of her if she were a man. The song received acclaim from critics, who praised its [[feminism

column1: \"The Man\" peaked at number 23 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100
column2: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]], becoming the fourth consecutive single from ''Lover'' to peak inside the top 40 of the chart. It also debuted at number 4 on the [[Rolling Stone Top 100
column3: ''Rolling Stone'' Top 100]]. It entered the top 40 on charts in Australia, Belgium, Canada, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Ireland, Malaysia, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, Slovakia and the United Kingdom. On February 7, 2020, an animated lyric video of the song was released on [[YouTube]]. On February 18, 2020, a live acoustic version of the song, titled \"The Man (Live from Paris)\", was released on all music platforms, accompanied by its live video.

column1: An official music video for \"The Man\" was released on February 27, 2020 and was directed by Swift herself, marking her solo directorial debut. The [[Satire
column2: satirical]] video sees Swift in her theoretical male alter-ego named \"Tyler Swift\", presenting several prevalent examples of [[Sexism
column3: sexist]] double standards in society, including [[Sexual objectification

column4: American actor [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] is name-checked in the lyrics of the song, whose films, ''[[Inception]]'' and ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)
column5: The Wolf of Wall Street]]'', are further referenced in its lyric video and music video, respectively.
column6: alt=Leonardo DiCaprio attending a film premiere]]The recording process for [[Taylor Swift]]'s seventh studio album ''[[Lover (album)
column7: Lover]]'' took under three months, and concluded in February 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=New Reputation: Taylor Swift shares intel on TS7, fan theories, and her next era
column14: date=May 9, 2019}}</ref> [[Joel Little]] was revealed as one of the producers for the album with the release of lead single \"[[Me!]]\" in April. He co-wrote and co-produced four of the eighteen tracks for the album.<ref name=\"notes\">{{cite AV media notes
column22: id=B003061202}}</ref> The song title was revealed along with the lyrics \"I'd be a fearless leader / I'd be an alpha type / When everyone believes ya— / What's that like?\" in Swift's ''[[Vogue (magazine)
column23: Vogue]]'' cover interview for the September 2019 issue.<ref name=\"Vogue\">{{cite magazine
column25: title=Taylor Swift on Sexism, Scrutiny, and Standing Up for Herself

column1: \"The Man\" is a [[synth-pop]] song which features flashy harmonies and murky synths. Over an uptempo production, Swift imagines the media's treatment of her if she were a man. She challenges societal sexist double standards, with lyrics including a noteworthy reference to American actor [[Leonardo DiCaprio]].<ref name=\"indep\">{{cite web
column4: title=Taylor Swift, Lover review: The sound of an artist excited to be earnest again
column8: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Swift uses the actor as an example to explain sexism, singing \"And they would toast to me, oh, let the players play/I'd be just like Leo in [[Saint-Tropez]]\".<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Taylor Swift Uses Leonardo DiCaprio As an Example to Explain Sexism in 'The Man'
column16: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> In outtakes from an interview with ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column17: Billboard]]'' in December 2019, Swift said she wrote the song not only from personal experience, but also from hearing the general experiences of women working across all parts of the music industry.<ref>{{cite magazine
column19: title=Taylor Swift Discusses 'The Man' & 'It's Nice To Have a Friend' In Cover Story Outtakes

column2: We [women] have to curate and cater everything, but we have to make it look like an accident. Because if we make a mistake, that's our fault, but if we strategize so that we won't make a mistake, we're calculating. There is a bit of a damned-if-we-do, damned-if-we-don't thing happening in music.}}

column1: According to ''Billboard''{{'s}} Gil Kaufman, \"The Man\" is a pointed statement about \"how much harder women need to work than men to get to the same finish line\".<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Drake, Idris Elba, Leo DiCaprio & More: All Of the Celeb Moments On Taylor Swift's 'Lover'
column9: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Jason Lipshutz of the same magazine described the song as a \"biting look at gender dynamics within both the pop industry and celebrity-driven culture\", noting that it is sonically composed of a rumbling beat and crackling synths and lyrically provides wry humor and an honest perspective.<ref name=\"BBLipshutz\">{{cite web
column12: title=Every Song Ranked on Taylor Swift's 'Lover': Critic's Picks
column16: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> An animated lyric video for \"The Man\" was released on February 7, 2020 at 12pm.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Taylor Swift's 'The Man' Lyric Video Is on the Way

column1: \"The Man\" received critical acclaim upon release, with praise towards its lyrics about [[sexism]] and [[women empowerment]].

''[[The Atlantic]]''{{'}}s Spencer Kornhaber described \"The Man\" as \"one of the most straightforwardly catchy songs\" on ''Lover'', and further called it Swift's \"most explicit musical statement on sexism\".<ref name=\"atlantic\">{{cite web
column4: title=Why Taylor Swift Wants to Be 'The Man'
column8: date=August 29, 2019}}</ref> He opined that the [[Leonardo DiCaprio
column9: DiCaprio]] reference is the \"most memorable\" line of the song. Brittany Hodak of ''[[Forbes]]'', praised the song as \"the most important song she's [Swift has] ever written\". She also stated that the song is \"a brilliant portrayal of the subtle and not-so-subtle sexism women face every day\".<ref>{{cite magazine
column11: title=Why 'Lover' Track 'The Man' Is The Most Important Song Taylor Swift Has Ever Written
column17: Time]]''{{'}}s Raisa Bruner labelled the song as \"a bombastic, empowering bop\" that is \"an anthem for anyone who's felt blocked by sexist double standards\".<ref>{{cite magazine
column19: title=Let's Discuss the Lyrics to Every Song on Taylor Swift's Lover
column25: accessdate=November 21, 2019}}</ref> Comparing the song to Swift's 2017 album, [[Rob Sheffield]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described \"The Man\" as \"a righteous feminist bombshell ''[[Reputation (Taylor Swift album)
column28: title=Why 'Lover' Is the Ultimate Taylor Swift Album
column34: Slate]]''{{'}}s Carl Wilson opined that the song \"widens the lens and makes a more convincing case for her [Swift's] grievances than on any beefing track she's ever written\". He further described the song as a \"synth-strut mode very reminiscent of [[Haim (band)
column35: Haim]]\" that \"takes aim at sexist music industry and media double standards and just keeps firing bull's-eyes\".<ref>{{cite magazine
column37: title=Taylor Swift's Lover Is a More Mature (Mostly) Successor to Red

column1: Writing for ''[[Elite Daily]]'', Sade Spence and Kristen Perrone stated that the lyrics of the song are \"super bold and carry a powerful message about women\". They further stated that the song is an addition to the \"legendary canon of crafty takes on sexism\" in music.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Taylor Swift's \"The Man\" Lyrics Are Pure, Perfect Girl Power
column10: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Allie Gemmill of ''[[Teen Vogue]]'' stated that the song \"gives women permission to keep challenging sexist double standards, and fans are here for it\", adding that the \"fierce\" song includes \"many incredibly good lyrics\".<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Taylor Swift's New Song 'The Man' Calls Out Leonardo DiCaprio in Saint Tropez and Sexist Double Standards
column17: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Writing for ''Billboard'', Jason Lipshutz called it \"a complete jam\" and ranked it as the 12th best track on the album, and further expanded that it \"will draw attention for its searing subject matter, but it's also one of ''Lover''{{'}}s most complete productions\".<ref name=\"BBLipshutz\" /> The same magazine's Gab Ginsberg opined that \"The Man\" is \"catchy-as-all-heck\".<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=What Should Taylor Swift's Next 'Lover' Single Be? Vote!
column24: date=August 29, 2019}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Jon Caramanica described the song \"excellent and pointed\" and stated that the song is a \"stern synth-pop take\" on sexism.<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=Taylor Swift Emerges From the Darkness Unbroken on 'Lover
column32: Spin]]'' negatively compared the song to \"[[You Need to Calm Down]]\", stating that the lyric \"If I was a man, then I'd be the man\" doesn't really offer much insight.<ref>{{cite web
column35: title=Taylor Swift's Lover Shines in Its Quietest Moments

column1: In the United States, following the release of its parent album ''Lover'', \"The Man\" debuted at number 4 on the [[Streaming Songs
column2: ''Billboard'' Streaming Songs]] chart, number 23 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column3: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and number 32 on the [[Digital Songs
column4: ''Billboard'' Digital Song Sales]] chart, all dated September 7, 2019.<ref name=\"US\">{{cite web
column7: title=All 18 Songs From Taylor Swift's New Album 'Lover' Chart On the Billboard Hot 100
column21: access-date=2020-02-22}}</ref> It was serviced to the US [[Hot adult contemporary
column23: pop]] radio formats on January 27 and 28, 2020 as the fourth single from ''Lover''.<ref>{{cite web
column31: title=Taylor Swift's New Single \"The Man\" Set To Impact Pop Radio On January 28
column36: access-date=January 29, 2020}}</ref> The single quickly became pop radio's most added song of the week dated January 27, 2020, picked up by 87 [[Mediabase]]-monitored pop stations.<ref>{{cite news
column38: title=Taylor Swift's \"The Man\" Ranks As Pop Radio's Most Added Song
column43: access-date=January 29, 2020}}</ref> It also topped the list of most added songs of the week by adult contemporary radio, picked up by 26 ''Hot AC'' Mediabase-monitored stations.<ref>{{cite news
column45: title=Taylor Swift's \"The Man\" Ranks As Hot AC Radio's Most Added Song
column50: access-date=February 4, 2020}}</ref> The song further peaked at number 21 and 12 on [[Mainstream Top 40
column52: ''Billboard'' Adult Pop Songs]] charts, respectively.<ref>{{Cite web
column54: title=Taylor Swift Scores Record-Extending 19th No. 1 on Digital Song Sales Chart With 'Only the Young'

column1: In Europe, \"The Man\" charted at number 16 in Ireland,<ref name=\"Ire\" /> 62 in Netherlands,<ref name=\"Net\" /> 24 in Norway,<ref name=\"Nor\" /> 82 in Scotland, 63 in Sweden and 80 in Switzerland.<ref name=\"Sco\" /><ref name=\"Swe\" /><ref name=\"Swi\" /> It reached number 21 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].<ref name=\"UK\" /> It was also commercially successful in Oceania, peaking at number 17 in Australia and 15 in New Zealand.<ref name=\"AUS\" /><ref name=\"NZ\" />

column4: American actor [[Dwayne Johnson]] voices Swift's male alter-ego in the music video.
column5: alt=Man smiling]]On February 25, 2020, Swift announced via her social media accounts that the music video will be released in two days' time.<ref>{{cite magazine
column7: title=Taylor Swift's 'The Man' Music Video Is Coming Really, Really Soon
column12: access-date=February 28, 2020}}</ref> The video was directed by Swift, making it her official solo directorial debut.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Every incredible Easter Egg in Taylor Swift's 'The Man' video
column19: accessdate=February 28, 2020}}</ref> Swift answered fan questions in the hour before the music video's premiere on YouTube on February 27, 2020. She stated that the entire preparation for the music video—including planning meetings, creating mood boards, scouting locations, and costume and set design—took several months. She also confirmed that there would be many of her trademark \"[[Easter egg (media)

column2: quote=With the \"The Man\" music video, I wanted to show a hightened reaction of how the world reacts to someone who's male, hot, rich, young and cocky. I wanted to show how there's immediate approval and benefit of the doubt given, in a ridiculous way.
column8: title=Taylor Swift - The Man (Behind The Scenes: Directing)

column1: The video features cameos from [[TikTok]] stars [[Loren Gray]] (the second most followed on the platform) and Dominic Toliver, actress Jayden Bartels, and Swift's father Scott Swift; actor [[Dwayne Johnson]] appears in a brief voice role.<ref>{{cite magazine
column3: title=All of the Easter Eggs in Taylor Swift's Video For 'The Man'
column9: accessdate=February 28, 2020}}</ref> The video's production team includes producer Jil Hardin, executive producer Rebecca Skinner, assistant director Joe Osborne, cinematographer [[Rodrigo Prieto]], production designer [[Ethan Tobman]], and makeup artist [[Bill Corso]]. Swift's transformation involved a \"muscle suit\", [[prosthetic makeup]], eyebrow wigs, and facial sculptures, which took between four and six hours to apply each day.<ref name=\"MakeupRS\">{{cite magazine
column11: title=Taylor Swift's Makeup Artist Reveals Transformation Behind 'The Man'
column16: accessdate=February 29, 2020}}</ref> She also worked with movement coaches Stephen Galloway and Spenser Theberge, as well as editor Chancler Haynes.<ref name=\"MakeupRS\"/> Visual effects were handled by Ingenuity Studios, which previously worked on several of Swift's videos such as \"[[Look What You Made Me Do]]\", \"[[End Game (song)
column17: End Game]]\", \"[[...Ready for It?]]\", and \"[[Lover (Taylor Swift song)

column2: satirical]] music video explores Swift's life as her theoretical male counterpart, an [[Alter ego
column3: alter-ego]] named \"Tyler Swift\". The video presents numerous prevalent examples of double standards in society, and comments on the [[Sexual objectification
column5: sexualization of women]], [[toxic masculinity]], [[patriarchy]], as well as performative allyship. Throughout the video, the male version of Swift is seen rudely inconveniencing the people around him, leading a luxurious and promiscuous lifestyle, [[manspreading]], receiving praise for the bare minimum, and throwing [[tantrum]]s without consequences. It contains visual references to ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)
column6: The Wolf of Wall Street]]'', a film involving the lyrically name-checked actor [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] and cinematographer Prieto, and tennis player [[Serena Williams]]' match controversy with a chair umpire at the [[2018 US Open (tennis)

column3: Swift's male alter-ego, Tyler Swift (in the middle), [[manspreading]] in a metro train.

column1: The video has several easter eggs alluding to Swift's other work, including ''[[Speak Now]]'', ''[[Red (Taylor Swift album)
column4: Reputation]]'' graffiti on a wall. ''[[Fearless (Taylor Swift album)
column5: Fearless]]'' is written backwards, while the title of her [[Taylor Swift (album)
column6: eponymous debut album]] appears in a sign saying \"Missing: If Found Return to Taylor Swift\". The \"missing\" sign, along with another wordless sign that appears to ban riding [[Scooter (motorcycle)
column7: scooters]], references her battle with [[Scooter Braun]] and [[Big Machine Records]] over the ownership of the master recordings of her first six studio albums. ''Lover'', the first album that Swift completely owns herself, is absent, but the word \"karma\" is written twice on the wall, a possible reference to Swift's plan to re-record her previous works thus lowering the value of the originals. The camera subsequently pans over a \"Mr. Americana\" poster for a film starring Tyler Swift, directed by Larry Wilson, and premiering at the 2020 Mandance Festival, a [[word play]] on Swift's [[Netflix]] documentary ''[[Miss Americana]]'' directed by [[Lana Wilson]], which debuted at the [[2020 Sundance Film Festival]]. Swift's alter-ego runs down a hallway giving high-fives to nineteen disembodied hands, alluding to double standards behind the [[walk of shame]] that women are often forced to take after a sexual encounter. The hands are said to be a reference to the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
column8: 19th amendment of the United States constitution]], which granted women the [[Women's suffrage in the United States
column9: right to vote]] in the country.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Taylor Swift Just Unveiled Her Self-Directed Music Video For \"The Man\" And It's Full Of Hidden Details

column1: In the final scene, Swift herself appears as the video's director to instruct her male alter-ego to be both \"sexier\" and \"more likeable\" in the next take—a subtle dig at the entertainment industry's blatant objectification of and sexist treatment toward women. Ending on messages of female empowerment, Swift then turns to praise Loren Gray for her acting performance as a tennis [[ball boy
column2: ball girl]], despite her role consisting of nothing more than an [[eye-rolling
column3: eye roll]]. The end credits list Swift as the director, writer, owner and star of the music video, Johnson as the voice of \"The Man\", and shows photos of Swift's transformation process into the male lead of the video. It ends with a [[disclaimer]] stating \"No men were harmed in the making of this video\".<ref name=\":2\" /><ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column5: title=Taylor Swift Is an Independent Woman Who Didn't Need a Man for 'The Man' Video

column2: masculine appearance]] as \"Tyler Swift\" has been compared with that of [[Christian Bale]], [[Harry Styles]], [[Jake Gyllenhaal
column3: Jake Gyllenhal]] and [[Joe Alwyn]].<ref name=\":4\" /><ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web
column5: title=Taylor Swift’s video for ‘The Man’ showcases her creativity—and features several shady Easter eggs

column1: The video received critical acclaim upon release, with many commentators complimenting the video's concept and Swift's \"unrecognizable\" transformation into the male alter-ego.
Bryan Rolli of ''[[Forbes]]'', highlighted that the video is characterized by an \"exaggerated and [[cartoon]]ish\" attitude \"in a [[Self-awareness
column2: self-aware]] way\", typical of Swift's \"most memorable videos\". He further expanded that \"obviously, not every man acts like her [Swift's] character; that's not the point. The point is to make a caricature of the buffoonish men who feel the need to criticize successful women like Swift for merely existing and dissect every public decision they make, whereas their male counterparts would receive praise for the same actions\".<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Taylor Swift's 'The Man' Is The Single (And Video) 'Lover' Deserved
column10: access-date=February 29, 2020}}</ref> Avery Blank, also writing for ''Forbes'', opined that the video is a \"reminder that women continue to face challenges when it comes to owning their ideas and maintaining control over their own careers\" and that the society \"expects women to be team players and not worry about getting credit for their work\". She further added that the video makes it clear to viewers that Swift \"will not let people mess with her\".<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Taylor Swift Shows How Women Can Take Ownership Of Their Work
column19: Glamour]]''<nowiki/>'s Chloe Laws wrote that the \"empowering\" video \"calls out [[sexism]] and the industry's double standards\", which is \"a small part of the bigger journey she's [Swift is] embarked on lately\", by \"refusing to let someone else control her narrative\".<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column21: title=Taylor Swift's 'The Man' calls out sexism and the industry's double standards and it's the empowering video we need RN
column27: Vox]]''{{'s}} Constance Grady opined that Swift is \"one of our great pop storytellers\", proved by the video that becomes \"the climax of her quest to own her voice\".<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column29: title=Taylor Swift's \"The Man\" video is the climax of her quest to own her voice

column13: Vulture]]''<nowiki/>'s Zoey Haylock commented that Swift as a man resembles [[Harry Styles]], [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] and [[Joe Alwyn]] combined, appreciating the [[Cosmetics

column26: title=Taylor Swift Transforms Into 'The Man' in New Music Video
column32: access-date=February 28, 2020}}</ref> ''[[iHeartRadio]]''{{'s}} Paris Close commended that the video \"does well to demonstrate how the hubris of [[male privilege]] plays out in the real world\".<ref>{{Cite web

column40: access-date=February 28, 2020}}</ref> [[CNN]]'s Lisa France opined that Swift is \"unrecognizable\" in the video, that \"brings to life Swift's lyrics about how differently the world views men and women\".<ref>{{Cite web
column42: title=Taylor Swift is literally 'The Man' in new music video
column47: access-date=February 29, 2020}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', Katie Shepherd and Allyson Chiu pointed out that the video is Swift's \"[[Gender bender
column48: gender-bending]] takedown of the [[patriarchy]]\", that \"skewer toxic masculinity and double standards, while airing personal grievances with an industry that has often subjected her to intense scrutiny\". They added that Swift takes aim at \"the cultural norms that allow, and at times even encourage, men to develop overinflated egos\".<ref>{{Cite web
column50: title=What Taylor Swift wants you to see in 'The Man,' her gender-bending takedown of the patriarchy
column60: ''Fast Company'']]'s Starr Rocque stated that Swift \"examines the ridiculousness of [[gender role]]s and weaves that into a [[Satire
column61: satirical]] spin on her own personal experiences and observations\", adding that Swift \"catches a lot of flack, but she's a fighter and always true to her brand of [[Women's empowerment

column2: animated]] lyric video for the song was released on February 7, 2020, exploring visual themes of women empowerment, feminism and [[occupational sexism

column4: [[Penrose stairs]] are incorporated into the lyric video to portray the never-ending difficulties faced by women in the corporate world.
column5: alt=A staircase in a square format. The stairs make four 90-degree turns in each corner, so they are in the format of a continuous loop.]]

column2: power suit]]-wearing woman, the only female figure in a maze-like city full of taller and larger [[corporatism
column3: corporate]] male drones, as she tries to navigate through [[Penrose stairs
column4: staircases that lead to nowhere]]. She is forced to run past the sauntering men to avoid getting trampled. When the woman finally reaches the top of a building, symbolizing her climb up the corporate ladder, the male drones push her off and leave her to freefall to death; thankfully, she is caught by another, benevolent, giant woman and shown to a place where all the women walk together in solidarity towards the city. The ending of the video implies that the true key to success for women is to lift each other up.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In honor of [[International Women's Day]] in 2020, \"The Man\" was added to playlists on streaming platforms such as [[Apple Music]], [[Spotify]] and [[Tidal (service)

column1: In March 2020, British politician [[Liz Truss]], the [[Secretary of State for International Trade]] and [[Minister for Women and Equalities]] of the United Kingdom, quoted the song's lyrics during a special International Women's Day debate in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom
column2: British parliament]], while talking about the need for [[gender equality]] across the workforce and greater protection for women against [[domestic violence]]. Truss stated: \"And so that, in the words of the brilliant Taylor Swift in her new song, 'women are left running as fast as they can, wondering if they'd get there quicker if they were a man'.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A British politician quoted Taylor Swift's 'The Man' during an International Women's Day debate in Parliament

column1: American journalist [[Jody Rosen]], writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', listed \"The Man\" as one of the \"25 songs that matter now\". Describing Swift as \"pop's best humblebraggart\", Rosen termed \"The Man\" as a \"sly protest song\", explaining that Swift \"has been pop's top bellyacher, turning a now-familiar set of grievances into great songs\". He added that Swift \"channels that indignation into a broader protest against the sexism and skepticism that all women face\". Rosen also opined that the song's \"most hard-hitting line is a plaintive rhetorical question that calls to mind a [[Me Too movement
column12: issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Naming \"The Man\" as the \"most important\" song Swift has ever written, Brittany Hodak of ''[[Forbes]]'', commended that \"the magic of \"The Man\" is not just that it captures a complex (and often misunderstood) issue so brilliantly and simply, but also that it conveys to Swift's female fans that even she isn't above the BS that so many of us are regularly subjected to\". Hodak concluded that she is \"hopeful that Swift’s spotlight on the issue will spark a national conversation about [[sexism]], [[Power (social and political)
column15: title=Why 'Lover' Track 'The Man' Is The Most Important Song Taylor Swift Has Ever Written

column1: \"'''The Man'''\" is a song by American singer-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]]. The song was serviced to US [[Hot adult contemporary
column3: pop]] radio formats on January 27 and 28, 2020 as the fourth single from Swift's seventh studio album, ''[[Lover (album)
column4: Lover]]'' (2019)''.'' Swift wrote and produced the song with [[Joel Little]]. It is a [[synth-pop]] song which features flashy harmonies and murky synths. Over an uptempo production, Swift imagines the media's treatment of her if she were a man. The song received acclaim from critics, who praised its [[feminism

column1: \"The Man\" peaked at number 23 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100
column2: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]], becoming the fourth consecutive single from ''Lover'' to peak inside the top 40 of the chart. It also debuted at number 4 on the [[Rolling Stone Top 100
column3: ''Rolling Stone'' Top 100]]. It entered the top 40 on charts in Australia, Belgium, Canada, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Ireland, Malaysia, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, Slovakia and the United Kingdom. On February 7, 2020, an animated lyric video of the song was released on [[YouTube]]. On February 18, 2020, a live acoustic version of the song, titled \"The Man (Live from Paris)\", was released on all music platforms, accompanied by its live video.

column1: An official music video for \"The Man\" was released on February 27, 2020 and was directed by Swift herself, marking her solo directorial debut. The [[Satire
column2: satirical]] video sees Swift in her theoretical male alter-ego named \"Tyler Swift\", presenting several prevalent examples of [[Sexism
column3: sexist]] double standards in society, including [[Sexual objectification

column4: American actor [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] is name-checked in the lyrics of the song, whose films, ''[[Inception]]'' and ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)
column5: The Wolf of Wall Street]]'', are further referenced in its lyric video and music video, respectively.
column6: alt=Leonardo DiCaprio attending a film premiere]]The recording process for [[Taylor Swift]]'s seventh studio album ''[[Lover (album)
column7: Lover]]'' took under three months, and concluded in February 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=New Reputation: Taylor Swift shares intel on TS7, fan theories, and her next era
column14: date=May 9, 2019}}</ref> [[Joel Little]] was revealed as one of the producers for the album with the release of lead single \"[[Me!]]\" in April. He co-wrote and co-produced four of the eighteen tracks for the album.<ref name=\"notes\">{{cite AV media notes
column22: id=B003061202}}</ref> The song title was revealed along with the lyrics \"I'd be a fearless leader / I'd be an alpha type / When everyone believes ya— / What's that like?\" in Swift's ''[[Vogue (magazine)
column23: Vogue]]'' cover interview for the September 2019 issue.<ref name=\"Vogue\">{{cite magazine
column25: title=Taylor Swift on Sexism, Scrutiny, and Standing Up for Herself

column1: \"The Man\" is a [[synth-pop]] song which features flashy harmonies and murky synths. Over an uptempo production, Swift imagines the media's treatment of her if she were a man. She challenges societal sexist double standards, with lyrics including a noteworthy reference to American actor [[Leonardo DiCaprio]].<ref name=\"indep\">{{cite web
column4: title=Taylor Swift, Lover review: The sound of an artist excited to be earnest again
column8: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Swift uses the actor as an example to explain sexism, singing \"And they would toast to me, oh, let the players play/I'd be just like Leo in [[Saint-Tropez]]\".<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Taylor Swift Uses Leonardo DiCaprio As an Example to Explain Sexism in 'The Man'
column16: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> In outtakes from an interview with ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column17: Billboard]]'' in December 2019, Swift said she wrote the song not only from personal experience, but also from hearing the general experiences of women working across all parts of the music industry.<ref>{{cite magazine
column19: title=Taylor Swift Discusses 'The Man' & 'It's Nice To Have a Friend' In Cover Story Outtakes

column2: We [women] have to curate and cater everything, but we have to make it look like an accident. Because if we make a mistake, that's our fault, but if we strategize so that we won't make a mistake, we're calculating. There is a bit of a damned-if-we-do, damned-if-we-don't thing happening in music.}}

column1: According to ''Billboard''{{'s}} Gil Kaufman, \"The Man\" is a pointed statement about \"how much harder women need to work than men to get to the same finish line\".<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Drake, Idris Elba, Leo DiCaprio & More: All Of the Celeb Moments On Taylor Swift's 'Lover'
column9: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Jason Lipshutz of the same magazine described the song as a \"biting look at gender dynamics within both the pop industry and celebrity-driven culture\", noting that it is sonically composed of a rumbling beat and crackling synths and lyrically provides wry humor and an honest perspective.<ref name=\"BBLipshutz\">{{cite web
column12: title=Every Song Ranked on Taylor Swift's 'Lover': Critic's Picks
column16: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> An animated lyric video for \"The Man\" was released on February 7, 2020 at 12pm.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Taylor Swift's 'The Man' Lyric Video Is on the Way

column1: \"The Man\" received critical acclaim upon release, with praise towards its lyrics about [[sexism]] and [[women empowerment]].

''[[The Atlantic]]''{{'}}s Spencer Kornhaber described \"The Man\" as \"one of the most straightforwardly catchy songs\" on ''Lover'', and further called it Swift's \"most explicit musical statement on sexism\".<ref name=\"atlantic\">{{cite web
column4: title=Why Taylor Swift Wants to Be 'The Man'
column8: date=August 29, 2019}}</ref> He opined that the [[Leonardo DiCaprio
column9: DiCaprio]] reference is the \"most memorable\" line of the song. Brittany Hodak of ''[[Forbes]]'', praised the song as \"the most important song she's [Swift has] ever written\". She also stated that the song is \"a brilliant portrayal of the subtle and not-so-subtle sexism women face every day\".<ref>{{cite magazine
column11: title=Why 'Lover' Track 'The Man' Is The Most Important Song Taylor Swift Has Ever Written
column17: Time]]''{{'}}s Raisa Bruner labelled the song as \"a bombastic, empowering bop\" that is \"an anthem for anyone who's felt blocked by sexist double standards\".<ref>{{cite magazine
column19: title=Let's Discuss the Lyrics to Every Song on Taylor Swift's Lover
column25: accessdate=November 21, 2019}}</ref> Comparing the song to Swift's 2017 album, [[Rob Sheffield]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described \"The Man\" as \"a righteous feminist bombshell ''[[Reputation (Taylor Swift album)
column28: title=Why 'Lover' Is the Ultimate Taylor Swift Album
column34: Slate]]''{{'}}s Carl Wilson opined that the song \"widens the lens and makes a more convincing case for her [Swift's] grievances than on any beefing track she's ever written\". He further described the song as a \"synth-strut mode very reminiscent of [[Haim (band)
column35: Haim]]\" that \"takes aim at sexist music industry and media double standards and just keeps firing bull's-eyes\".<ref>{{cite magazine
column37: title=Taylor Swift's Lover Is a More Mature (Mostly) Successor to Red

column6: title=Taylor Swift's \"The Man\" Lyrics Are Pure, Perfect Girl Power
column10: date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> Allie Gemmill of ''[[Teen Vogue]]'' stated that the song \"gives women permission to keep challenging sexist double standards, and fans are here for it\", adding that the \"fierce\" song includes \"many incredibly good lyrics\".<ref>{{cite web

column20: title=What Should Taylor Swift's Next 'Lover' Single Be? Vote!

column5: alt=Man smiling]]On February 25, 2020, Swift announced via her social media accounts that the music video will be released in two days' time.<ref>{{cite magazine

column14: title=Every incredible Easter Egg in Taylor Swift's 'The Man' video
column19: accessdate=February 28, 2020}}</ref> Swift answered fan questions in the hour before the music video's premiere on YouTube on February 27, 2020. She stated that the entire preparation for the music video—including planning meetings, creating mood boards, scouting locations, and costume and set design—took several months. She also confirmed that there would be many of her trademark \"[[Easter egg (media)

column2: quote=With the \"The Man\" music video, I wanted to show a hightened reaction of how the world reacts to someone who's male, hot, rich, young and cocky. I wanted to show how there's immediate approval and benefit of the doubt given, in a ridiculous way.
column8: title=Taylor Swift - The Man (Behind The Scenes: Directing)

column1: The video features cameos from [[TikTok]] stars [[Loren Gray]] (the second most followed on the platform) and Dominic Toliver, actress Jayden Bartels, and Swift's father Scott Swift; actor [[Dwayne Johnson]] appears in a brief voice role.<ref>{{cite magazine
column3: title=All of the Easter Eggs in Taylor Swift's Video For 'The Man'
column9: accessdate=February 28, 2020}}</ref> The video's production team includes producer Jil Hardin, executive producer Rebecca Skinner, assistant director Joe Osborne, cinematographer [[Rodrigo Prieto]], production designer [[Ethan Tobman]], and makeup artist [[Bill Corso]]. Swift's transformation involved a \"muscle suit\", [[prosthetic makeup]], eyebrow wigs, and facial sculptures, which took between four and six hours to apply each day.<ref name=\"MakeupRS\">{{cite magazine
column11: title=Taylor Swift's Makeup Artist Reveals Transformation Behind 'The Man'
column16: accessdate=February 29, 2020}}</ref> She also worked with movement coaches Stephen Galloway and Spenser Theberge, as well as editor Chancler Haynes.<ref name=\"MakeupRS\"/> Visual effects were handled by Ingenuity Studios, which previously worked on several of Swift's videos such as \"[[Look What You Made Me Do]]\", \"[[End Game (song)
column17: End Game]]\", \"[[...Ready for It?]]\", and \"[[Lover (Taylor Swift song)

column2: satirical]] music video explores Swift's life as her theoretical male counterpart, an [[Alter ego
column3: alter-ego]] named \"Tyler Swift\". The video presents numerous prevalent examples of double standards in society, and comments on the [[Sexual objectification
column5: sexualization of women]], [[toxic masculinity]], [[patriarchy]], as well as performative allyship. Throughout the video, the male version of Swift is seen rudely inconveniencing the people around him, leading a luxurious and promiscuous lifestyle, [[manspreading]], receiving praise for the bare minimum, and throwing [[tantrum]]s without consequences. It contains visual references to ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)
column6: The Wolf of Wall Street]]'', a film involving the lyrically name-checked actor [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] and cinematographer Prieto, and tennis player [[Serena Williams]]' match controversy with a chair umpire at the [[2018 US Open (tennis)

column3: Swift's male alter-ego, Tyler Swift (in the middle), [[manspreading]] in a metro train.

column1: The video has several easter eggs alluding to Swift's other work, including ''[[Speak Now]]'', ''[[Red (Taylor Swift album)
column4: Reputation]]'' graffiti on a wall. ''[[Fearless (Taylor Swift album)
column5: Fearless]]'' is written backwards, while the title of her [[Taylor Swift (album)
column6: eponymous debut album]] appears in a sign saying \"Missing: If Found Return to Taylor Swift\". The \"missing\" sign, along with another wordless sign that appears to ban riding [[Scooter (motorcycle)
column7: scooters]], references her battle with [[Scooter Braun]] and [[Big Machine Records]] over the ownership of the master recordings of her first six studio albums. ''Lover'', the first album that Swift completely owns herself, is absent, but the word \"karma\" is written twice on the wall, a possible reference to Swift's plan to re-record her previous works thus lowering the value of the originals. The camera subsequently pans over a \"Mr. Americana\" poster for a film starring Tyler Swift, directed by Larry Wilson, and premiering at the 2020 Mandance Festival, a [[word play]] on Swift's [[Netflix]] documentary ''[[Miss Americana]]'' directed by [[Lana Wilson]], which debuted at the [[2020 Sundance Film Festival]]. Swift's alter-ego runs down a hallway giving high-fives to nineteen disembodied hands, alluding to double standards behind the [[walk of shame]] that women are often forced to take after a sexual encounter. The hands are said to be a reference to the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
column8: 19th amendment of the United States constitution]], which granted women the [[Women's suffrage in the United States
column9: right to vote]] in the country.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Taylor Swift Just Unveiled Her Self-Directed Music Video For \"The Man\" And It's Full Of Hidden Details

column1: In the final scene, Swift herself appears as the video's director to instruct her male alter-ego to be both \"sexier\" and \"more likeable\" in the next take—a subtle dig at the entertainment industry's blatant objectification of and sexist treatment toward women. Ending on messages of female empowerment, Swift then turns to praise Loren Gray for her acting performance as a tennis [[ball boy
column2: ball girl]], despite her role consisting of nothing more than an [[eye-rolling
column3: eye roll]]. The end credits list Swift as the director, writer, owner and star of the music video, Johnson as the voice of \"The Man\", and shows photos of Swift's transformation process into the male lead of the video. It ends with a [[disclaimer]] stating \"No men were harmed in the making of this video\".<ref name=\":2\" /><ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column5: title=Taylor Swift Is an Independent Woman Who Didn't Need a Man for 'The Man' Video

column2: masculine appearance]] as \"Tyler Swift\" has been compared with that of [[Christian Bale]], [[Harry Styles]], [[Jake Gyllenhaal
column3: Jake Gyllenhal]] and [[Joe Alwyn]].<ref name=\":4\" /><ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web
column5: title=Taylor Swift’s video for ‘The Man’ showcases her creativity—and features several shady Easter eggs

column1: The video received critical acclaim upon release, with many commentators complimenting the video's concept and Swift's \"unrecognizable\" transformation into the male alter-ego.
Bryan Rolli of ''[[Forbes]]'', highlighted that the video is characterized by an \"exaggerated and [[cartoon]]ish\" attitude \"in a [[Self-awareness
column2: self-aware]] way\", typical of Swift's \"most memorable videos\". He further expanded that \"obviously, not every man acts like her [Swift's] character; that's not the point. The point is to make a caricature of the buffoonish men who feel the need to criticize successful women like Swift for merely existing and dissect every public decision they make, whereas their male counterparts would receive praise for the same actions\".<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Taylor Swift's 'The Man' Is The Single (And Video) 'Lover' Deserved
column10: access-date=February 29, 2020}}</ref> Avery Blank, also writing for ''Forbes'', opined that the video is a \"reminder that women continue to face challenges when it comes to owning their ideas and maintaining control over their own careers\" and that the society \"expects women to be team players and not worry about getting credit for their work\". She further added that the video makes it clear to viewers that Swift \"will not let people mess with her\".<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Taylor Swift Shows How Women Can Take Ownership Of Their Work
column19: Glamour]]''<nowiki/>'s Chloe Laws wrote that the \"empowering\" video \"calls out [[sexism]] and the industry's double standards\", which is \"a small part of the bigger journey she's [Swift is] embarked on lately\", by \"refusing to let someone else control her narrative\".<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web

They added that Swift takes aim at \"the cultural norms that allow, and at times even encourage, men to develop overinflated egos\".<ref>{{Cite web

column2: animated]] lyric video for the song was released on February 7, 2020, exploring visual themes of women empowerment, feminism and [[occupational sexism

column4: [[Penrose stairs]] are incorporated into the lyric video to portray the never-ending difficulties faced by women in the corporate world.
column5: alt=A staircase in a square format. The stairs make four 90-degree turns in each corner, so they are in the format of a continuous loop.]]

column2: power suit]]-wearing woman, the only female figure in a maze-like city full of taller and larger [[corporatism
column3: corporate]] male drones, as she tries to navigate through [[Penrose stairs
column4: staircases that lead to nowhere]]. She is forced to run past the sauntering men to avoid getting trampled. When the woman finally reaches the top of a building, symbolizing her climb up the corporate ladder, the male drones push her off and leave her to freefall to death; thankfully, she is caught by another, benevolent, giant woman and shown to a place where all the women walk together in solidarity towards the city. The ending of the video implies that the true key to success for women is to lift each other up.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In honor of [[International Women's Day]] in 2020, \"The Man\" was added to playlists on streaming platforms such as [[Apple Music]], [[Spotify]] and [[Tidal (service)
column2: Tidal]]. Public figures such as [[Malala Yousafzai]] and [[Kristin Chenoweth]] added the song to their International Women's Day playlists.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Starbucks' International Women's Day Celebrations Include A Spotify Playlist From Malala Yousafzai
column10: access-date=March 16, 2020}}</ref> Furthermore, Swift included the song in her Apple Music \"Playlist by ME!\", which was updated to spotlight songs from rising female artists such as [[Beabadoobee]], [[Clairo]], [[Phoebe Bridgers]], [[Caroline Polachek]], [[Celeste (singer)
column17: MUNA]], [[Oh Wonder]], [[Brittany Howard]], [[Margaret Glaspy]], [[Princess Nokia]], [[Selena Gomez]], [[Låpsley]], [[Yebba]] etc.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=Taylor Swift's International Women's Day Playlist: Listen

column1: In March 2020, British politician [[Liz Truss]], the [[Secretary of State for International Trade]] and [[Minister for Women and Equalities]] of the United Kingdom, quoted the song's lyrics during a special International Women's Day debate in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom
column2: British parliament]], while talking about the need for [[gender equality]] across the workforce and greater protection for women against [[domestic violence]]. Truss stated: \"And so that, in the words of the brilliant Taylor Swift in her new song, 'women are left running as fast as they can, wondering if they'd get there quicker if they were a man'.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A British politician quoted Taylor Swift's 'The Man' during an International Women's Day debate in Parliament

column1: American journalist [[Jody Rosen]], writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', listed \"The Man\" as one of the \"25 songs that matter now\". Describing Swift as \"pop's best humblebraggart\", Rosen termed \"The Man\" as a \"sly protest song\", explaining that Swift \"has been pop's top bellyacher, turning a now-familiar set of grievances into great songs\". He added that Swift \"channels that indignation into a broader protest against the sexism and skepticism that all women face\". Rosen also opined that the song's \"most hard-hitting line is a plaintive rhetorical question that calls to mind a [[Me Too movement
column12: issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Naming \"The Man\" as the \"most important\" song Swift has ever written, Brittany Hodak of ''[[Forbes]]'', commended that \"the magic of \"The Man\" is not just that it captures a complex (and often misunderstood) issue so brilliantly and simply, but also that it conveys to Swift's female fans that even she isn't above the BS that so many of us are regularly subjected to\". Hodak concluded that she is \"hopeful that Swift’s spotlight on the issue will spark a national conversation about [[sexism]], [[Power (social and political)
column15: title=Why 'Lover' Track 'The Man' Is The Most Important Song Taylor Swift Has Ever Written

column1: →‎'Schizoid Factors in the Personality' (1940):I added to the description of Fairbairn's structural model in the section previously described a \Splitting of the Ego\" and re titled it \"Endopsychic Structure Considered in terms Of Object-Relationships, his 1944 paper",safe,David Celani,"{{EngvarB

column7: n}}) [[FRSE]] (11 August 1889 – 31 December 1964) was a Scottish psychiatrist, psychoanalyst and a central figure in the development of the [[object relations theory]] of psychoanalysis.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book
column10: title=The Illusion Of Love: Why The Battered Woman Returns To Her Abuser

column3: Fairbairn's birthplace - The Red House, Cluny Gardens]]

column1: Ronald Fairbairn was born at the Red House, Cluny Gardens,<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1889-90</ref> in [[Morningside, Edinburgh]] in 1889, the only child of Cecilia Leefe and Thomas Fairbairn, a chartered surveyor, and President of the Edinburgh Architectural Association.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite ODNB
column3: title=Fairbairn, (William) Ronald Dodds (1889–1964), psychiatrist and psychoanalyst
column12: title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002
column16: url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref> He was educated at [[Merchiston Castle School]] and at the [[University of Edinburgh]] where he studied for three years in [[divinity]] and [[Hellenic Greek]] studies, graduating MA in 1911.

column1: In the [[First World War]] he joined the [[Royal Engineers]] and served under [[Edmund Allenby, 1st Viscount Allenby
column2: General Allenby]] in the [[Sinai and Palestine Campaign
column3: Palestinian campaign]], and then the [[Royal Garrison Artillery]].

column1: On his return to home he began medical training, probably inspired by his war experience. He received a doctorate in Medicine (MD) on 30 March 1929 from the [[University of Edinburgh]].<ref name=\"Archive\">Available at the [https://www.era.lib.ed.ac.uk/handle/1842/9999 Edinburgh Research Archive].</ref> From 1927 to 1935 he lectured in psychology at the University and also independently practised analysis. From 1941 until 1954 he was Consultant Psychiatrist to the [[Ministry of Pensions]].<ref name=\":1\" />
In 1931 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[James Drever]], [[Edwin Bramwell]], Sir Godfrey Hilton Thomson and [[Robert Alexander Fleming]].

On the basis of his writings he became an associate member of the British Psychoanalytical Society in 1931, becoming a full member in 1939. Fairbairn, though somewhat isolated in that he spent his entire career in Edinburgh,<ref>{{cite book
column9: page=132}}</ref> had a profound influence on British Object Relations and the relational schools. Fairbairn was one of the theory-builders for the [[British Independent Group (psychoanalysis)
column18: page=21}}</ref> (now called the Independent Group) psychoanalysts. The Independent Group contained analysts who identified with neither the [[Melanie Klein
column19: Klein]]ians nor the [[Anna Freud]]ians. They were more concerned with the relationships between people than with the \"drives\" within them.

column1: He died in Edinburgh at the age of 75. He is buried with his wives in [[Dean Cemetery]] in western [[Edinburgh]]. The grave lies very close to the main east entrance and lodge-house.

column4: Ronald Fairbairn's grave, Dean Cemetery, Edinburgh]]

column1: In 1926 Fairbairn married Mary Ann More Gordon (1901–1952) the daughter of Harry More Gordon. Their daughter Ellinor was born in 1927, followed by twins in 1928, however they did not survive. Their fourth child was born in 1929, and in 1933 their fifth son [[Nicholas Fairbairn
column2: Nicholas]] was born, who would go on to become a barrister and MP.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: In 1959 he married Marion Frances Mackintosh (1907–1995), daughter of Captain H. E. M. Archer.<ref name=\":0\" />

Fairbairn's works include: ''Psychoanalytic Studies of the Personality'' (1952)<ref name=\":2\" /> and ''From Instinct to Self: Selected Papers of W. R. D. Fairbairn'' (1994). There is also a biography by  [[John Derg Sutherland]], ''Fairbairn’s Journey into the Interior'' (1989)<ref>{{Cite book
column9: pages=}}</ref>, a study of his work by James Grotstein and R. B. Rinsley, ''Fairbairn and the Origins of Object Relations'' (1994)<ref>{{Cite book
column12: title=Fairbairn and The Origins of Object Relations
column17: pages=}}</ref>, an edited study by Neil J. Skolnik and David E. Scharff, ''Fairbairn Then and Now'' (1998)<ref>{{Cite book
column25: pages=}}</ref>, a text by David Celani which is an application of Fairbairn's model  to domestic violence, ''The Illusion of Love:Why The Battered Woman Returns to Her Abuser'' (1994)<ref name=\":3\" /> , and a second text by Celani on the application of  Fairbairn's model to the treatment of severe personality disorders,  ''Fairbairn's Object Relations Theory in the Clinical Setting'', (2010)<ref name=\":4\" />.

column1: The importance of Fairbain's work lies in its direct challenge to Freud's model of psychoanalysis. ''Psychoanalytic Studies of Personality'', a 1952 collection of Fairbairn's papers previously published in various psychoanalytic journals, includes four papers that contain most of his innovative concepts.

Fairbairn's model is  classified as psychoanalytic model or theory because it shares the common assumption of all psychoanalytic models—the belief that the fundamental source of human motivation originates in the unconscious—as well as offering explanations of the origins and dynamics of transference, repetition compulsions, and resistance. His enormously ambitious goal was to replace Freudian [[metapsychology]] with his own. Fairbairn's vision of the human psyche was not based on the Freudian notion that the infant is overflowing with primitive drives needing to be tamed, but rather that the infant is seeking love and emotional attachment that can infuse him with the security he needs to explore the world, safe in the knowledge that he has parents ready to help him if he becomes overwhelmed in that exploration. Fairbairn's model offers a different theory of psychological development, a completely new vision of the structure and dynamics of the personality, a different source of the origins of psychopathology, and a different approach to the treatment of disordered individuals. Fairbairn's model also shifts the focus away from repression (of the Id's forbidden desires) and back to dissociation as humans' fundamental defense mechanism.
Greenberg and Mitchell noted the basic changes promoted by Fairbairn.

In a series of dense and fertile papers written during the early 1940's, W.R.D. Fairbairn developed a theoretical perspective which, along with Sullivan's \"interpersonal psychiatry\", provides the purest and clearest expression of the shift from the drive/structure model to the relational/structure model (Greenberg and Mitchell, 1983:151).<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite book

The psychoanalytic model Freud offers is a '''drive/structure model''': it proposes that human beings are born with innate, biological drives (e.g., sexual desire and aggression) contained in the unconscious Id. The infant's Id seeks discharge of its tensions regardless of the situation. When the discharging drive (hitting, biting, urinating, defecating) comes into contact with the demands and prohibitions of society, there is immediate conflict. A new structure must emerge from the Id of the growing infant to insure that its drives are expressed in a socially acceptable way. Thus the unconscious Id—Freud's metaphor for the whole range and strength of biological drives—is forced to develop contact with reality through the emergence of a second structure: the Ego. Thus the Ego has the task of mediating between the primitive Id and society. Later on in development (via the Oedipal Conflict), the child internalizes the values of his parents. These internalized values become the third internal structure, which is called the Super Ego. These three hypothetical ego structures—Id, Ego, and Super Ego—mature and grow with experience. Freud postulated that all psychological development is based on the Id seeking satisfaction, the Ego curbing the Id's most extreme demands, and the Super Ego pressing the Ego to make morally correct choices.

In contrast, Fairbairn's is a '''relational/structure model''' in its assumption that the human psyche develops its structure from actual human experience, not from pressure from the Id, whose existence Fairbairn rejects. Instead, Fairbairn proposes that the human psyche develops structures based on actual interpersonal events. A child's growing and maturing internal ego structures can be understood as packages of memories that coalesce and form internal representations of the parents, of the child himself, and of the child's relationship to his parents. For Fairburn, the unconscious develops as a consequence of empathic failures of the parents that are too disruptive for the child's underdeveloped central ego to tolerate. Awareness of these failures would interfere with the child's absolute dependency on his parents, and knowledge of them would destroy the necessary illusion that he is loved and cherished. In families where punishment is frequent and severe, parental failures can be catastrophic to the child's developing sense of self. That is, the child can be so overwhelmed by parental aggression that it faces the loss of its sense of self, as described by Bromberg:     <blockquote>

Psychological trauma occurs in situations, explicitly or implicitly interpersonal, in which self-invalidation (sometimes self-annihilation) cannot be escaped from or prevented, and from which there is no hope of protection, relief, or soothing.
