column2: ground = Ardeer Reserve (The Ghetto)<ref name=\"foxsportspulse1\">[http://www.foxsportspulse.com/comp_info.cgi?action=VENUE&venueid=22084368&client=1-8746-124172-298145-16773983 Venue for Round 0 – FOX SPORTS PULSE] {{webarchive

column3: date=10 March 2014 }}</ref> also referred to as '''Westgate Sindjelic''', is a semi-professional [[Serbia]]n-founded [[Australia]]n [[association football]] club located in [[Ardeer, Victoria
column4: Ardeer]], [[Melbourne]], that plays in the [[Victorian State League Division 2]], Australia's joint fifth tier in the country's [[Australian soccer league system

column1: The club was founded on 18 February 1985 as Royal Richmond, with its home ground based at Burnley Oval in the suburb of [[Richmond, Victoria
column2: Richmond]]. In 1986, the club changed its home venue to Yarraville Oval and officially converted the club named to Westgate FC by 1987. The club won its first trophy in 1987 after winning the Victorian State League Division 2.<ref name=\"ozfootball1\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1987VD2T.html 1987 Victorian League Division Two – Final Table] {{webarchive
column4: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Westgate FC have twice been crowned champions of the [[Football Federation Victoria
column5: Victorian State League Cup]] and have won the [[Karadjordje Cup]] a record five times.

column1: Upon the club's foundation, they would compete in the [[Victorian State League Division 2]] under the name Royal Richmond. Their home matches were played at Burnley Oval in the suburb of Richmond.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1985VD2R.html 1985 Victorian League Division Two – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> The club's first ever goal scorer in an official league match was Tony Marchett, who scored in the 50th minute of Royal Richmond's Round 1 fixture against Waverley City on 23 March.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> The club eventually went on to be defeated 2–1, having been winning 1–0.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> Marchett would score again in the next fixture, which was a 2–0 away victory against Keilor Austria on 30 March.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> Dragan Vasic would get his name on the score sheet for the next three fixtures, himself and Tony Marchett would play a major part in scoring for the club throughout the duration of the season.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> After a series of many defeats, including a 4–0 home victory against South Oakleigh on 8 June, the club gained an important 3 points when defeating Dandenong City 2–0 away on 15 June, with goals coming from Dragan Vasic and Jim Kondarios.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> In Round 15, Royal Richmond gained another crucial 3 points to avoid relegation when they defeated Keilor Austria 2–0 at home on 29 June.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> From this match onwards, Royal Richmond went on to avoid defeat for the next seven matches, with Dragan Vasic netting six times out of the six fixtures, including an important 3–2 home victory against Coburg on 21 September.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> Having been un beaten for a total of eight consecutive weeks, the club suffered a 3–0 home defeat against Eltham on 17 August.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> After draws with South Melbourne, Sandringham and South Oakleigh, a win was needed to avoid relegation in their last round.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> In Round 26, Royal Richmond defeated Dandenong City 3–2 at home on 14 September, with a double from Dragan Vasic.<ref name=\"ozfootball6\"/> The club finished their inaugural season 8th position with 22 points, 3 points from relegation, having won 8 matches, drawn 6 times and lost 12.<ref name=\"ozfootball7\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1985VD2T.html 1985 Buffalo Victorian League Division Two – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: In 1986, the club continued in the [[Victorian State League Division 2]], the 1986 season being the last one in which they participated under the club name 'Royal Richmond'. In the 1986 season, the club used Yarraville Oval as their venue for home matches. Royal Richmond drew their first two fixtures before defeating Keilor Park 4–0 at home in round 3 on 5 April, with Dragan Vasic with three goals in the three fixtures and Tony Marchett with two.<ref name=\"ozfootball8\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1986VD2R.html 1986 Victorian League Division Two – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Vasic went on a goal-scoring stint from Round 5 to Round 12, netting 14 goals in 8 consecutive matches.<ref name=\"ozfootball8\"/> In Round 17, Tony Marchett scored a hat-trick, becoming the first player to ever do so for the club, in a 4–0 home victory against Moreland Park Rangers on 12 July.<ref name=\"ozfootball8\"/> The club finished the last round of the season with a 1–0 away victory against Bulleen on 13 September, with a goal from Dragan Vasic.<ref name=\"ozfootball8\"/> The club finished in 5th position of the table with 30 points.<ref name=\"ozfootball9\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1986VD2T.html 1986 Victorian League Division Two – Final Table] {{webarchive
column5: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Vasic concluded the 1986 season with 22 as the leading goal scorer of the Victorian State League Division 2.

column1: Under the name 'Westgate FC', the club began the 1987 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] season with a 3–0 home victory against [[North Geelong Warriors]] on 28 March, Pedro Gasco (top player) scored a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1987VD2R.html 1987 Victorian League Division Two – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> In the following fixtures, Westgate were thrashed 5–1 away against Prahran City on 4 April, with Pedro Gasco again scoring.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> By Round 5, Westgate had obtained three consecutive wins with Pedro Gasco netting in each match, totalling to six goals in five matches.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> In Round 10, Westgate recorded their biggest ever win, a 7–1 home victory against Eltham on 30 May, Tony Marchett scored a double and Pedro Gasco also got his name on the score sheet.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> Two fixtures later, Westgate demolished Doveton 4–0 at home on 13 June, with two goals from Pedro Gasco.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> Gasco again scored another double in the following fixture, which saw Westgate defeat Morington 5–3 away on 20 June.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> After suffering two defeats throughout a handful of matches, Westgate continued their winning ways with a 5–1 home victory against [[Geelong Rangers
column4: Hamlyn Rangers]] on 18 July.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> In the following fixture, Westgate would snare off a challenge from Dandenong City in a 1–0 away victory on 25 July, the goal coming from former [[National Soccer League]] and [[Australia national association football team
column6: Joe Picioane]].<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> In Round 26, Westgate defeated Mornington 7–2 at home on 19 September, with Tony Marchett recording a total of 6 goals in the match.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> A Round 20 fixture against [[Altona City SC
column7: Altona City]] was re-scheduled to be played at the end of the season.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> Prior to the fixture, Westgate were standing in third position of the Victorian State League Division 2 table, needing just 1 point in order to gain promotion to the Victorian State League Division 1.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> A win would see them crowned champions of the entire league, topping both Mooroolbark and Sandringham City, who both sat equal on top with 37 points.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> The match was played at Altona City's home, as they took an early lead in the match.<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> Westgate eventually finished the game winning 3–1, ending the 1987 season in first place of the Victorian State League Division 2 with 38 points, 1 point ahead of joint second placed Mooroolbark and Sandringhan City and 3 points ahead of [[North Geelong Warriors]].<ref name=\"ozfootball10\"/> After just three years of experience in Victoria's stage leagues, Westgate FC gained promotion to the [[Victorian State League Division 1]] for the 1988 season, a league in which they would serve for the next 15 seasons.<ref name=\"ozfootball1\"/> Pedro Gasco netted a total of 18 league goals for the club and was the leading goal scorer of the entire league. [[Josip Picioane
column8: Joe Picioane]] was also awarded with the Best and Fairest award of the entire league.

column1: Westgate's season concluded in 7th position of the 1988 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] table with a total of 28 points.<ref name=\"ozfootball11\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1988VD1T.html 1988 Victorian League Division One – Final Table] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Westgate's 1988 season kicked off with a 1–0 away victory against Nunawading on 2 April, with Tony Marchett scoring.<ref name=\"ozfootball12\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1988VD1R.html 1988 Victorian League Division One – Season Results] {{webarchive
column5: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> The season would consist of regular wins and losses, before Westgate went on an undefeated streak from Round 11 to Round 14, notably beating Nunawading City 4–0 at home on 2 July, with Chris Andriotis scoring a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball12\"/> In Round 18, Westgate would thrash Richmond 6–0 at home on 30 July, with Tony Marchett scoring a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball12\"/> Westgate also claimed their first State League Cup title, after former [[South Melbourne FC
column6: South Melbourne]] striker Chris Andriotis netted in a 1–0 victory against Mooroolbark in the final.

column1: Westgate's 1989 season commenced with two straight losses and one draw. The club earned their first 3 points in Round 4 in a 1–0 home victory against Albion on 22 April, with [http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1989VD1R.html 1989 Victorian League Division One – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Number of draws and losses continued, including a 4–0 defeat away against Sandringham City on 27 May in Round 9.<ref name=\"ozfootball13\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1989VD1R.html 1989 Victorian League Division One – Season Results] {{webarchive
column5: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> In the following round, Westgate earned just their second league win of the season in a 1–0 home victory against Broadmeadows City on 3 June, with a goal from Milan Vlatokovic.<ref name=\"ozfootball13\"/> Vlatkovic again scored in the following fixture, a 1–0 away victory against Essendon on 10 June.<ref name=\"ozfootball13\"/> In Round 16, Westgate earned a crucial 3 points in a 2–1 home victory against Mooroolbark on 15 July.<ref name=\"ozfootball13\"/> As of Round 19, Westgate then went undefeated until Round 23, recording an important 5–0 away victory against Mordialloc on 20 August and conceding just one goal within the 4 rounds.<ref name=\"ozfootball13\"/> Westgate went on to lose their last two matches of the season and concluded the competition in 8th position, with 25 points, just 3 points from being relegated.<ref name=\"ozfootball14\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/1989VD1T.html Victorian League Division One – 1989] {{webarchive

column1: From 1988 to 2002 (15 seasons) they competed in Victorian State League Division 1. In 2002 Wesgate finished 10th, and had to go into a play-off to remain in the division. The club also made an appearance in the final of the Harry Armstrong (Reserves) Cup in 1993. The game was played as a curtain raiser to the [[Dockerty Cup]] final between Heidelberg United and South Melbourne at Olympic Park.

The 2000 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] season saw Westgate defeated 5–3 away to Westvale in Round 1, before defeating [[Springvale White Eagles]] 1–0 at home in Round 2.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2000D1R.html 2000 Victorian Division One – 2000 Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Westgate went on to suffer 8 consecutive defeats, including a 4–0 home defeat against [[Frankston Pines]] in Round 8 and a 5–0 away defeat against Essendon in Round 10.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> They ended their losing streak with a 4–3 home victory against Doncaster Rovers in Round 11, and the following week, Darryl Spiteri netted a hat-trick at home in a 3–1 victory against Westvale in Round 12.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> In the following fixture, Tony Lingurovski netted a double and Darryl Spiteri also found his name on the scoresheet as Westgate defeated [[Springvale White Eagles]] 3–1 away in Round 13.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> Westgate continued their winning ways when Darryl Spiteri again scored in a 1–0 home victory against Richmond in the following fixture in Round 14.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> The goal was Spiteri's 5th in three consecutive games and Westgate had gone four weeks without losing.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> They then suffered two losses and two draws before being defeated 4–2 away against [[Frankston Pines]] in Round 19.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> Westgate went on to lose the next two matches, the second being a 7–0 thrashing at home against Essendon in Round 21, one of the biggest defeats in Westgate's history.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> Westgate won their last match of the season, a 4–1 away victory against Doncaster Rovers in Round 22, with a hat-trick from Darryl Spiteri and a goal from Robert Georgieski, the win was sufficient enough to avoid relegation.<ref name=\"ozfootball15\"/> Westgate finished the season towards the bottom half of the table, just 3 points from relegation.<ref name=\"ozfootball16\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2000D1T.html Victorian State League Division One Table – 2000] {{webarchive
column5: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Darryl Spiteri had also concluded the season with 12 goals, finishing as the league's 5th leading goal scorer.<ref name=\"ozfootball17\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2000Score.html VicScorers 2000] {{webarchive

column1: The 2001 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] began with a 4–2 home defeat against Westvale. Another two losses would follow until Round 4, when Westgate defeated [[Springvale White Eagles]] 5–0 away, with Tony Lingurovski scoring a hat-trick.<ref name=\"ozfootball18\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2001D1R.html 2001 Victorian Division One – 2001 Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> In the following fixture, Westgate again earned 3 points with another 5–0 victory away against [[Frankston Pines]].<ref name=\"ozfootball18\"/> Westgate would then go on to achieve a 2–0 and a 1–0 victory, keeping a clean sheet for four weeks straight.<ref name=\"ozfootball18\"/> Unbeaten since Round 3, Westgates undefeated streak was ended in Round 13 in a 1–0 home defeat against [[Western Suburbs SC
column4: Western Suburs]].<ref name=\"ozfootball18\"/> Another two losses followed, followed by a series of two draws and another loss, Westgate did not win another fixture until Round 19 in a 3–0 away victory against [[Sunshine George Cross FC
column5: Sunshine George Cross]], with Tony Lingurovski scoring a hat-trick.<ref name=\"ozfootball18\"/> Westgate concluded the last 3 fixtures of the season with two draws and a 5–0 home victory against Frankston Strikers on 9 September.<ref name=\"ozfootball18\"/> Westgate concluded the season in 7th position with 31 points.<ref name=\"ozfootball19\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2001D1T.html Victorian State League Division One – 2001] {{webarchive
column7: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Tony Lingurovski had scored a total of 14 league goals and finished the season as the league's 3rd leading goal scorer.<ref name=\"ozfootball20\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2001Score.html Victorian Leagues Leading Scorers – 2001] {{webarchive

column2: caption = Westgate 2001 State League Cup final squad.<ref name=\"ozfootball21\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2001StateCup.html 2001 Victorian State League Cup] {{webarchive

column1: Westgate were drawn in Group 6 of the 2001 State League Cup against [[Keilor Park SC
column2: Keilor Park]], Williamstown and North Sunshine Eagles. Westgate woul gain 5 points form their group stage, having drawn twice and won in a 5–1 thrashing against Northern Sunshine Eagles on March, with Francisco Vera netting a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball21\"/> In Round 2 of the competition, Westgate were drawn against Westvale where they would defeat them 3–2 on 17 March. On 25 March, Westgate defeated Whittlesea Stallions 2–0 at the quarter-final stage of the competition.<ref name=\"ozfootball21\"/> In the semi-final, Westgate faced [[Northcote City SC
column3: Northcote City]] on 16 April, where they would come out winners with a 4–3 result after extra time.<ref name=\"ozfootball21\"/> Westgate then faced [[Cranbourne Comets]] in the 2001 State League Cup final on 25 April, the match was refereed by Senko Rastocic and the venue of the final was SS Anderson Reserve, the stadium of [[Port Melbourne Sharks]].<ref name=\"ozfootball21\"/> Cranbourne Comets had not conceded a goal during the entire competition, going six games with a clean sheet.<ref name=\"ozfootball21\"/> Darryl Spiteri, Zoran Kostadinovski and Alex Jovicic were all substituted in during the second half for Westgate as Dusko Delic scored in the 67th minute of the match to win 1–0.<ref name=\"ozfootball21\"/>

column1: Westgate began the 2002 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] campaign with a series of poor results, one loss and two draws, before earning their first 3 points in Round 4 against [[Springvale White Eagles]] in a 1–0 home victory on 28 April.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2002D1R.html 2002 Victorian State League Division One – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> They were only able to score 2 goals out of the 4 fixtures.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> The following two rounds saw Westgate suffer defeats, without being able to score any goals, a 3–0 away loss against Essendon Royals on 4 May and a 2–0 home defeat against Knox City on 11 May.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> In Round 7, they were able to gain an important 3 points in a 3–1 away victory against Thomastown Devils on 20 May, with goals coming from Kwabena Adomako, Dan Ito and Ernie Tapai.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> In Round 9, Westgate avoided defeat against [[Frankston Pines]], who eventually won the league and lost just once, after a 0–0 away draw on 1 June.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> Westgate continued to draw their fixtures, which eventually became a total of 9 as the season concluded.<ref>[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2002D1T.html 2002 Victorian State League Division One – Final Table] {{webarchive
column5: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> They were able to earn another important 3 points in a 3–1 home victory against Essendon Royals on 20 July.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> Another series of losses and draws would continue, including another tie with Frankston Pines, which ended 1–1 at home on 18 August.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> In round 21, Westgate defeat [[Oakleigh Cannons]] 1–0 at home on 31 August with a goal from Zdravko Atanasovski and in the following fixture thrashing Lalor United 9–3 away on 7 September with Jim Gacovski scoring three and Quentin O'Grady, Kwabena Adomako and Rene Andersen netting a double each.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> The 9–3 result recorded the club's highest ever win.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/> Westgate finished the 2002 season third last, with 27 points, needing just 2 points to avoid relegation, and subsequently appeared in the league play-off against [[Hume City
column6: North Coburg United]], who had finished in 2nd place in the 2002 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West.<ref>[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2002D2NWT.html 2002 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive
column8: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Over just one-leg of the promotion-relegation play-off, Westgate were defeated 4–2 against North Coburg United on 21 September and, along with Springvale White Eagles and Lalor United, were relegated to the Victorian State League Division 2.<ref name=\"ozfootball22\"/>

column1: The 2003 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West season began in a positive manner for Westgate, as they obtained 10 points in their first five fixtures, losing just one, and winning three times, including two 4–2 home victories.<ref name=\"ozfootball23\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2003D2NWR.html 2003 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> A series of losses would then following, including a 4–0 thrashing against Williamstown on 7 June in Round 9.<ref name=\"ozfootball23\"/> This was part of six rounds going without a win, with Westgate losing give times and drawing just once.<ref name=\"ozfootball23\"/> In Round 12, Westgate earned an important victory against [[Moreland City]] in a 3–2 away victory on 28 June, with Daniel Glogovac scoring a double and Alex Jovicic netting to assure Westgate's victory against a team who eventually went on to finish in third place of the table.<ref name=\"ozfootball23\"/> In the following round, Westgate would record a 5–1 home victory against [[Croxton Park]] on 5 July, with Daniel Glogovac again on the scoresheet alongside Sam Bubulj, and Dino Grillo, who scored a hat-trick.<ref name=\"ozfootball23\"/> Westgate went on to suffer two consecutive 4–1 defeats, before drawing the last two fixtures of the season 2–2 and 3–3, with Dino Grillo scoring three goals in within the two matches.<ref name=\"ozfootball23\"/> Westgate concluded the season in 9th spot of the Victorian State League Division 2 North-West table, three points from being relegated, with a total of 28 points.<ref>[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2003D2NWT.html 2003 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Having lost in Round 1 of the 2004 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West season, Westgate obtained 6 points in their next two matches, having won twice, with Con Georgiou scoring 4 goals during both fixtures<ref name=\"ozfootball24\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2004D2NWR.html 2004 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Westgate went on to draw three times and win once in the next four rounds, with Ivan Filiposki scoring in three out of the four fixtures.<ref name=\"ozfootball24\"/> Westgate continued their undefeated streak by defeating North Sunshine Eagles 4–2 at home on 5 June and [[Moreland City]] 1–0 at home in the following fixtures on 12 June, Ivan Filiposki again netting in both matches.<ref name=\"ozfootball24\"/> Filiposki scored in the following fixture, a 2–1 away loss against [[Brunswick City]] on 19 June, the defeat spelling an end to the club's nine-week undefeated stint. in Round 14, Westgate would win 4–1 away at Corio on 10 July, with two goals from Ivan Filiposki.<ref name=\"ozfootball24\"/> Filiposki had scored 7 goals in the last 6 consecutive fixtures from Rounds 9 to 14.<ref name=\"ozfootball24\"/> In Round 17 on 31 July, Westgate recorded a 5–0 home victory against [[Albion Rovers SC]] with a double being scored by both Dimce Panev and David Maglovski, Alex Stevanovic would also get on the score sheet.<ref name=\"ozfootball24\"/> Westgate would then draw once and win twice before losing their last two fixtures of the 2004 season.<ref name=\"ozfootball24\"/> The season concluded seeing Westgate with 38 points, one point under [[Keilor Park SC
column4: Keilor Park]], finishing in 4th position.<ref>[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2004D2NWT.html 2004 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Beginning the 2005 season winning their first two fixtures, Westgate would then lose their next two matches.<ref name=\"ozfootball25\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2005D2NWR.html 2005 Victorian State League Division 2 North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> In Round 5 they would draw 3–3 away against [[North Geelong Warriors]], who would eventually go on to win the league and gain promotion, on 30 April, with goals coming from Adrian Caniglia, Con Georgiou and Dejan Tosic.<ref name=\"ozfootball25\"/> In Round 8, Westgate would thrash [[Geelong SC]] 4–1 at home on 13 July, and would win the next three matches 1–0, 1–0 and 2–0.<ref name=\"ozfootball25\"/> Their four-week winning streak would end on 18 June against [[Banyule City]] in a 3–2 away defeat.<ref name=\"ozfootball25\"/> This defeat would be one of 10 matches that Westgate would lose out of their following 11 fixtures, losing 9 of them consecutively, including a 4–0 away loss against Lalor United on 20 August, and a 2–1 home loss against [[Thomastown Devils]] on 30 July, with one of Thomastown's goals being scored by Joe Montagnese, who would go on to coach Westgate in 2014.<ref name=\"ozfootball25\"/> Despite the club's 11-week winless streak, Westgate finished in 8th position of the 2005 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West season table with 23 points, just a single point clear of being relegated.<ref>[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2005D2NWT.html 2005 Victorian State League Division 2 North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: The 2006 season commenced with a 1–0 away victory against [[Altona City]] on 1 April.<ref name=\"ozfootball26\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2006SD2NWR.html 2006 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> Milan Savic scoring the only goal of the match.<ref name=\"ozfootball26\"/> In the following match, Westgate would win 4–2 at home against [[Westvale SC
column4: Westvale]] on 8 April with Dominic Murdaca scoring a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball26\"/> Westgate continued their winning streak with a 4–1 away victory in Round 3 against Keilor Park on 22 April, with Dominic Murdaca again on the score sheet.<ref name=\"ozfootball26\"/> Their first loss of the season came in the following fixture on 29 April, a 2–1 home defeat against [[Lalor United]].<ref name=\"ozfootball26\"/> This loss would be one of just four losses during the entire 2006 season, with Westgate commencing an 11-week unbeaten run as of Round 8 which included a 6-week winning streak which included two 4–0 victories.<ref name=\"ozfootball26\"/> Westgate eventually suffered a 2–0 away defeat against Yarraville Glory on 19 August in Round 19, however, Westgate had obtained their second league title with three league fixtures remaining.<ref name=\"ozfootball26\"/> Westgate finished in first place of the Victorian State League Division 2 North-West table with 50 points, 6 points clear of their nearest rivals Keilor Park.<ref name=\"ozfootball2\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2006SD2NWT.html 2006 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive
column6: date=21 April 2013 }}</ref> Dominic Murdaca had scored 11 goals for Westgate during the 2006 season and was also the leading goal scorer of the league.

column1: Westgate's commencement to the 2007 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] season began slowly, with just 4 points being obtained in the first five rounds.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2007SD1R.html 2007 Victorian State League Division One – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> In Round 6, the club would gain an important win to keep them mid-table in a 2–1 away victory against [[North Geelong Warriors]] on 19 May.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Westgate had been trailing 1–0 until goals from Daniel Glogovac and Marcos Oliveira would help seal the victory.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Westgate would go on to win the next two fixtures with clean sheets with two 1–0 results, including an away victory against [[Hume City FC
column4: Hume City]], who had been undefeated all season, on 2 June, with a goal from Zdravko Atanasovski.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> After two consecutive defeats, the club would play out a 3–3 draw with [[Brunswick City]] on 23 June to gain 1 point, with Robert Trajanovski scoring all three goals. In the following fixture, Westgate would gain a crucial 3 points after defeating [[Port Melbourne Sharks]] in a 2–1 result at home on 30 June to avoid the relegation zone.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Both Robert Trajanovski and Zdravko Atanasovski had netted Westgate's goals.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> In Round 14, Westgate were demolished 6–2 away against [[Dandenong Thunder]] on 14 July, the match would be one of three fixtures that Westgate would go on to lose in the next five rounds.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Westgate would not record their next win, a crucial one, until Round 19 which was again against [[Hume City FC
column5: Hume City]] as goals came from Ilce Mladenovski and Boban Pajic.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Westgate sealed a 2–1 home victory on 18 August.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Ilce Mladenovski would again strike in the following fixture against [[St. Albans Saints]] as Westgate defeated their opponents in a 1–0 away victory on 26 August, assuring their presence in the Victorian State League Division 1 for the 2008 season.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> The club would end the season with a 2–1 away victory against [[Brunswick City]] on 8 September in Round 22, with goals coming from Joe De Bono and Michael Maljanek.<ref name=\"ozfootball27\"/> Westgate concluded the 2007 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] season in 7th place with 30 points, having won 8, drawn 6 and lost 8 fixtures in total.<ref>[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2007SD1T.html 2007 Victorian State League Division One – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Westgate commenced the 2008 [[Victorian State League Division 1]] season two consecutive loses before gaining their first 3 points in a 4–0 home victory against [[Springvale White Eagles]] on 19 April in Round 3, with Boban Pajic scoring twice.<ref name=\"ozfootball28\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2008SD1R.html 2008 Victorian State League Division One – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=30 May 2013 }}</ref> In Round 5, Westgate recorder an important 3–1 home victory against [[Sunshine George Cross FC
column4: Sunshine George Cross]] on 3 May, with Robert Trajanovski scoring his third goal in three consecutive fixtures.<ref name=\"ozfootball28\"/> Westgate would then face poor results, drawing four times and losing twice in the next six rounds.<ref name=\"ozfootball28\"/> They would not get their next win until Round 12 in a 4–1 away victory against Kingston City on 20 June.<ref name=\"ozfootball28\"/> Westgate would gain just 2 points out of their next 8 fixtures, having suffered 6 loses, including a 7–1 away thumping against [[Bulleen Royals]] on 25 August.<ref name=\"ozfootball28\"/> The club would get its last win of the 2008 season in a 2–0 home victory against Keilor Park on 30 August before being held 1–1 away at Langwarrin on 6 September.<ref name=\"ozfootball28\"/> Westgate had finished in third last place on the table, with 20 league points, and were relegated alongside Keilor Park and [[Kingston City]].<ref name=\"ozfootball3\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2008SD1T.html 2008 Victorian State League Division One – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Westgate's 2009 Victorian State League Division 2 campaign got under way on a negative note, with the club obtaining just two points out of its first four fixtures.<ref name=\"ozfootball29\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2009SD2NWR.html 2009 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=20 April 2013 }}</ref> They would record their first win in Round 5 in a 2–0 away victory against Williamstown on 2 May, with Jamie Porter netting a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball29\"/> One week later, a 6–2 away thrashing would follow at the hands of [[North Geelong Warriors]] on 8 May. David Maglovski would score both of Westgate's goals.<ref name=\"ozfootball29\"/> Another victory would follow, as Westgate then went on to lose three more matches. In Round 12, the club would secure its third league win in a 4–1 thrashing against Thomastown Devils on 27 June.<ref name=\"ozfootball29\"/> The club faced a series of draws and losses before earning their last wins in Rounds 20 and 22, with Kwabee Otuo-Acheampong scoring a total of three goals in both fixtures.<ref name=\"ozfootball29\"/> Westgate were relegated for the second consecutive season, again alongside Keilor Park. Both clubs had finished as the bottom two teams on the 2009 Victorian State League Division 2 North-West table.<ref name=\"ozfootball4\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2009SD2NWT.html 2009 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Westgate commenced the 2010 [[Victorian State League Division 3]] with two consecutive draws before obtaining their first win in a 3–2 away victory against [[Melbourne University Rangers]] on 24 April, as Volkan Kalayci scored a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball30\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2010SD3NWR.html 2010 Victorian State League Division Three North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=20 April 2013 }}</ref> By Round 10, the club would suffer just its third defeat of the season as by that time they had gained 15 points. After two consecutive loses, Westgate defeated [[Geelong SC]] 2–1 away from home on 23 July, as Josh D'Alessi would score both goals to keep the club's title hopes alive.<ref name=\"ozfootball30\"/> Westgate would go on to win the next three fixtures with Henry Nunez scoring in each match, including a 6–1 home thrashing of [[Essendon United]] on 14 August, where Josh D'Alessi would score a hat-trick making that his sixth goal in the last four matches.<ref name=\"ozfootball30\"/> D'Alessi went on to score a double in the next fixture as Westgate were defeated 4–2 away at [[La Trobe University]] on 21 August. Westgate would win the next three league matches, conceding just one goal in the process, which clinched them the title and gained them promotion back into the [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West for the 2011 season having concluded the season with 40 points, just two points from their nearest rivals Geelong SC.<ref name=\"ozfootball5\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2010SD3NWT.html 2010 Victorian State League Division Three North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: The club commenced the 2011 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West on a positive note with two wins in their first three matches, with Nana Addo scoring 3 goals in 3 appearances.<ref name=\"ozfootball31\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2011SD2NWR.html 2011 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=20 April 2013 }}</ref> Westgate earned two important victories in the next four rounds, including a 3–2 home victory against [[Altona East Phoenix]] on 30 April, with Josh D'Alessi netting a double. Westgate would comfortably beat [[Banyule City]] 4–1 at home on 28 May, before being thrashed 5–1 away against [[Moreland City]] in the following fixture on 4 June, with Joe De Bono scoring in both matches for Westgate.<ref name=\"ozfootball31\"/> The following week, the club faced another 5–1 thrashing away against [[Ballarat Red Devils]] on 18 June. By Round 13, the club faced their fourth loss in five matches until a 15th minute Henry Nunez goal in a Round 14 fixture was enough to see the club earn a 1–0 home victory against [[Williamstown, Victoria
column4: Williamstown]] on 16 July. Westgate would then suffer four defeats in the next five fixtures. In Round 21, the club would earn just their seventh win of the 2011 season in a 4–1 home victory against [[Ballarat Red Devils]] on 12 September, with Joe De Bono scoring a double.<ref name=\"ozfootball31\"/> Westgate finished in 9th position on the table, having been deducted 3 points along with [[Werribee City]], [[Brunswick City]], [[Clifton Hill, Victoria
column5: Clifton Hill]] and [[Geelong SC]], with 21 league points in total.<ref name=\"ozfootball32\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2011SD2NWT.html 2011 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Westgate commenced the 2012 FFV Division 2 season with a 4–1 home victory against [[Preston Lions]] on 31 March.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2012SD2NWR.html 2012 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Season Results] {{webarchive
column3: date=17 March 2014 }}</ref> In Round 2, the club would be held to a 1–1 away draw against [[Ballarat Red Devils]] on 14 April, this draw being one of eleven that Westgate would go on to take with them to the end of the season.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\"/> In Round 5, the club recorded its second win of the season in a 2–0 away victory against [[Keilor Park SC
column4: Keilor Park]] on 12 May, with goals coming from Matthew Italiano and Nemanja Vucic.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\"/> Westgate would go on to win two out of their next five fixtures, including a 4–2 home victory against [[La Trobe University]] on 23 June, with Raffael Origlia scoring a first-half double.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\"/> Origlia would score in the next fixture as Westgate would be defeated 2–1 away against [[Moreland City]] on 30 June, having been 1–0 in front. Westgate went on to suffer two consecutive defeats in their next three fixtures, including a 4–1 home thrashing against [[Brunswick City]] on 21 July.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\"/> In Round 18, Westgate would earn their last match of the 2012 season in a 3–2 home victory against Clifton Hill on 18 August, with goals coming from Matthew Italiano, Raffael Origlia and Kwabee Otuo-Acheampong.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\"/> The club would draw their last three fixtures of the season before concluding the competition in 7th position of the 2012 [[Victorian State League Division 2]] North-West table, having been deducted one point, ultimately with 25 points.<ref name=\"ozfootball33\"/><ref name=\"ozfootball34\">[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2012SD2NWT.html 2012 Victorian State League Division Two North-West – Final Table] {{webarchive

column1: Due to the introduction of Australia's new [[National Premier Leagues
column2: National Premier League]] competition, Westgate went from State League 2 North-West to the new State League 1 North-West, but retained its level in the [[Australian soccer league system]] as the Premier League was made up of NPL Victoria and NPL Victoria 2. The club participated in its first official competitive fixture in the [[2014 Dockerty Cup]]. It was the club's first appearance in the competition since its return in 2011. Westgate were defeated 3–0 at home against Mornington in the competition's Third Round on 14 March.<ref name=\"foxsportspulse\">{{cite web
column4: title=FFV – Metropolitan Match Centre – FOX SPORTS PULSE
column8: title=Results for Dockerty Cup – FOX SPORTS PULSE
column12: title= Westgate FC Season Fixture in FFV – Metropolitan – FOX SPORTS PULSE
column14: accessdate=2015-11-30}}</ref> Westgate finished the season in 9th place, two points clear of the relegation zone.<ref name=\"foxsportspulse4\">{{cite web
column16: title=Ladder for Men's State League 1 North-West – FOX SPORTS PULSE

column1: In 2015, Westgate dispatched Hampton Park United by a scoreline of 5–1 in the Third Round of the [[2015 FFA Cup preliminary rounds]], but lost 3–1 to [[Geelong SC]] at Stead Park in the Fourth Round, exiting the competition. In the league, Sindjelic once again placed 9th and once more narrowly avoided relegation, this time by three points.<ref name=\"foxsportspulse5\">{{cite web
column3: title=Ladder for Zagame's Men's State League 1 North-West – FOX SPORTS PULSE

column1: Fortunes improved in 2016 and, with a young squad, the club finished in 6th place, well beyond pre-season expectations.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Ladder for Zagame's Men's State League 1 North-West

column1: In 2017, though, Westgate was unable to fend off relegation, finishing in 11th position and experiencing relegation back to State League 2 North-West.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Ladder for Men's State League 1 North-West

column1: In the off-season, Westgate presented its newly redeveloped $1.5m facility, \"Oreana Park\" at Ardeer Reserve.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Star Weekly {{!}} New soccer pavilion for Ardeer

column1: Westgate FC's home ground, Ardeer Reserve, is located on Yallourn Street in Melbourne's western suburb of [[Ardeer, Victoria
column2: Ardeer]].<ref name=\"foxsportspulse1\"/> It sits approximately 10 blocks from [[Sunshine George Cross FC]] stadium K. G. Chaplin Reserve, and 13 blocks from [[Sunshine railway station, Melbourne]].<ref name=\"google\">{{cite web
