column37: archivedate= 5 June 2014 }}</ref> The Singapore police were on location to block roads and protect the filming equipment,<ref name=sify1/> such as when the film's action scenes required two 250-foot high industrial cranes.<ref name=action/> Author Audrey Yue noted that the film shoot benefited Singapore by leading to domestic and Indian [[Pop-culture tourism

column1: Filming also took place in [[Manali, Himachal Pradesh
column2: Manali]] and [[Film City]] in [[Mumbai]].<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=11 November 2013 }}</ref> During filming of a flying stunt, one of the wires that was tied to Hrithik Roshan broke, causing him to fall 50 feet, though he landed safely on a shop's canopy.<ref name=\"fall\">{{cite web
column14: accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> Hrithik described the incident as a \"freak accident\", stating, \"I was skydiving to my death till I fell on a six-feet-long canopy of a shop that was out because of the slight drizzle. The canopy had iron rods. But I missed those rods too. What do I say? I guess the right word to describe the situation would be ''jadoo'' (magic).\"<ref name=\"fall\"/> Roshan also suffered other injuries during the film's production. He tore the hamstring in his right leg during a circus scene, singed his hair while running through fire in another action scene, and broke his thumb and toe during strenuous training for the wirework.<ref>{{cite web

column2: Prasad EFX]] assigned a team of more than 100 VFX specialists to work with Marc Kolbe and Craig Mumma to create the visual effects for the film.<ref name=osa/><ref name=pdf>{{cite news
column12: title=Friday Review Chennai / Cinema : '\"Krrish\" will be a trendsetter'
column18: archivedate=21 February 2014 }}</ref> Included were sophisticated [[3D modelling]] and [[computer animation]], including whole body scans, 3D replicas of vehicles, fire sequences, complicated wire removals and [[compositing]] work.<ref name=osa/> They prepared over 1,200 VFX shots, accounting for approximately 90 minutes of screen time.<ref name=made>{{cite web
column27: title=Krrish, a giant leap for Bollywood
column34: archivedate= 3 October 2012 }}</ref> Describing the effects, Rakesh Roshan stated, \"If you liked the visual effects in ''Koi... Mil Gaya'', you will find them far better in ''Krrish''. I do not think audiences have seen anything like this in Hindi films.\"<ref>Subhash K. Jha, Indo-Asian News Service, Mumbai, 18 June 2006</ref><ref>{{cite web

column1: The film's soundtrack, composed by [[Rajesh Roshan]], was released on 30 April 2006 by  [[T-Series (company)
column2: T-Series]].<ref name=\"music 2\"/> Lyricists included Ibraheem Ashk, Nasir Faraaz, and Vijay Akela. [[Salim-Sulaiman]] provided the background score. It became the seventh best selling Bollywood soundtrack of the year.<ref>{{cite web
extra7 = Rafaqat Ali Khan, Alka Yagnik

column1: Critical reviews of the soundtrack were generally favourable, though some in the media called it a disappointment.<ref name=hw/> Joginder Tuteja of Bollywood Hungama gave the album a rating of 3.5 out of 5 stars, saying that it was \"another good outing for Bollywood music lovers.\" He especially praised the songs \"Chori Chori\", \"Koi Tumsa Nahi\", and \"Pyaar Ki Ek Kahani.\"<ref name=\"music 1\">{{cite web
column8: Rediff]] gave a favourable review for the soundtracks's \"catchy\" songs. However, she felt that while the songs meshed with the film, \"none of them bear the staying power of Rajesh Roshan's earlier soundtracks.\"<ref>{{cite web
column16: archivedate=25 March 2008 }}</ref> Shruti Bhasin of Planet Bollywood enjoyed the original songs, giving 8.5 out of 10 stars, but was disappointed with the remixes.<ref name=\"music 2\">{{cite web
column17: title=''Krrish'' – Music Review by: Shruti Bhasin
column23: archivedate=18 September 2012 }}</ref> Dr Mandar V. Bichu of Gulf News said that it did not live up to the pre-release expectations.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The final budget of ''Krrish'' came to {{INRConvert
column3: m}},<ref name=\"Budget\"/> which at the time was considered big-budget film by Bollywood standards.<ref name=budget2>{{cite news
column7: title=South Asia | Bollywood launches its superhero
column16: title=Krrish grosses over Rs 100 cr in 2 weeks
column22: archivedate= 2 June 2014 }}</ref> The film was released on 23 June 2006 with 1,000 prints,<ref name=superman>{{cite web
column26: title=`Krrish,' Bollywood Blockbuster, Pummels `Superman' in India
column32: archivedate=12 September 2011 }}</ref> and in five languages simultaneously. It was the first Indian film to receive payments in advance for product placement, music, and international distribution rights.<ref name=study>{{cite news
column38: url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2006-07-16/india/27812519_1_krrish-case-study-singapore-government}}</ref> There was also related merchandise offered for sale prior to the film's release to maximize profits. These included action figures, masks and other toys.<ref>{{cite web
column54: archivedate= 2 June 2014 }}</ref> The film's DVD was released in [[DVD region code#Region codes and countries
column59: accessdate=20 August 2009}}</ref> On 21 August 2006, it was released for all regions by Filmkraft.<ref>{{cite web
column63: accessdate=20 August 2009}}</ref> Adlabs also released a Blu-ray version.<ref>{{cite web
column67: accessdate=29 March 2012}}</ref> After the success of ''Krrish'', Rakesh Roshan announced that he would be making a sequel, tentatively titled ''[[Krrish 3]]''. He confirmed that Hrithik Roshan and Priyanka Chopra would reprise their roles,<ref>{{cite web
column75: archivedate=21 October 2012 }}</ref> and that the main antagonist would be played by [[Vivek Oberoi]].<ref>{{cite web
column77: title=Vivek to play villain in Krrish 3 – Times Of India

column1: ''Krrish'' received mixed reviews from critics in India.<ref name=mixed>{{cite web
column3: title=Krrish might outfly Fanaa — Rediff.com Movies
column9: archivedate= 2 June 2014 }}</ref> [[Taran Adarsh]] of [[Bollywood Hungama]] believed that the film surpassed expectations, but felt that there were issues with pacing in first hour. Overall, he deemed ''Krrish'' to be \"a terrifically exciting and compelling experience\", and awarded the film 4.5 of 5 stars.<ref name=bhr>{{cite web
column19: archivedate=30 January 2013 }}</ref> Nikhat Kazmi noted in ''[[The Times of India]]'' that while the superhero and action sequences were appealing, there were not enough of them. He was also not excited by the romantic parts, comparing them to a sightseeing tour, first in India and then in Singapore. He said that overall, this film lacks the fun of its predecessor.<ref name=toireview>{{cite web
column24: accessdate=29 March 2012}}</ref> On the other hand, Raja Sen said that ''Krrish'' was infinitely better than ''KMG'', though ultimately it was all about Hrithik Roshan. Sen and Sukanya Verma, writing for [[Rediff.com
column25: Rediff]], both gave the film 3 out of 5 stars, and both said that it was a good film for children. Sen summarised \"So, is it a good superhero movie? No, but it's well-intentioned. It's a full-on kiddie movie, and while a lot of us might be scornful of ''Krrish'', it's heartening to see fantasy officially entering mainstream Bollywood.\"<ref name=rdr1>{{cite web
column27: title=Hrithik makes Krrish work — Rediff.com movies
column33: archivedate=28 March 2012 }}</ref> Verma agreed with other critics that it took too long for the action to get started, and said that a lot of attention was spent showing off Roshan's muscles. He summarised, \"''Krrish'' neither has the sleek aura nor the deep-rooted ideology of superheroes. What it does have is a super spirited performance from Hrithik Roshan, which is likely to appeal to children. And that's worth a three-star cheer.\"<ref name=rdr2>{{cite web
column35: title=A super spirited Hrithik! – Rediff.com movies
column41: archivedate=25 November 2011 }}</ref> Saibal Chatterjee wrote in the ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' that ''Krrish'' is a hackneyed, formulaic masala film, with special effects added on top, and hoped that this would not be the future of Bollywood.<ref name=htreview>{{cite web
column49: archivedate= 7 June 2014 }}</ref> Rajeev Masand of [[CNN-IBN]] condemned the screenplay and thought that the only thing that made the film watchable was the acting of Hrithik Roshan. He gave the film only 2 out of 5 stars, saying \"''Krrish'' is only an average film that could have been so much better if the makers had concentrated as hard on its story as they did on its action and stunts.\"<ref name=ibnreview>{{cite web
column51: title=Masand's Verdict: Krrish-crass — Movies News News — IBNLive

column1: Overseas reviews were consistently positive.<ref name=fan/> The [[Rotten Tomatoes]] aggregate rating is 88% \"Fresh\", based on 8 reviews, with an average rating of 7 out of 10.<ref name=\"100% fresh\">{{rotten-tomatoes
column3: Krrish}}</ref> Richard James Havis of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' stated, \"This Bollywood epic crunches together romance, comedy, extraterrestrials, martial arts, dancing and action to tell an entertaining story about a reluctant Indian superhero\" but said it may be \"far too crazed for foreign viewers\".<ref name=fan>{{cite web
column10: archivedate=19 October 2012 }}</ref> David Chute of ''[[LA Weekly]]'' deemed it a \"hearty pulp cinema that really sticks to your ribs\".<ref name=\"100% fresh\"/> Likewise, Laura Kern of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said it was a blend of carefree romance, show-stopping action and sci-fi.<ref>{{cite web
column21: Variety]]'' said that it was an \"enjoyable, daffily improbable escapist romp\". He praised the action sequences as ingeniously choreographed, but very family-friendly.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title=Variety Reviews — Krrish — Film Reviews — N.Y. Asian — Review by Ronnie Scheib
column32: archivedate=12 November 2012 }}</ref> Though Jaspreet Pandohar of [[BBC]] was critical of the script for being \"low on originality\", he praised Hrithik Roshan's performance and the action scenes.<ref name=bbcr>{{cite web
column39: archivedate=18 July 2006 }}</ref> Dr. P.V. Vaidyanathan, in a review for BBC Shropshire, said that the film's excellent special effects were as good as the best from Hollywood, praised Hritik's acting, but called the music mundane.<ref name=bbc2>{{cite web

column1: ''Krrish'' had a good opening week,<ref name=gnweek>{{cite web
column3: title=Bollywood's Superman flies high at box office
column9: archivedate=21 February 2014 }}</ref> and tickets were reportedly selling for many times the original cost at some locations.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Krrish might outfly Fanaa — Rediff.com movies
column17: archivedate=15 April 2012 }}</ref> Total gross collections were an Indian record of {{INRConvert
column21: m}} nett) for its opening week.<ref>{{cite web
column28: url-status=dead }}</ref> ''Krrish'' became the second-highest-grossing film of 2006, earning over {{INR}} 690 million nett in India alone, and was classified as a \"Blockbuster\" by Box Office India.<ref>{{cite web
column35: url-status=dead }}</ref> It also grossed $4,320,000 in the overseas market, where it was declared a \"hit\".<ref>{{cite web
column42: url-status=dead }}</ref> The final worldwide total gross was {{INRConvert
column51: url-status=dead }}</ref> One week after ''Krrish'' was released, another superhero film, ''[[Superman Returns]]'' was released in India. Rakesh Roshan stated, \"I was a little skeptical that Superman might hurt me, but fortunately it didn't.\" In fact, ''Krrish'' fared better at the box office in India than ''Superman Returns'' did.<ref name=superman/>

column1: ''Krrish'' was one of India's possible nominations for the [[List of submissions to the 79th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film
column2: 2007 Academy Award for Best Foreign Film]], but the country ultimately chose ''[[Rang De Basanti]]'' as its pick.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Rang De heads to the Oscars!
column10: archivedate=18 October 2012 }}</ref> Despite this, ''Krrish'' won numerous awards, including three [[Filmfare Award]]s—[[Filmfare Best Special Effects Award
column11: Best Special Effects]], [[Filmfare Best Action Award
column12: Best Action]] and [[Filmfare Best Background Score Award
column13: Best Background Score]]—and was nominated for the awards of [[Filmfare Best Film Award
column16: Best Actor]], [[Filmfare Best Supporting Actress Award
column17: Best Supporting Actress]], and [[Filmfare Best Villain Award
column20: title=Filmfare Award Winners 2007 – 52nd (Fifty Second) Fair One Filmfare Awards
column30: accessdate=21 August 2009}}</ref> At the [[2007 IIFA Awards]], ''Krrish'' received awards for [[IIFA Best Actor Award
column34: title=Rang de Basanti best film, Hrithik best actor — Times Of India
column39: title=Rang De Basanti wins Best Film at IIFA
column45: archivedate=21 February 2014 }}</ref> [[IIFA Award for Best Action
column46: Best Action]], and [[IIFA Award for Best Special Effects
column56: archivedate=12 June 2012 }}</ref> Rakesh Roshan won the Creative Person of the Year title. Additionally the film was nominated in the following categories at the ceremony: Best Director, Best Story, and Best Music Direction.<ref>{{cite web
column64: title=IIFA Awards 2007 – 8th International Indian Film Academy Awards — Samsung IIFA

column1: [[Hrithik Roshan]] won other acting awards that year, including the [[Star Screen Award Best Actor]],<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Hrithik, Kareena clinch Screen Awards — Movies News News — IBNLive
column9: archivedate=14 October 2012 }}</ref> [[Zee Cine Award for Best Actor – Male]],<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=RDB, Munnabhai win big at Zee Cine Awards
column18: df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Bengal Film Journalists' Association - Best Actor Award (Hindi)
column21: title=70th Annual BFJA Awards for the year 2006
column25: accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref> and [[GIFA Best Actor]].<ref>{{cite news
column28: title=Film about independence sweeps Indian Film Awards — Arts & Entertainment — CBC News
column31: accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref> The film's special effects won the [[National Film Award for Best Special Effects]].<ref>{{cite web
column34: publisher=Directorate of Film Festivals – Ministry of Information & Broadcasting
column38: archivedate=17 April 2012 }}</ref> The film also took Best Picture honours at the [[Matri Shree Media Award]]s.<ref>[https://archive.is/20131008011245/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/23-scribes-felicitated-with-Matri-Shree-awards/Article1-219307.aspx 23 scribes felicitated with Matri Shree awards - Hindustan Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

column1: In a showing of the film's popularity with children, ''Krrish'' swept the major film categories at the [[Pogo (TV channel)
column2: Pogo]] Amazing Kid's Awards, which are voted on by children across India. Winners were: Hrithik Roshan (Most Amazing Actor — Male), Priyanka Chopra (Most Amazing Actor — Female), ''Krrish'' (Most Amazing Film), Special Effects in ''Krrish'' (Most Amazing Moment in a film).<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Host of 'Young Geniuses' honoured at Pogo Amazing kids awards
title=In ''Krrish'', Bollywood Gets a Superhero of Its Own

column1: The term '''Gujarati Muslims''' is usually used to signify an Indian [[Muslim]] from the state of [[Gujarat]] in western coast of India.  Gujarati Muslims are very prominent in industry and medium-sized businesses, and there is a very large Gujarati Muslim community in [[Mumbai]].<ref>{{cite book
column6: title=Bombay and Mumbai : the city in transition
column11: url=https://books.google.com/?id=jmPuAAAAIAAJ&q=gujarati+muslims+in+mumbai&dq=gujarati+muslims+in+mumbai}}</ref>. Gujrati Muslim are termed as the richest Muslims in India and Pakistan as well. Many members of this community migrated to [[Pakistan]] in 1947 and have settled in [[Sindh]] province especially in [[Karachi]], contributing to the national welfare and economy of Pakistan.<ref>{{cite book
column13: title=Karachi : ordered disorder and the struggle for the city
column19: quote=Out of Pakistan's forty-two largest industrial groups, thirty-six were in the hands of Karachi-based businessmen - generally members of the Gujarati/Kutchi/Kathiawari trading sects, both Sunni (Memon) and Shia (Khojas, Bohras, etc.)  Whereas they accounted for 0.4 per cent of Pakistan's total population, Gujarati trading groups (they are considered [[Muhajir people
column20: Muhajir]] since many of their members were already settled in Karachi before the independence) controlled 43 per cent of the country's industrial capital. Halai Memons alone (0.3 per cent of the national population) owned 27 per cent of these industries. And while he patronised Pashtun entrepreneurs in Karachi, Ayub Khan also relied upon Gujarati businessmen to finance his electoral campaign in 1964, while facilitating the entry into politics of some Muhajir entrepreneurs, such as Sadiq Dawood, a Memon industrialist who became an MNA,  and the Treasurer of Ayub's Convention Muslim League.}}</ref> Having earned a formidable accolade as some of India's greatest seafaring merchants,<ref>{{cite book
column23: title=Interwoven Globe: The Worldwide Textile Trade, 1500-1800
column24: publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York
column29: quote=Of the Asian trading communities the most successful were the Gujaratis, as witnessed not only by Pires and Barbosa but by a variety of other sources. All confirm that merchants from the Gujarati community routinely held the most senior post open to an expatriate trader, that of shah-bandar (controller of maritime trade).
column30: year=2013}}</ref> the centuries-old Gujarati diaspora is found scattered throughout the ''Near East, Indian Ocean, and Southern Hemisphere'' regions everywhere in between Africa and Japan with a notable presence in:<ref>{{cite web
column31: title=Where on earth do they speak Gujarati?
column35: title=New frontiers : imperialism's new communities in East Asia, 1842-1953
column43: quote=The 1889 Hong Kong Directory and Hong List for the Far East lists three Sindhi firms in Hong Kong among a total of thirty-one firms, of which the majority were Parsi and Gujarati Muslim.}}</ref> [[United Kingdom
column50: quote=Raziah Locate is a manager in a hospitality school. Her grandfather Omarjee Ismael embarked on a voyage with his wife in 1870 from Kathor, near Surat, in Gujarat. He came to Reunion Island to seek better opportunities to further his trade in clothing. Her grandfather was one of the 40,000 merchants, traders and artisans from Gujarat who are said to have voluntary migrated to Reunion Island starting in the 1850s. Her grandfather was one of the pioneers who paved the way for other Gujarati Muslims to settle in Reunion, who have built a mosque and a madrasa on the island.
column55: title=In the Heart of Mysterious Oman
column57: website=The New York Review of Books
column65: quote=Mr. Haji, clad in the gold-trimmed, white cap that is standard for Bohra men, was in a flurry on a recent Friday, as he catered to streams of constituents and answered phone calls. He slid effortlessly between Arabic, Urdu, English and Dawat ni zabaan—a strain of Gujarati particular to Bohras that is peppered with Arabic and Persian. He explained that they have other shrines in Yemen, but this is one of the most important. Some 10,000 Bohras, mostly from India but also from their populations in Pakistan, East Africa, the United States, Europe and the Middle East, travel here each year.}}</ref> [[Mozambique]],<ref>{{cite web
column67: title=Pakistanis who have never seen Pakistan
column71: quote=After ties broke down between India and Portugal, Gujarati Muslims stranded in Mozambique were given Pakistani citizenship...Merchants from Diu had settled on the island of Mozambique in the early 1800s. Hindus from Diu, Sunni Muslims from Daman, and others from Goa migrated to Mozambique as small traders, construction workers and petty employees. Many Gujaratis moved from South Africa to Mozambique in the latter half of the 19th century.}}</ref> [[Zanzibar]],<ref>{{cite book
column73: title=An African Indian Community in Hyderabad: Siddi Identity, Its Maintenance and Change
column79: quote=Some centuries later, the Gujarati merchants established permanent trading posts in Zanzibar, consolidating their influence in the Indian Ocean... Gujarati Muslims, and their Omani partners, engaged in a network of mercantile activities among Oman, Zanzibar and Bombay. Thanks to those mercantile Gujarati, India remained by far the principal trading partner of Zanzibar.}}</ref> [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Myanmar
column82: title=Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar and recent riots - an Aman Report
column84: website=Centre for study of society and secularism
column86: quote=Lot of Muslims had gone from Surat and still there is a beautiful Surti mosque. Muslims in Myanmar are highly diverse. There are very few ethnic Burmese Muslims, most of them are migrants from different parts of India when Burma was a part of India. There are large number of Tamil, Gujarati and Bengali and Bohra Muslims and very few Urdu speaking Muslims since Urdu speaking are not in business.
column96: quote=Gujarati merchants may also have financed slave voyages to Madagascar in the nineteenth century. They sailed to its west coast from the mid 1810s to the mid 1820s but do not appear to have become extensively involved in this trafficking, either as shippers or as financiers. This is likely explained by the increasing presence in coastal Madagascar of Khoja and Bohra Shi'ia merchants from Kutch who, together with the Bhatiya merchants, established a significant presence there as financiers of the slave trade from the second decade of the nineteenth century.

column1: According to the 2011 [[Census of India]], the Gujarati Muslim population was 5,846,761 but significant numbers of Gujarati Muslims are found within the larger context of the Gujarati diaspora that became established throughout all the inhabited continents of the world.{{cn

Most Gujarati Muslims have Gujarati language as their mother tongue, but some communities such as the [[Momin Ansari]], [[Memons]],<ref>Gazetteer of the Bombay Presidency, Gujarat Population: Musalmans and Parsis, Volume IX pages 13 to 14 Government Central Press, Bombay</ref> [[Gujarati Shaikh]],<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Parzor | The UNESCO Parsi Zoroastrian Project
column6: accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref><ref name=\"survey\">People of India Gujarat Volume XXII Part One Editors R. B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan and M Azeez Mohideen pages 74 to 77</ref> and others, have [[Urdu]] as their mother tongue.<ref>name=\"Indian Census 2001 - Religion\" [http://demotemp257.nic.in/httpdoc/Census_Data_2001/Census_data_finder/C_Series/Population_by_religious_communities.htm Indian Census 2001 - Religion] {{webarchive

column1: The majority of Gujarati Muslims are Sunni, with a minority of heterodox Shi'ite groups.
The Gujarati Muslims are further sub-divided into groups, such as the [[Sunni Bohra
column7: Ghanchi]] and [[Chhipa]] each with their own customs and traditions.

column1: Gujarati Muslims played a pivotal role in establishing [[Islam]] in [[Southeast Asia]].<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Gujarat helped establish Islam in SE Asia

column1: Located in the westernmost portion of India, Gujarat includes the region of [[Kutch]], [[Saurashtra (region)
column2: Saurashtra]], and the territories between the rivers [[Banas River
column4: Damanganga]]. [[Islam]] came early to Gujarat, with immigrant communities of [[Arab]] and [[Persian people
column5: Persian]] traders.  Most came as traders as they did before Islam and built a masjid during the times of Muhammad and other parts of the western seacoast of India as early as the 8th century C.E, spreading Islam soon as the religion gained a foothold in the Arabian peninsula.<ref>{{cite book
column12: quote=Islam was introduced into Gujarat in the 7th century C.E. The first Arab raid came in 635 when the Governor of Bahrain sent an expedition against Broach. Then through the centuries colonies of Arab and Persian merchants began sprouting in the port cities of  Gujarat, such as Cambay, Broach and Surat.
column13: isbn=9788171542208}}</ref> They were later joined by [[Persian people
column16: first1=edited by Tazim R. Kassam, Françoise
column17: title=Gināns : texts and contexts : essays on Ismaili hymns from South Asia in honour of Zawahir Moir
column26: quote=In the early period, it appears that the Ismailis in western India, consisted of ethnic Arab or Persian merchant settlers, as well as local converts from pastoralist, cultivating or merchant groups. They may have included militarised peasants and pastoralists from north-west India, some of whom went on to become part of the emerging Rajput status hierarchy... After the fall of Alamut to the Mongols in 1256, more Nizari missionaries came to Sind and Gujarat, Ucch in particular becoming an important centre.}}</ref> Many of these early merchants were [[Ismaili]] [[Shia]], both [[Mustaali]] and [[Nizari]]. They laid the foundation of the [[Mustaali
column27: Bohra]] and [[Khoja]] communities. In the early era however Gujarat was ruled by the [[Valabhi]] dynasty. In the thirteenth century, the last [[Hindu]] ruler Karna, was defeated by [[Alauddin Khalji]], the [[Turkic peoples
column29: Sultan of Dehli]]. This episode ushered a period of five centuries of Muslim Turkic and [[Mughal Empire
column30: Mughal]] rule, leading to a conversion of a number of Hindu Gujarati people to [[Islam]], and the creation of new communities such as the [[Molesalam Rajput

column1: In the sixteenth century, the [[Memon people
column2: Memon]] community immigrated from [[Sindh]] and settled in Kutch and [[Kathiawar]]. While in [[Bharuch]] and [[Surat]], a [[Schism (religion)
column3: schism]] occurred among the Bohras, and a new community of [[Sunni Bohra]]s was created. Another Muslim sect, the [[Mahdawi]] also settled in Gujarat, and led to the creation of the [[Tai (caste)
column6: first1=Ira M. Lapidus, University of California
column12: quote=The Mahdawi movement was important in Gujarat in the sixteenth century and was widely accepted during the reign of Sultan Akbar by the administrative, military, landowning, and merchant elites.}}</ref> In 1593, the Mughal Emperor [[Akbar]] conquered Gujarat, and incorporated Gujarat in the Mughal Empire. This period led to the settlement of the [[Mughal (tribe)
column13: Mughal]] community. A good many [[Sayyid of Gujarat
column15: Shaikh]] families also are said to have arrived during the period of Mughal rule. With the establishment of the Sufi [[Suhrawardiyya
column16: Suhrawardi]] and [[Chishti]] orders in [[Multan]], Sind and Gujarat, [[pir (Sufism)
column19: first1=Ira M. Lapidus, University of California
column26: accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> At the same time, the Muslims from various provinces such as [[Hyderabad Deccan]], [[Kerala]], Balochistan, Sindh, [[Punjab]], Gujarat, [[Kashmir]] and other parts of South Asia also moved to capitals of Muslim empire in [[Delhi]] and [[Agra]]. After the death of the Mughal emperor [[Aurangzeb]], in 1707, Mughal rule began weaken after ruling for a century. Most of Gujarat fell to the [[Maratha]]s, and this period saw the dispersal of further Pathans and Baluchis, who came as mercenaries and were destroyed or defeated by the [[Maratha]]s. Gujarat fell to [[United Kingdom
column27: British]] in the late 19th century.<ref name=\"Muslim Peoples pages 294\">Muslim Peoples: A World Ethnographic Survey editor Richard V Weekes pages 294 to 297</ref>

column1: Gujarati Muslim merchants played an historically important role in facilitating the Portuguese discovery of \"[[Indies
column8: quote=Historians have differed over the identity of the sailor, calling him a Christian, a Muslim and a Gujarati. According to another account, he was the famous Arab navigator Ibn Majid. Some historians suggest Majid could not have been near the vicinity at the time. German author Justus says it was Malam who accompanied Vasco...Italian researcher Sinthia Salvadori too has concluded that it was Malam who showed Gama the way to India. Salvadori has made this observation in her 'We Came In Dhows', an account written after interacting with people in Gujarat.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column9: title=Homage to a Historian: A Festschrift
column11: publisher=Dr. N. Subrahmanian 60th Birthday Celebration Committee
column16: title=Rethinking solidarity in global society : the challenge of globalisation for social and solidarity movements : 50 years after Bandung Asian-African Conference 1955
column18: publisher=Strategic Information and Research Development Centre
column24: accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref> in spreading and propagating Islam to the [[Far East]],<ref>{{cite book
column29: title=A history of Christianity in Indonesia
column37: quote=The predominant Muslim position in the international trade was also represented by Muslim outposts along the southern coast of the Indian subcontinent. They included Randir, Surat and Cambay (in Gujarat). In fact, they had been supposed to have not only played a significant role in international Muslim trade, but also in the spread of Islam, in supposedly in the Malay-Indonesian archipelago.}}</ref> and in promoting the British [[Exploration of Africa
column40: title=The shaping of modern Gujarat : plurality, Hindutva, and beyond
column48: quote=After the opening up of East Africa in the nineteenth century, they became pioneers of trading activity there, dominating not only the financial world but also the political affairs of the region. Interestingly, it was these Gujarati Muslim traders along with Kutchi Bhatias who provided equipment, rations and financial services to European explorers such as, Stanley,  Livingstone, Burton and Cameron, and thus facilitated the 'discovery of Africa'}}</ref> In Southeast Asia, Malays referred to the Islamic elite among them by the noble title of adhirajas.<ref>{{cite book
column51: title=A History of Early Southeast Asia Maritime Trade and Societal Development, 100-1500.
column59: quote=All the Gujarati merchants were Muslims, and the elite among them were termed adhiraja, a Malay title of nobility, seemingly as an acknowledgment that there was a local mix of the resident Gujarati merchant elite and the Malay political aristocracy.}}</ref> The [[Sufi]] trader, [[Nuruddin ar-Raniri
column60: Shaikh Randeri]] (Shaikh Raneri) was responsible for spreading Islam to [[Acheh]] in [[Indonesia]].<ref>{{cite book
column61: title=Biographical Encyclopaedia of Sufis: South Asia

column1: Surti merchants in particular also pioneered the use of scientific concepts, and invented structural and mechanical advances in technology for the nationbuilding of [[Mauritius]],<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=The genuis<!-- sic -->: Amode Ibrahim Atchia, (1868-1947)
column6: publisher=lexpess.mu.online}}</ref> such as introducing [[hydro-electric power]] to the people of [[Mauritius]].<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Major Atchia, a model of enterprise

column1: Gujarati speaking Muslim society has a unique custom known as '''Jamat Bandi''', literally meaning communal solidarity.<ref>{{cite web
column6: quote=Muslims of Gujarat are probably the most diverse of Muslim population of any other Indian state. Some of them came from different parts of the Islamic world over a period of thousand years to seek security, employment, trade, and to spread Islam; bringing with them their culture, knowledge, and their own versions of Islam. Though there has been much interaction with different Muslim groups, the differences have survived to make Gujarati Muslims a very diverse ummah...First came the Arabs; within the first 100 years of revelation of Quran, there were a number of Muslim towns along the coast of Gujarat. They were followed by Iranians, Africans, and Central Asians. Earlier Muslims came as traders; some came with the invading armies and settled down. Many others came seeking better employment opportunities, while some like Bohras came here fleeing persecution.}}</ref> This system is the traditional expression of communal solidarity. It is designed to regulate the affairs of the community and apply sanctions against infractions of the communal code. Almost all the main Gujarat communities, such as the Ghanchi,[[Ismailism
column7: Ismāʿīlī]],    [[Khoja]], [[Dawoodi Bohra]], [[Chhipa]], and [[Sunni Bohra]] have [[caste]] associations, known as jamats. Social organization at the Jamat Bandi level varies from community to community. In some communities, the Jamat simply runs a mosque and attached rest house, and a [[madrasah]]. Some larger communities, such as the [[Khoja]] and [[Memon people
column8: Memon]] have developed elaborate and highly formalized systems with written and registered constitutions. Their organizations own large properties, undertake housing projects and schools, dispensaries and weekly newspapers.

column1: The region of Kutch has always been historically distinct, with the Muslims there accounting for about twenty percent of the population. This region is characterised by salt deserts, such as the [[Rann of Kutch]]. Because of this landscape, the Kutch Muslims are [[Maldhari]] pastoral nomads found in the [[Banni Grasslands Reserve
column2: Banni]] region of Kutch. Most of them are said to have originated in Sindh, and speak a dialect of [[Kutchi language
column4: Sindhi]] loanwords. Major [[Maldhari]] communities include the [[Sandhai Muslims]], [[Jats of Kutch
column7: Samma]] tribes.<ref>People of India Gujarat Volume XXI  Part  Two edited by R.B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan & M Azeez Mohideen pages 487-491</ref> The other important Muslim community is the [[Memons (Kathiawar)
column8: Khatiawari Memon]] community, that migrated and resettled beyond Gujarat state during partition of India in 1947.<ref>{{Citation
column14: access-date=2020-02-25}}</ref> Khatiawari memon community is regarded as the wealthiest community in India and Pakistan. Mainly, due to their involvement in international trade and contribution to nations economy. [[Memons (Kathiawar)
column15: Khatiawari memons]] are famous for their humanitarian services and other welfare services under the banner of [https://wmoworld.com/ World Memon Organization]. Khatiawari memons follow are also further divided under various surnames like Adamjee, Adani, Admani, Bagha, Bandukra, Chamadia, Dhedhi, Lakhani, Patel; [[Memons (Kathiawar)
column16: Khatiawari memons]] proudly recall their rich history from their ansestral villages named [[Kutiyana]], [[Bantva]], [[Porbandar]] currently located in modern state of [[Gujarat]], [[India]].

column1: The Gujarat coastline is also home to significant numbers of [[Siddi]], otherwise known as ''Zanji'' or ''Habshi'', descendants of Africans e.g. [http://britishlibrary.typepad.co.uk/asian-and-african/2013/04/ikhlas-khan-the-african-prime-minister-of-bijapur.html Royal Habshis] (Abyssinian aristocracy e.g. [[Sidi Saiyyed Mosque
column2: Siddi Sayyid]]), or [[Bantu peoples]] from Southeast Africa that were brought to the Indian subcontinent as slaves by the Portuguese and Arab merchants.<ref name=\"Prashad\">{{Citation
column3: title=Everybody Was Kung Fu Fighting: Afro-Asian Connections and the Myth of Cultural Purity
column9: quote=... since the captains of the African and Arab vessels bore the title Sidi (from Sayyid, or the lineage of Muhammad), the African settlers on the Indian mainland came to be called Siddis ...}}</ref> Siddis are primarily [[Sufism
column10: Sufi Muslims]], although some are [[Hindu]]s and others [[Roman Catholic]] Christians.<ref name=\"ali1996j\">{{Citation
column11: title=The African dispersal in the Deccan
column17: quote=... Among the Siddi families in Karnataka there are Catholics, Hindus and Muslims ... It was a normal procedure for the Portuguese to baptise African slaves ... After living for generations among Hindus they considered themselves to be Hindus ... The Siddi Hindus owe allegiance to Saudmath ...}}</ref> [[Malik Ambar]], a prominent military figure in Indian history at large, remains a figure of veneration to the Siddis of Gujarat.

column1: There is historical evidence of Arabs and Persians settling along the [[Konkan]]-Gujarat coast as early as the 9th, 8th and perhaps 7th century.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Al-Hind, the making of the Indo-Islamic world
column13: quote=Up to about the tenth century the largest settlement of Arabs and Persian Muslim traders are not found in Malabar however but rather more to the north in coastal towns of the Konkan and Gujarat, where in pre-Islamic times the Persians dominated the trade with the west. Here the main impetus to Muslim settlement came from the merchants of the Persian Gulf and Oman, with a minority from Hadramaut.}}</ref> Arab traders landed at [[Ghogha]] (located just across the narrow Gulf of [[Cambay]] from [[Bharuch]]/[[Surat]]) around the early seventh century and built a masjid there facing [[Jeruselum]].<ref>{{cite book
column23: accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> Thus Gujarat has the oldest mosque in India built between 624-626 C.E. by the Arabs who traded and stayed there. These Arabs and others who settled in [[Bharuch]] and [[Surat]] were sailors, merchants and [[nakhuda]]s, who belonged to various [[South Arabia]]n coastal tribes while others were from the [[Persian Gulf]] and [[Mediterranean]], and large numbers married local women adopting the local Gujarati language and customs over time.<ref>{{cite book
column26: title=The adventures of Ibn Battuta, a Muslim traveler of the fourteenth century
column31: edition=Rev. ed. with a new pref.
column34: quote=Many of these \"foreign merchants\" were transient visitors, men of South Arabian and Persian Gulf ports, who migrated in and out of Cambay with the rhythm of the monsoons. But others were men with Persian and fewer Arab patronyms whose families had settled in the town generations, even centuries earlier, intermarrying with Konkani ethnic origins within Gujarats women, and assimilating everyday customs of the Hindu hinterland}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column37: title=Portuguese trade in Asia under the Habsburgs, 1580-1640
column46: quote=The history of Indian Ocean trade is a succession of alien merchant diasporas establishing themselves and eventually dominating the region. Gujarat's Muslim community, for example, had originated from traders their mosques, and later the very small settlements of merchants from Turkey, Egypt, Persia and Arabia.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column51: title=The South Asian diaspora transnational networks and changing identities
column59: quote=The social world of the Muslim merchants was complex. The heterogeneity of the Muslim merchant community was made up by the trade but much smaller number of settlers originating from various countries,  as well as by those who were peripatetic traders, coming from places like Persia, Egypt and few from Afghanistan.}}</ref>

column1: Over the course of history, a number of famous Arab travelers, scholars, Sufi-saints and geographers who visited India, have described the presence of thriving Arab-Muslim communities scattered along the Konkan-Gujarat coast.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Gujarat built mosques to draw Arab ships
column7: quote=The accounts of Arab travellers like Masudi, Istakhari, Ibn Hauqal and others, who visited Gujarat between the 9th and 12th centuries, amply testify to the settlements of Muslims in Cambay and other cities of Gujarat.}}</ref> Suleiman of Basra who reached [[Thana, Maharashtra
column8: Thana]] in 841 AD, observed that the [[Rashtrakuta]] empire which extended from [[Bharuch]] to Chaul during his time, was on friendly terms with the Arabs, and Balhara kings appointed Arab merchant princes as governors and administrators in their vast kingdom.<ref>{{cite book
column10: title=The shaping of modern Gujarat : plurality, Hindutva, and beyond
column22: title=Humanity : texts and contexts : Christian and Muslim perspectives : a record of the sixth Building Bridges seminar convened by the Archbishop of Canterbury, National University of Singapore, December 2007
column30: quote=Memorials can be found in Gujarat honoring Arab Muslims who martyred themselves fighting against Muslim Turks on behalf of Hindu kingdoms. These same kingdoms endowed mosques on behalf of Arab traders.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column33: title=Parsis in India and the Diaspora
column40: quote=The Chinchani copper plates, datable to the early 10th century,  mention the appointment of Muhammed Sugapita (Sanskrit - 'Madhumati'), a Tajik, as governor of 'Sanyanapattana' (Sanjan port) by the Rashtrakuta king from 878 to 915 AC (Sircar 1962)... This fact is relevant in that it mentions a Muslim administrator controlling the region during the late 9th, and early 10th century... That Sanjan had a large and cosmopolitan population is mentioned in the accounts of travelers as well as the Indian inscriptions and grants mentioned above. While the local tribal populations consisted largely of Kolis and Mahars, the inscriptions list Muslims and Arabs, Panchagaudiya Brahmins, Modha Baniyas and Zoroastrians (Sankalia 1983: 210)}}</ref> [[Ibn Hawqal]], a 10th-century Muslim Arab geographer and chronicler while on his travels observed that mosques flourished in four cities of Gujarat that had Hindu kings, with mosques being found in Cambay, [[Kutch]], Saymur and [[Patan district
column41: Patan]], alluding to an atmosphere where Muslim foreigners were assimilated into the local milieu of medieval Gujarati societies.<ref>{{cite book
column44: title=Al-Hind, the making of the Indo-Islamic world
column55: title=Merchants and rulers in Gujarat : the response to the Portuguese in the sixteenth century
column64: quote=Most of these \"foreign\" Muslims were resident in Gujarat, with their own houses there, and so were in fact subjects of Gujarat, whatever their country of birth, which could be Turkey, Egypt, Arabia or Persia. The heterogeneity of the Muslim population was not confined to merchants, for the sultans made a practice of tempting capable foreigners to Gujarat with handsome salaries, to serve in their armies.}}</ref> His well-known Iranian contemporary [[Estakhri]], the Persian medieval geographer who traveled to Cambay and other regions of Gujarat during the same period, echoed the words spoken by his predecessors alongside his itineraries.<ref>{{cite book
column66: title=Muslim Communities in Gujarat: Preliminary Studies in Their History and Social Organization
column71: accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> [[Al-Masudi]], an Arab historian from [[Baghdad]] who was a descendant of [[Abdullah ibn Masud
column72: Abdullah Ibn Mas'ud]], a companion of [[Muhammad]] traveled to Gujarat in 918 C.E, and bore written witness account that more than 10,000 Arab Muslims from [[Siraf]] (Persia) [[Madha]] in Oman, Hadhramaut in [[Yemen]], [[Basra]], Baghdad, and other cities in the Middle East, had settled in the seaport of Chamoor, a port close to [[Bharuch]].<ref>{{cite web
column80: title=Notes on the history and antiquities of Chaul and Bassein
column88: quote=The Lar, also called Lardesa, mentioned by Masudi, is evidently the territory of Gujarat and the Northern Konkan, embracing Broach, Thana, and Chaul, and which name is given by Ptolemy as Larike...As regards Balhara, whom Masudi mentions as the reigning prince to whom Saimur was tributary, it has long been identified as the name of the dynasty which reigned at Valabhi (Valabhipura) in Gujarat, and according to Soliman, a merchant and one of the greatest travellers of his age, was in his time the chief of all the greatest princes in India, the latter acknowledging his preeminence; while the Arabs themselves were shown great favours and enjoyed great privileges in his dominions.}}</ref>

column1: Despite the medieval conquest of Gujarat by [[Alauddin Khalji]] and its annexation to the [[Delhi Sultanate]] in the 13th century, peaceful Islamic settlements appear to have continued under Hindu rule. Bi-lingual Indian inscriptions from [[Somnath]] in Sanskrit and Arabic, make reference to the Arab and Iranian shipowners who constructed mosques in Gujarat from the grants given to Muslims by the [[Vaghela dynasty

column12: quote=The person responsible for the construction of the mosque was a sailor and shipowner known as Firuz b. Abu Ibrahim from the state of Hormuz, and in the Arabic version the Muslim ruler to whom these sailors gave their allegiance is recorded as Abu Nusrat Mamud b. Ahmad.... Firuz the shipwner is not the only Persian who appears to have been a person of some standing among the Muslim communities of Gujarat. In Bhadresvar one of the tombstones belongs to one Abu'l-faraj b. Ali, from Siraf, at that time one of the most important ports on the Iranian coast of the Persian Gulf. Another inscription found in Cambay, records the construction of a mosque by Ali b. Shapur in 615/1218-19. The name Shapur shows the Iranian origin of this personage. Other epitaphs are to be found in Cambay belonging to Abi'l-mahasin b. Ardeshir al-Ahwi (d.630/1232-3), Sharaf al-din Murtida b. Mohammad al-Istarabadi, and Ali b Salar b. Ali Yazdi... In the inscription of the mosque at Junagadh, Iraj, the name of a southern Iranian city, near Ramhurmuz, or of the ancestor of Abulqasim b. Ali is also an indication of the Iranian origin of our \"chief of the marchants and shipmasters of the town\". }}</ref> Similar epitaphs mention the arrival of pious Muslim nakhudas from [[Hormuz, Fars
column13: Hormuz]] as well as families from [[Bam, Iran
column14: Bam]] residing in Cambay, and from the discovery of tombstones of personages from [[Siraf]], at the time one of the most important ports on the Iranian coast in the Persian Gulf, suggests altogether that the Muslim community of [[Junagadh]] had a strong and established link with [[Iran]] through the commercial sea routes.<ref>{{cite book
column16: first1=Mehrdad Shokoohy with contributions by Manijeh
column19: title=Bhadreśvar ; the oldest Islamic monuments in India
column26: accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> The 19th century ''European Gazetteer'' by George Newenham Wright,  corroborates this cultural exchange through the ages as he points out that the Arab inhabitants of [[Mukalla]], capital city of the [[Hadhramaut]] coastal region in [[Yemen]], were known to intermarry with the Mohammedans of [[Kathiawar]] and those resident from other areas of Gujarat.<ref>{{cite book
column28: title=A New and Comprehensive Gazetteer, Volume 5
column32: quote=The coast of Southern Arabia, was explored in 1833, by Mr. Bird. The people at Mukallah intermarry with the Mohammedans of Katehwar and Gujarat. The sheikh's youngest wife is the daughter of a petty chief in that quarter. The town has rather an imposing appearance as approaching it from the sea.

column1: Arabic sources speak of the warm reception of the significant immigration of [[Hadhrami people
column2: Hadhrami]] ''sāda'' (descendants of [[Muhammed]]) who settled in [[Surat]] during the [[Gujarat Sultanate]]. Prominent and well respected [[Sayyid
column3: Sāda]] who claimed noble descent through [[Abu Bakr al-Aydarus]] (\"Patron Saint of Aden\"),<ref>José-Marie Bel, Théodore Monod, ''Aden: Port mythique du Yémen'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=TURek_n2BrkC&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=aidrus+aden+mosque+saint&source=bl&ots=ONzOZ0--id&sig=r9xheL_PhnPLydaPdgqBd-hVd-c&hl=en&ei=sd7JSZahNJCo6gOWkOC6Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result pg 99]</ref> were held in high esteem among the people and became established as Arab religious leaderships of local Muslims. Intermarriages with Indian Muslim women were highly sought<ref>{{cite book
column6: title=Hadhrami traders, scholars and statesmen in the Indian Ocean : 1750s - 1960s
column14: accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref> which led to a [[creole peoples
column15: creole]] Hadhrami-Indian community to flourish in Gujarat by the 17th century.<ref>{{cite book
column18: title=The graves of Tarim genealogy and mobility across the Indian Ocean

column1: Early 14th-century [[Maghrebi]] adventurer, [[Ibn Batuta]], who visited India with his entourage, recalls in his memoirs about Cambay, one of the great emporia of the Indian Ocean that indeed:<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=The adventures of Ibn Battuta, a Muslim traveler of the fourteenth century

column2: [[Cambay]] is one of the most beautiful cities as regards the artistic architecture of its houses and the construction of its mosques. The reason is that the majority of its inhabitants are foreign merchants, who continually build their beautiful houses and wonderful mosques - an achievement in which they endeavor to surpass each other.}}

column1: In the 17th century, the eminent city of Surat, famous for its cargo export of silk and [[diamonds]] had come on a par with contemporary [[Venice]] and [[Beijing]] which were some of the great mercantile cities of Europe and Asia,<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Modern migrations : Gujarati Indian networks in New York and London
column11: quote=Indeed, Fernand Braudel likened Surat to some of the great mercantile cities of Europe and Asia, such as Venice and Beijing.... Godinho estimated that Surat's population was more than 100,000, but less with some settlements of people from other cities all over from India residing in the city as well as some foreigners frequenting it for business. He even claimed that it surpasses our \"Evora in grandeur\"}}</ref> and earned the distinguished title, ''Bab al-Makkah'' (Gate of Mecca)because it is one of the great places of the subcontinent where ancient Hindus welcomed Islam and it flourished as time went on.<ref>{{cite book
column21: quote=Surat was then the place of embarkation of pilgrims to Mecca; known as Bab al-Makkah or  the Gate of Mecca, it was almost a sacred place for the Muslims of India. More to the point it was the main city for foreign imports, where many merchants had their bases,  and all the European trading companies were established. Its population was more than 100, 000.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column22: title=The journal of Asian studies, Volume 35, Issues 1-2
column25: quote=For a pious emperor, Surat had more than economic and political importance; it was the port from which the hajj (pilgrimage) ships left Mughal India for the Red Sea. The port was variously known as Bab-al-Makkah, the Bab-ul-Hajj, the Dar-al-Hajj, and the Bandar-i-Mubarak.

column1: Mufti Abdur Rahman Ibn Yusuf Mangera of the UK who is a prominent Islamic Scholar once listed as one of the 500 most influential Muslims in the world, Mufti Ismail Ibn Musa Menk, another prominent Islamic Scholar also of Gujarati descent, South African cricketer [[Hashim Amla]], South African Quran - Bible Scholar [[Ahmed Deedat]], Carabbean eschatologist and Islamic scholar [[Imran N. Hosein]], [[Badruddin Tyabji]],<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Making Britain: Discover how South Asians shaped the nation, 1870-1950
column6: quote=Badruddin Tyabji was the son of Cambay merchant, Tyab Ali, and his wife, Ameena, the daughter of a rich mullah, Meher Ali.}}</ref> a Congress president and [[Mohammad Ali Jinnah]], the founding father of Pakistan.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Jinnah didn't know Urdu, was fluent in Gujarati
column11: quote=But Jinnah was fluent in Gujarati. He could read as well as write Gujarati, his mother tongue. Jinnah was a native of Paneli — not far from Gandhiji's birthplace Porbandar. It is often said the issue of Partition boiled down to these two Kathiawadis.}}</ref> Bollywood is represented by [[Asha Parekh]] who is half Gujarati Muslim, [[Farooq Shaikh]], and [[Sanjeeda Sheikh]]. Famous Indian film score composers include [[Salim-Sulaiman]] Merchant who are [[Ismaili]] [[Shia]] and [[Taher Saifuddin]], who was the 51st [[Da'i al-Mutlaq]] of the [[Dawoodi Bohras]], a sect within [[Shia Islam]]. Famous political activists such as [[Ahmed Timol]],<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Ahmed Timol | South African History Online
column16: accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> [[Yusuf Dadoo]], and [[Ahmed Kathrada]] played a leading role in the [[anti-apartheid movement]] of South Africa.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Review of Kathrada, A. M., No Bread for Mandela: Memoirs of Ahmed Kathrada, Prisoner No. 468/64
