column16: trans-title=EZLN rejects the Mayan Train, AMLO's emblematic project
column18: date=Jan 1, 2020}}</ref> and the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
column19: Mexico office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (ONU-DH)]] has criticized the consultation process, saying it fell short of international standards. Giovanna Gasparello of the [[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia
column20: National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH)]] points out that there no studies linking the project and development have been published.<ref>{{cite web
column22: title=Maya Train consultations seen as empty gesture that provided little information
column24: url=https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/maya-train-consultations-seen-as-empty-gesture/}}</ref> 93% of the 100,940 people who voted in the referendum supported the project, but they represent only 2.86% of the 3,526,000 registered voters.<ref name=\"contra\">{{cite web
column26: title=Solo votó el 2.86% del padrón por Tren Maya
column28: trans-title=Only 2.86% of the registered voted for Tren Maya

column1: [[Fuel theft]] from pipelines owned by Pemex, has been a long-term problem in Mexico,<ref name=huachicoleros>{{Cite web
column3: title=Fuel theft increased by 52.6% in Mexico
column6: accessdate=Feb 2, 2019}}</ref> with a loss to the government of between MXN $15 and $20 billion (US$80 to $106 million) every year.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Ante el robo de combustible, ¿Cuál es el papel de Hacienda?
column13: trans-title=With the theft of fuel, What is the role of the Treasury?}}</ref> When President [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] took office in December 2018, he launched a campaign against ''[[huachicolero]]s'' and dispatched close to 5,000 troops from the [[Mexican Armed Forces
column15: Federal Police]] to guard pipelines across Mexico.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=More Than 60 Dead, Dozens Injured In Mexican Pipeline Explosion
column20: accessdate=Feb 2, 2020}}</ref> The plan began on December 21, 2018, and involved closing and monitoring pipelines, particularly in the states of Puebla, Guanajuato, Jalisco, and the State of México. It soon led to fuel shortages in the west and center of the country, despite the dispatch of numerous fuel trucks to supply local gas stations.<ref>{{cite web
column22: title=Robo y desabasto de gasolina en México: claves de una estrategia que ha alarmado a la población
column26: trans-title=Theft and shortage of gasoline in Mexico: keys to a strategy that has alarmed the population
column28: author=Sonia Corona}}</ref> Tragically, it also led to the [[Tlahuelilpan pipeline explosion]] on January 18 that caused 137 deaths. A memorial for the victims was built in 2020, and each family effected was granted MXN $15,000 (US$800) in compensation.<ref>[https://www.elsegundero.com/2020/01/construiran-memorial-de-victimas-de.html A memorial of explosion victims in Tlahuelilpan will be built] {{in lang

column1: Andrés Manuel López Obrador was a leading voice against privatization of [[Pemex]] throughout the 2010s,<ref>[https://mvsnoticias.com/noticias/nacionales/amlo-anuncia-que-morena-va-solo-contra-la-privatizacion-del-petroleo-549/ AMLO announces that Morena will go alone against the privatization of oil]  [https://lopezobrador.org.mx/temas/privatizacion-del-petroleo/ oil privatization]  [https://www.proceso.com.mx/349790/un-gran-golpe-un-atraco-privatizar-el-petroleo-amlo A big blow and a robbery to privatize oil: AMLO] {{in lang
column2: es}} retrieved 15 Feb 2020</ref> and he emphasized that point once elected.<ref>[https://aristeguinoticias.com/2409/mexico/hemos-encontrado-crudo-en-aguas-someras-gobiernos-neoliberales-querian-privatizar-esos-campos-amlo/ We have found oil in shallow waters, neoliberal governments wanted to privatize those fields: AMLO]  [https://politico.mx/minuta-politica/minuta-politica-gobierno-federal/amlo-gente-sin-experiencia-se-les-dieron-contratos-petroleros/ AMLO: people without experience were given oil contracts] {{in lang
column3: es}} retrieved 15 Feb 2020</ref> As president he canceled contracts with private companies.<ref>[https://www.df.cl/noticias/internacional/economia/analisis-del-editor-amlo-le-puso-la-lapida-a-la-privatizacion-petrolera/2020-01-15/141650.html Editor's analysis: AMLO put the tombstone to oil privatization in Mexico] Diario Financiero, 15 Jan 2020, retrieved 15 Feb 2020 {{in lang

column1: In a speech in [[Merida, Yucatan]] in February 2020, Lopez Obrador said that his policies had saved [[Pemex]] from bankruptcy. He promised to review the pensions for retired employees of the [[Comisión Federal de Electricidad
column2: Federal Electricity Commission (CFE)]], inaugurated construction of gas pipelines (''Cuxtal II'' and the ''Central Ciclo Combinado Mérida''), and promised to build thermoelectric plants in Merida and [[Cancun]]. He also reminded his audience about the oil refinery that is being built in Dos Bocas, Tabasco, the first new refinery in forty years.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=\"Ya rescatamos a Pemex del fracaso de la bancarrota\", dice López Obrador
column8: trans-title=\"We have already rescued Pemex from bankruptcy failure,\" says López Obrador

column1: On February 28, 2020, Pemex released figures showing an increase in production and a decrease in debt. They say ''huachicol'' has decreased by 90%.<ref>[https://regeneracion.mx/pemex-huachicol-cae-90-se-producen-100-mil-barriles-diarios-mas/?fbclid=IwAR09MBaSRmW5YXTK4ztwtncnkjotHj2zK-Q-Fm6MV12ei992mLg_fQoeXL0 Pemex: huachicol falls 90%, 100 thousand barrels per day more are produced] {{in lang

61% of the population say that the government of Andrés Manuel López Obrador is acting \"well\" or \"very well\" against corruption, according to the [[Global Corruption Barometer]] 2019, compared to 24% who considered that of [[Enrique Peña Nieto
column2: Enrique Peña Nieto's]] government in 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=10 datos que revelan qué tan grave es la corrupción en México
column6: trans-title=10 facts that reveal how serious corruption is in Mexico
column8: url=https://politica.expansion.mx/mexico/2019/12/09/10-datos-que-revelan-que-tan-grave-es-la-corrupcion-en-mexico}}  [https://www.gob.mx/sfp/es/articulos/historico-salto-de-la-confianza-ciudadana-en-la-lucha-contra-la-corrupcion-con-el-gobierno-de-amlo?idiom=es Histórico salto de la confianza ciudadana en la lucha contra la corrupción con el gobierno de AMLO] Secretaria de la Función Pública, Gobierno de México, 23 Sep 2019</ref> However, Eduardo Bohórquez, director of the watchdog group ''Transparencia Mexicana'' warns of \"hyperpolitization\" of corruption and compares the treatment of [[Rosario Robles]] with that of [[Carlos Lomelí Bolaños]] and their alleged roles in the [[Estafa Maestra]] (Master Scam).<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Hiperpolitización de la lucha contra la corrupción, una tendencia mundial que incluye a México
column12: trans-title=Hyperpolitization of the fight against corruption, a global trend that includes Mexico

column1: As a candidate, Andrés Manuel López Obrador offered to remove the military from the streets; two weeks before taking office he released his ''Plan Nacional de Paz y Seguridad'' (\"National Plan for Peace and Security\"), calling for legalization of some drugs, an eventual disarming of criminal gangs, and the creation of a [[National Guard (Mexico)
column2: National Guard]] under the control of the [[Secretariat of National Defense (Mexico)
column3: Secretariat of National Defense (SEDENA)]].<ref name=bbc_guard>{{cite web
column6: title=AMLO: las críticas al controvertido plan de seguridad en México presentado por López Obrador
column7: trans-title=AMLO: criticisms of the controversial security plan in Mexico presented by López Obrador
column9: url=https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-46270997}}</ref> The National Guard was officially launched in July 2019,<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2019/07/13/741391138/a-look-at-mexicos-new-national-guard A Look At Mexico's New National Guard] By James Fredrick, NPR, 13 July 2019</ref> despite the opposition of groups such as [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref name=bbc_guard />

column1: One part of the plan proposes special laws for transitional justice [[Truth Commission for El Salvador
column2: similar to those found in countries that have been at war]]. Another strategy is to treat drug use as a health problem and to legalize the cultivation and use of marijuana. An [[Amnesty law]] for minor drug offenders continues to be a priority for the [[LXIV Legislature of the Mexican Congress
column5: title=Las 7 prioridades legislativas de AMLO para el próximo periodo de sesiones
column7: trans-title=AMLO's 7 legislative priorities for the next session
column11: url=https://www.unotv.com/noticias/portal/nacional/detalle/las-prioridades-legislativas-amlo-proximo-periodo-sesiones-104561//}}</ref> ''La Unión Nacional de Padres de Familia'' (\"The National Union of Parents of Families\") insists this would be counterproductive.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Presidencia de AMLO en México: 5 puntos clave del Plan Nacional de Paz y Seguridad de López Obrador para combatir la violencia y pacificar el país
column15: trans-title=AMLO Presidency in Mexico: 5 key points of the López Obrador National Peace and Security Plan to combat violence and pacify the country
column20: title=México: la polémica \"pacificación\" que propone López Obrador para terminar con la cruel guerra del narco en su país
column24: trans-title=Mexico: the controversial \"pacification\" proposed by López Obrador to end the cruel war of the narco in his country

column1: Ten months into 2019, the results do not look promising. 28,741 [[List of countries by intentional homicide rate
column2: intentional homicides]] and 833 [[femicide]]s were committed in the first ten months of the year, (average 95 per day) 706 more than in January–October 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Asesinan a un promedio de 95 personas al día en México: 2019 podría ser el año más violento de su historia
column6: trans-title=An average of 95 people a day are killed in Mexico: 2019 could be the most violent year in its history

column1: Among the most notorious cases was the ambush-murder of 13 police officers in [[Michoacán
column2: El Aguaje, Michoacán]] by the [[Jalisco New Generation Cartel]] on October 15, 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Mexico: Army deployed after police killed in ambush
column6: url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-50064542}}</ref> Two days later, on October 17, the police and National Guard botched an attempted arrest and extradition of [[Ovidio Guzmán López]] of the [[Sinaloa Cartel]] in [[Culiacán]]. Heavily armed men attacked various parts of the city, including an apartment complex housing the relatives of military personnel and the local airport, killing fourteen people before Guzmán López was released by the police.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=How the Sinaloa Cartel Bested the Mexican Army
column11: url=https://time.com/5705358/sinaloa-cartel-mexico-culiacan/}} [https://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/preacceso/articulo/default.aspx?urlredirect=https://www.reforma.com/suman-14-muertos-por-balaceras-en-culiacan/ar1796322?__rval=1 Suman 14 muertos por balaceras en Culiacán] By Marcos Vizcarra, Reforma, 21 Oct 2019</ref> AMLO said he supported the release of Guzmán López, saying \"This decision was taken to protect citizens... We do not want deaths. We do not want war.\"<ref>{{cite web
column13: title='We do not want war': Mexico president defends release of El Chapo’s son
column16: url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/oct/18/el-chapo-son-ovidio-guzman-lopez-release-amlo}}</ref> Three weeks after that, three women and six children, members of the [[LeBarón and Langford families massacre
column17: LeBarón family]], were massacred en route to a wedding in Le Barón, [[Galeana, Chihuahua]], 70 miles south of the U.S.-Mexico border.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=3 detained in connection to massacre that left 9 family members dead in Mexico
column21: url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/lebaron-family-massacre-3-detained-mexico-today-2019-12-01/}}</ref> All nine victims were dual [[American immigration to Mexico
column22: Mexican-American citizens]], prompting U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] to threaten to declare Mexican drug cartels \"terrorists\" which would give him the authorization to attack them, violating Mexico's sovereignty.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title=Trump to designate Mexican drug cartels as terrorists
column26: url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-50568812}}</ref> Trump backed off after U.S. Attorney General [[William Barr]] spoke to Lopez Obrador,<ref>{{cite web
column29: title=Trump says he will hold off designating Mexican drug cartels as terrorist groups

column1: [[Femicide]] (Spanish: ''feminicidio''), [[rape]], and other forms of violence against women becomes a source of contention for the government in late [[2019 in Mexico
column3: 2020]]. Several highly publicized murders<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-51469528 Ingrid Escamilla's Feminicide: Indignation in Mexico over the brutal murder of the young woman and the dissemination of photos of her body] {{in lang
column4: es}}  [https://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2020/01/14/alerta-mexicano-culpable-de-abuso-sexual-a-menores-seguira-en-los-legionarios-de-cristo/ Mexican guilty of sexual abuse of minors will remain in the Legionaries of Christ {{in lang
column5: es}}]  [https://netnoticias.mx/juarez/lamentan-muerte-de-isabel-cabanillas-convocan-a-homenaje/ They lament the death of Isabel Cabanillas; summon tribute {{in lang
column6: es}}]  [https://www.radioformula.com.mx/noticias/20190714/hallan-cuerpo-de-nina-de-12-anos-en-atizapan-feminicidas-la-incendiaron/ Body of a 12-year-old girl found in Atizapán; feminicides set her on fire {{in lang
column7: es}}]  [https://www.milenio.com/policia/feminicidio-iztapalapa-hallan-muerta-guadalupe-hernandez-perez Lupita denounced her ex-partner for violence; she appears dead in Edomex {{in lang
column8: es}}] Retrieved 14 Feb 2020</ref> lead to demonstrations in Mexico City and elsewhere, as well as a four-month strike in the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico
column9: UNAM]].<ref>[http://wradio.com.mx/radio/2020/02/10/nacional/1581294604_563593.html Strike at five schools and faculties of the UNAM lifted {{in lang
column10: es}}] Retrieved 14 Feb 2020</ref> Femicides are at an all-time high<ref>[https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/femicide-cases-have-doubled-in-4-years/ Femicide cases have doubled in 4 years; 890 recorded in first 11 months] Mexico News Daily, 27 Dec 2019, Retrieved 14 Feb 2020</ref> and López Obrador seems incapable of addressing women's concerns.<ref>[https://actualidad.rt.com/opinion/cecilia-gonzalez/343438-lopez-obrador-presidente-entiende-feminismo López Obrador, the president who does not understand (and unworthy) feminism] by cecilia gonzalez, RT, 18 Feb 2020</ref> 100,000 women marched across Mexico on March 8, 2020,<ref>[https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mujeres/marchan-m%C3%A1s-de-15-mil-en-monterrey/ar-BB10Wwwk More than 15,000 march in Monterrey] {{in lang
column11: es}} by Caroline Leon, Milenio, 9 Mar 2020  [https://politica.expansion.mx/mexico/2020/03/08/miles-mujeres-marchan-cdmx-consignas-pintas-reclamos-justicia Thousands of women march on CDMX between slogans, graffiti, and claims for justice] {{in lang
column12: es}} Expansion Politica, 8 Mar 2020  [https://www.agendatlaxcala.com/2020/galeria/mujeres-de-tlaxcala-unen-sus-voces-marchan-de-manera-organizada-y-ordenada?fbclid=IwAR3PTyOLGEGA8OfUKG6xfOL1tX-lVZb0czb79wsM3M_vpAeRG_cbduZuQr8 Tlaxcala women unite their voices, march in an organized and orderly manner] Agenda Tlaxcala, 8 Mar 2020</ref> The following day, women went on strike across the country, demanding an end to [[violence against women in Mexico
column13: violence against women]], while closing schools, businesses, and banks.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-51736957 Fury fuels historic women's strike in Mexico] By Will Grant, BBC News, 9 Mar 2020  [https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mexico/hoy-ellas-no-llegaron-as%C3%AD-luce-m%C3%A9xico-por-el-el9nadiesemueve/ar-BB10WyzH \"Today, they did not arrive\": This is how Mexico looks for # El9NadieSeMueve] {{in lang
column14: es}} by Gustavo Álvarez, 24 Horas, 9 Mar 2020  [https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mexico/paro-de-mujeres-paraliza-la-c%c3%a1mara-de-diputados/ar-BB10XzHs Women's strike paralyzes the Chamber of Deputies] by Fernando Damián, Milenio, 9 Mar 2020  [https://www.msn.com/es-mx/video/noticias/cierran-sucursales-bancarias-ante-paro-de-mujeres/vi-BB10X1gh Bank branches closed in response to women's strike] {{in lang
column15: es}} La Jornada, 9 Mar 2020</ref> The [[CONCANACO]] estimates that the strike cost MXN $30 trillion (US$13.5 billion), 15% more than the original estimate.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com.mx/30000-mdp-razones-no-undiasinnosotras/?fbclid=IwAR0RgwxlLcSM0D7q6kZ_RkjpdDWaT3mrvHb2mAQI0IjsXH2QCM0SXheCsHM # UnDíaSinNosotras was reflected in 30,000 million pesos] {{in lang

column1: President Lopez Obrador wants to change the emphasis of the health care system for non-insured individuals from curation to prevention. He promises that obesity will be combatted by a nutrition campaign, not through new taxes.<ref>[https://www.proceso.com.mx/613540/obesidad-se-combatira-con-campana-amlo Obesidad se combatirá con campaña de nutrición no con aumento a impuestos: AMLO] Proceso, Jan 9, 2020 {{in lang
column2: es}}</ref> AMLO pushed for his new health care program, [[Insabi]].<ref>[https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mexico/se-suman-al-insabi-18-gobiernos-estatales-amlo/ar-BBZbihv Se suman al Insabi 18 gobiernos estatales: AMLO] La Jornada, 21 Jan 2020 {{in lang
column3: es}}</ref> The old system, ''Seguro Popular,'' (Popular Insurance) provided medical care through grants to the states, but Insabi is centralized; some procedures are more expensive as a result; the system is not free as many people were led to believe. Medicine was formally purchased through drug distributors, but AMLO cut out the middle-man and bought directly from manufacturers. As transportation costs were not included, this often led to higher prices and shortages. Corruption was common with ‘‘Seguro Popular,’’ but many health providers found themselves without work.<ref name=vox>[https://www.vox.com/2020/3/26/21193823/coronavirus-mexico-andres-manuel-lopez-obrador-health-care Mexico’s coronavirus-skeptical president is setting up his country for a health crisis] By Alex Ward, ''[[Vox (website)

column1: Parents of children with cancer protested the lack of medicine in January 2020.<ref>[https://cnnespanol.cnn.com/video/protesta-padres-menores-cancer-desabasto-medicamentos-amlo-salud-perspectivas-mexico/ Madres de niños con cáncer reclaman a AMLO que termine con la falta medicamentos] Mario Gonzalez, CNN en Español, 24 Jan 2020 {{in lang

The first alerts about the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Mexico]] were announced on January 9, 2020,<ref>[https://www.reporteindigo.com/piensa/el-nuevo-virus-coronavirus-no-representa-un-peligro-para-mexico/ The New Coronavirus Does Not Represent a Danger for Mexico] {{in lang
column2: es}} Reporte de Indigo, 22 Jan 2020, retrieved 14 Mar 2020</ref> but the first three confirmed cases in the country were at the end of February.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Mexico Confirms Its First 2 Coronavirus Cases
column14: title=Van 3 casos confirmados de coronavirus en México
column17: access-date=2020-02-29}}</ref> In March, the [[World Health Organization]] declared that [[COVID-19]] had become a pandemic, but that all of the confirmed cases in Mexico were related to people who had traveled overseas, so it was not considered an emergency. Nonetheless, Mexico began preparing for Phase 2, canceling or postponing massive entertainment events and classes in universities but without instituting travel restrictions.<ref>[https://politica.expansion.mx/mexico/2020/03/13/la-cercania-de-la-fase-2-de-coronavirus-moviliza-a-mexico-y-su-gobierno The proximity of phase 2 of coronavirus mobilizes Mexico and its government] {{in lang
column18: es}} Expansión Politica, 13 Mar 2020</ref> Mexico entered Phase 2 on March 24, 2020, stepping up restrictions by closing movie theaters, bars, nightclubs, museums, and other entertainment centers. The government banned some large gatherings but allowed others to continue. It encouraged social distancing, but AMLO was widely criticized for not practicing it himself. With 60% of the population in the “informal economy” and not protected by sick leave or unemployment insurance, ALMO refused to take strict efforts to close the economy down.<ref name=vox></ref> A poll by ''Gabinete de Comunicación Estratégica'' on March 27, 2020, showed that 68.5% of Mexicans felt the government was not prepared for the health crisis. AMLO's overall approval rating fell to 37.4% from 80% at the time of his inauguration.<ref>[https://www.20minutos.es/noticia/4206691/0/la-popularidad-de-lopez-obrador-cae-a-su-nivel-mas-bajo-por-su-gestion-de-la-crisis-del-coronavirus/ López Obrador's popularity falls to its lowest level for his management of the coronavirus crisis] {{in lang

column1: ===Human rights and freedom of the press===
The [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
column2: Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in Mexico]] condemned the consultation process for construction of the [[Mayan Train
column7: title=ONU critica consulta del Tren Maya: no cumplió con estándares

column4: trans-title=UN criticizes Mayan Train consultation: did not meet standards}}</ref> and in January 2020, a judge in [[Campeche]] issued a temporary injunction against construction of the railway because was approved in a \"simulated consultation.\"<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Otorgan suspensión provisional contra el Tren Maya por \"consulta simulada\"
column8: trans-title=Provisional injunction granted against the Mayan Train for \"simulated consultation\"

column1: Lopez Obrador said on January 29, 2020, that he would oppose any efforts to bring back defamation laws or other efforts to limit [[freedom of the press]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Mexican president promises no return of criminal defamation
column6: url=https://apnews.com/48d5a9be6c525bf8ced1c774a9fd03fc}}</ref> Several changes in the administration of justice are among AMLO's legislative priorities in 2020.<ref name=prioridades />

column1: Although there have been a number of well-publicized efforts to end corruption, such as the resignation of [[Secretariat of Environment and Natural Resources (Mexico)
column2: Secretary of the Environment]] [[Josefa González-Blanco Ortiz-Mena]] and arrest warrants for [[Emilio Lozoya Austin]], former CEO of [[Pemex]], a January 2020 ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' survey of 20,000 citizens shows that Mexico is seen as the second-most corrupt country in the world.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=México es señalado como el segundo país más corrupto del mundo, a pesar del discurso de López Obrador
column6: trans-title=Mexico is designated as the second most corrupt country in the world, despite López Obrador's speech

column1: 93% of the 100,940 people who voted in the referendum on the [[Mayan Train
column2: Maya Train]] supported the project, but they represent only 2.86% of the 3,526,000 registered voters.<ref name=\"contra\"/>

column1: AMLO's security plan has been severely criticized, especially by the [[National Action Party (Mexico)
column2: National Action Party (PAN)]], which filed a complaint with the [[Attorney General of Mexico
column3: Attorney General of Mexico (FGR)]] against López Obrador and the [[Secretariat of Security and Civilian Protection (Mexico)
column4: Secretariat of Security and Civilian Protection]], [[Alfonso Durazo]] after the October 2019 liberation of [[Ovidio Guzmán López]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=PAN presentó denuncia contra AMLO ante la FGR por liberación de Ovidio Guzmán
column9: trans-title=PAN filed a complaint against AMLO before the FGR for the release of Ovidio Guzmán
column10: url=https://www.diariodemexico.com/pan-present%C3%B3-denuncia-contra-amlo-ante-la-fgr-por-liberaci%C3%B3n-de-ovidio-guzm%C3%A1n}}</ref> A few hundred members of the [[Church of the Firstborn (LeBaron family)
column11: LeBaron family]], [[Margarita Zavala]] (wife of former president [[Felipe Calderón]] and [[2018 Mexican general election
column12: unsuccessful candidate for president in 2018]]), and members of PAN marched in Mexico City against Lopez Obrador's security policies on December 1, 2019.<ref>[https://www.infobae.com/america/mexico/2019/12/01/la-familia-lebaron-marko-cortes-y-margarita-zavala-los-tres-frentes-de-la-marcha-antiamlo/ La familia LeBarón, Marko Cortés y Margarita Zavala: los tres frentes de la marcha anti-AMLO] Infobae, 1 Dec 2019</ref>

column1: The president won praise when he opened the archives on police political activities in February 2019, but cutting off public access a year later was not seen in a positive light. The archives were opened in 1998, allowing access to information about the [[Mexican Movement of 1968
column2: 1968 student movement]], but historians worry about a new age of secrecy regarding wrongdoing by [[Miguel Nazar Haro]], [[Jorge Carrillo Olea]], and [[Marcial Maciel]], among others.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=La 4T cierra archivos históricos que antes \"abrió\"
column9: trans-title=The 4T closes historical archives that before were \"opened\"

column1: Representatives from Canada, the United States, and six European countries met in Mexico City in March 2020 to discuss possible negative effects of AMLO's energy policies and his rejection of contracts signed by President Enrique Peña Nieto's government.<ref>[https://www.elsegundero.com/2020/03/canada-eu-y-ue-discuten-preocupaciones.html?fbclid=IwAR3I2dOLQ3y4PhSir2UavsIXc25blhUCEpDEm-OdtJqU9bCfj86BFrENDHs Canada, U.S., and EU discuss concerns over AMLO energy policy] {{in lang

column4: Andrés Manuel López Obrador's (AMLO)]] 2018 campaign promise to do away with privileged abuses that have plagued Mexico in recent years. López Obrador defined the first three transformations as the [[Mexican War of Independence]] (1810-1821), the [[Reform War]] (1858-1861) and the [[Mexican Revolution]] (1910-1917).<ref name=\"que\">{{cite web
column6: title=AMLO presidente: ¿qué es la \"Cuarta Transformación\" que propone Andrés Manuel López Obrador para México?
column10: trans-title=AMLO president: What is the \"Fourth Transformation\" proposed by Andrés Manuel López Obrador for Mexico?

column1: The ''privileged abuses'' Lopez Obrador refers to have to do with high salaries and the luxurious enjoyed by high government officials in a country where half the population lives in poverty. AMLO wants to lower salaries for not only the [[President of Mexico
column3: Cabinet]] members and high-level bureaucrats, justices of the [[Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation
column5: legislators]], and members of independent agencies such as the [[Instituto Nacional Electoral
column6: electoral commission (INE)]] and the [[National Institute of Statistics and Geography
column7: census office (INEGI)]]. In addition to salaries, AMLO mentions luxury vehicles including airplanes and helicopters; expensive private health insurance in addition to the [[Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers
column8: program for government officials (ISSSTE)]]; expense accounts for bodyguards, gasoline, cell phones, and food; and a lack of transparency.<ref name=\"abusivos\">{{cite web
column10: title=México: los \"abusivos\" privilegios en el gobierno que AMLO quiere eliminar con su plan de austeridad
column14: trans-title= Mexico: the \"abusive\" privileges in the government that AMLO wants to eliminate with its austerity plan

column2: Desafuero of Andrés Manuel López Obrador}}

\"Based on what we have achieved, we will seek to undertake a peaceful and orderly transformation, yes, but no less profound than Independence, the Reformation, and the Revolution; we have not made all this effort for mere cosmetic changes, by far, and much less to stay with more of the same.\" — Andrés Manuel López Obrador<ref name=\"cuarta\">{{cite web
column4: title=¿Qué es la cuarta transformación de México que presume AMLO?
column7: trans-title= What is the fourth transformation of Mexico that AMLO presumes?

column1: In a speech given at the end of his [[2018 Mexican general election
column2: campaign for president]], Lopez Obrador spelled out what he means by the Fourth Transformation. He called for a nation of laws wherein nothing is outside the law and no one is above the law. He said the security services would be reformed so that no one was spied upon and religion, ideas, and the right to descent would be respected. AMLO called for a true democracy guaranteeing free elections and prison for electoral fraud. He called for an end of corruption and said the law should apply not only to government officials but also to their families. He said he would reform the [[Constitution of Mexico
column3: Constitution]] so that even the [[Desafuero of Andrés Manuel López Obrador
column4: president could be prosecuted]] for corruption. He called for a [[popular consultation]] process after three years to determine whether the president should be recalled. He insisted that luxuries, such as high salaries for government officials, the presidential airplane and [[Los Pinos
column5: official residence]], bodyguards, and presidential pensions should be cut or eliminated.<ref name=\"cuarta\"/>

column1: AMLO also called for increased attention to the needs of rural communities, revitalization of the construction industry, improvements in the energy sector, pensions for elderly Mexicans, free medicine, and improved education with access for all.<ref name=\"cuarta\"/>

column2: Forbes Mexico]],'' in a September 2018 article said that the Fourth Transformation presents an opportunity for Mexico to move forward as a true democracy. It could not depend on one political party and must move beyond campaign slogans. The authors, Nicola Morfini and Bernardo Sainz Martínez of the [[Instituto Panamericano de Alta Dirección de Empresa
column3: Pan American Institute for High Business Management (IPADE)]], argue that Mexico is at a crossroads: the large margin of victory by ''[[Juntos Haremos Historia]]'' in the 2018 election makes true change possible while also highlighting the possibility of regression. They warn that if decision-making depends exclusively on [[National Regeneration Movement
column4: National Regeneration Movement (Morena)]], the legislature could lose power as it did under the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party
column5: Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI)]]. Given the high poverty levels in the country, the authors suggest that popular democracy may be easily manipulated. They point out that many members of Morena were once members of PRI, which should have a moderating effect on political changes. Finally, they conclude that the future of Mexico depends on everyone.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=López Obrador hacia la cuarta transformación
column13: trans-title= López Obrador towards the fourth transformation

column1: President Lopez Obrador cites three previous periods of transformation in [[history of Mexico]]: the Independence Movement (1810-1821), ''La Reforma'' (1858-1861), and the Mexican Revolution (1910-1917). While all three events involved extreme violence, AMLO insists that the fourth transformation be peaceful.<ref name=\"que\"/><ref name=\"cuarta\"/>
After nearly 300 years of Spanish colonization, on the morning of September 16, 1810, Catholic priest [[Miguel Hidalgo]] called the people of [[Cry of Dolores
column2: Dolores Hidalgo]] to take up arms against their Spanish overlords. Hidalgo took up a banner of the [[Our Lady of Guadalupe
column6: title=Mexico Independence Day: What You Need to Know
column8: accessdate=Jan 22, 2020}}</ref> After a few battles, Hidalgo had gathered a ragtime, disorganized army of 80,000. Hidalgo's army was eventually defeated, and Hidalgo was defrocked and beheaded. His chief collaborator, [[Ignacio Allende]] was also captured and beheaded.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Hidalgo's disciple, Father [[José María Morelos]] took up the struggle, winning 22 battles in nine months. Morelos convened the [[Congress of Chilpancingo]], which declared independence, abolished slavery and the [[caste]] system, and declared Catholicism the state religion. However, Morelos soon was defeated, caught, and executed.<ref name=\"jose\">{{cite web
column3: title=The Independence movement after the death of Miguel Hidalgo

column1: For five years, the insurgents were confined mostly to guerrilla warfare, led by [[Guadalupe Victoria]] near Puebla and [[Vicente Guerrero]] in the mountains of Oaxaca. By 1819, the Spanish viceroy, [[Juan Ruiz de Apodaca, 1st Count of Venadito
column2: Juan Ruiz de Apodaca]] was able to report that the situation was under control.<ref name=\"jose\"/>

column1: Events in Spain led to a weakening of the crown, With Guerrero, he wrote the [[Plan of Iguala]]. Iturbide, Guerrero, and Victoria marched on Mexico City; on September 27, 1821, they defeated the Spanish and Mexico consolidated its independence.<ref name=\"jose\"/>

column2: emperor]] of the new nation, but three years later he was deposed and a [[History of Mexico
column3: republic]] was established with Guadalupe Victoria as its [[List of heads of state of Mexico

column1: ''La Reforma'' (the Reform) was a liberal movement led by [[Benito Juárez]] in 1857 to disestablish the power of the [[Catholic Church in Mexico
column2: Catholic Church]]; establish [[separation of Church and State]]; reduce the power of the military; and establish civil registry of births, marriages, and deaths.<ref name=\"cuarta\"/> Conservatives fought back, leading to the [[War of Reform]] (1858-1861).<ref>{{cite web
column6: url=https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/mexican-reform.htm}}</ref> The liberals won the war, but the war left the country weak, and it was soon followed by the [[Second French Intervention in Mexico
column7: French intervention]], and the establishment of the [[Second Mexican Empire]] with [[Maximilian I of Mexico
column8: Maximilian I]] of Austria as emperor (1864-1867). Juarez and the liberals retook power in 1867.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=The Victorious origins of Cinco de Mayo

column1: After an unsuccessful electoral campaign against President and dictator [[Porfirio Díaz]], on November 20, [[1910 in Mexico
column2: 1910]], [[Francisco I. Madero]] called the Mexican people to arms. In 30 years of rule, Diaz had modernized the country and established a growing economy, but he had done so by granting numerous concessions to British and American investors while denying basic liberties to peasant farmers, miners, and workers. In a bad year, such as 1908–1909, the peasants were reduced to virtual slavery. Within six months of Madero's call to arms, Diaz had resigned and the moderate, middle-class Madero became president.<ref name=\"today\">{{cite web
column5: title=The Mexican Revolution, which began in 1910, was one of the great revolutionary upheavals of the twentieth century.

column1: Madero's moderate reforms were not satisfactory to peasant leaders such as [[Poncho Villa]] in the north and [[Emiliano Zapata]] in the south. Fighting continued, and full warfare broke out. Madero was overthrown by the army and assassinated in early 1913 by [[Victoriano Huerta]], who after thirteen months of harsh rule and fierce fighting was overthrown and executed.<ref name=\"today\"/> There were numerous small bands led by local warlords; eventually, many of them gave up while others united under [[Venustiano Carranza]]. Carranza was able to consolidate his power, and on February 5, 1917, he published the [[Constitution of Mexico
column2: Constitution of 1917]], which many see as the end of the Mexican Revolution. However, fighting continued well into the 1920s.<ref>{{cite web

column1: A year after the election and seven months since he took office, President [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador
column2: López Obrador]] stated that he had fulfilled 78 of the 100 promises he had made, including ending the [[Mexican Drug War
column3: Drug War]]. He also said that the state has stopped being the principal [[Human rights in Mexico
column4: human rights]] violator. He promised to end corruption and admitted that there is still a lot of work to do in questions of the economy, health, and public safety.<ref>{{cite web

column1: President Lopez Obrador announced an MXN $859 billion (US$44 billion) investment plan for 147 infrastructure projects in November 2019. The investments are in highways, railways, ports, and airports as well as investments in telecommunications with most of the capital coming from the private sector. \"This is of the highest importance,\" said Lopez Obrador. \"Participation of the private sector in the country’s growth is necessary.\"<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Mexico Unveils $44 Billion Infrastructure Plan to Boost GDP
column9: title=Mexico to spend $44 billion on infrastructure in first phase of plan

column1: Priority energy projects are the [[Petroleum coke
column3: Tula, Hidalgo]] (MXN $40 billion), the refinery in [[Cadereyta Jiménez, Nuevo León
column4: Cadereyta, Nuevo León]] (MXN $17 billion), and the Pemex Gas Processing Complex to the Mayakán pipeline in [[Macuspana Municipality
column5: Macuspana, Tabasco]] (MXN $1 billion). MXN $219 is destined for the port of [[Topolobampo
column6: Topolobampo, Sinaloa]] and the port in [[Lázaro Cárdenas, Michoacán]] is scheduled to receive MXN $41 million. MXN $14,152 is earmarked for 15 airport improvements, particularly in [[Cancún International Airport
column8: Merida]]. An MXN $86.161 million investment is expected from telecommunications companies.<ref name=62projects>{{cite web
column10: title=Exclusive: The 62 Projects in Andrés Manuel López Obrador's Infrastructure Plan
column13: url=https://www.lapoliticaonline.com/nota/122994-exclusive-the-62-projects-in-andres-manuel-lopez-obradors-infrastructure-plan/}}</ref> Thirty-three projects may begin in 2020 with an investment of MXN $78 billion—other airport investments, railroads, highways, a new hospital for [[Torreón
column14: Torreón, Coahuila]], and other energy projects. Fourteen projects worth MXN $21.356 billion (US$14 million), including the expansion of the [[Cuautitlán]]-Huehuehuetoca train in the [[State of Mexico]], are planned for 2021.<ref name=62projects />

column1: During the 2018 campaign for president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador opposed the construction of the [[Mexico City Texcoco Airport
column2: Mexico City Texcoco Airport (NAIM)]], the principal infrastructure project of President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]]. AMLO complained about costs, corruption, and environmental concerns such as unstable soil on the bed of [[Lake Texcoco]]. He said it would be better to convert the military base of Santa Lucia in [[Zumpango]], State of Mexico, to civilian use.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=AMLO y el Nuevo Aeropuerto viven una relación turbulenta
column8: trans-title=AMLO and the New Airport live a turbulent relationship

column1: Ending the Texcoco project was highly controversial so after winning the election Lopez Obrador decided to submit the proposal to the people of Mexico. A [[popular consultation]] was held across the country, from October 25–28, 2018.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Inicia la consulta ciudadana para decidir el futuro del nuevo aeropuerto
column5: trans-title=Citizen consultation begins to decide the future of the new airport
column7: url=https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/politica/Inicia-la-consulta-ciudadana-para-decidir-el-futuro-del-nuevo-aeropuerto-20181025-0051.html}}</ref> The option to convert the Santa Lucia airport to civilian use and to improve the existing [[Mexico City International Airport
column8: Benito Juárez International Airport]] and [[Toluca International Airport]]s won with 69.95% of the votes: 748,335 for Santa Lucia and 311,132 in favor of Texcoco.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Santa Lucía gana con 748 mil votos; Texcoco: 311 mil 132
column15: trans-title=Saint Lucia wins with 748 thousand votes; Texcoco: 311 thousand 132}}</ref> The NAIM debt ran into MXN $105 billion (US$5.6 billion) when it was paid off in July 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Gobierno ya pagó 105 mil mdp para cancelar NAIM
column20: trans-title=Government has already paid 105 thousand million pesos to cancel NAIM}} [https://www.forbes.com.mx/ya-se-pago-la-deuda-por-cancelacion-del-naim-lopez-obrador/ The debt for cancellation of the NAIM has already been paid: López Obrador] Forbes Mexico, July 27, 2019 {{in lang

column1: Construction of the airport in Zumpango, now called ''General Felipe Ángeles Airport'', began on October 18, 2019. It will have two runways for civilian use and one for military use and is scheduled to open on March 21, 2022.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Green light to new international airport in Mexico
column8: title=Así avanzan las obras del aeropuerto de Santa Lucía
column11: trans-title=This is how the work at the Santa Lucia airport is progressing

column2: Maya Train]] project, first proposed in September 2018, is a 1,525-kilometer (948-mile) railroad that will traverse the [[Yucatán Peninsula]] in the hopes of boosting tourism and boost the economy in one of the most marginalized areas of the country.<ref name=Diaz>{{cite web
column5: title=Mexico wants to run a tourist train through its Mayan heartland — should it?
column7: author=Gabriel Diaz Montemayor}}</ref> The US $6.2-billion project was approved by 92.3% of the voters who participated in the December 14–15, 2019 referendum.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=AMLO's 'Maya Train' wins in landslide in Mexico
column11: url=https://www.france24.com/en/20191216-amlo-s-maya-train-wins-in-landslide-in-mexico}}</ref> Critics worry about environmental effects, threats to local indigenous cultures, and economic benefits that will include communities that do not have one of the 18 stops along the route. Another concern is that construction seems to be rushed in the hope of finishing before the end of AMLO's term in 2024.<ref name=Diaz /> The [[Zapatista Army of National Liberation
column12: Zapatista Army of National Liberation (EZLN)]] promises to resist construction of the train,<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=EZLN rechaza el Tren Maya, proyecto emblema de AMLO
column16: trans-title=EZLN rejects the Mayan Train, AMLO's emblematic project
column18: date=Jan 1, 2020}}</ref> and the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
column19: Mexico office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (ONU-DH)]] has criticized the consultation process, saying it fell short of international standards. Giovanna Gasparello of the [[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia
column20: National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH)]] points out that there no studies linking the project and development have been published.<ref>{{cite web
column22: title=Maya Train consultations seen as empty gesture that provided little information
column24: url=https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/maya-train-consultations-seen-as-empty-gesture/}}</ref> 93% of the 100,940 people who voted in the referendum supported the project, but they represent only 2.86% of the 3,526,000 registered voters.<ref name=\"contra\">{{cite web
column26: title=Solo votó el 2.86% del padrón por Tren Maya
column28: trans-title=Only 2.86% of the registered voted for Tren Maya

column1: [[Fuel theft]] from pipelines owned by Pemex, has been a long-term problem in Mexico,<ref name=huachicoleros>{{Cite web
column3: title=Fuel theft increased by 52.6% in Mexico
column6: accessdate=Feb 2, 2019}}</ref> with a loss to the government of between MXN $15 and $20 billion (US$80 to $106 million) every year.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Ante el robo de combustible, ¿Cuál es el papel de Hacienda?
column13: trans-title=With the theft of fuel, What is the role of the Treasury?}}</ref> When President [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] took office in December 2018, he launched a campaign against ''[[huachicolero]]s'' and dispatched close to 5,000 troops from the [[Mexican Armed Forces
column15: Federal Police]] to guard pipelines across Mexico.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=More Than 60 Dead, Dozens Injured In Mexican Pipeline Explosion
column20: accessdate=Feb 2, 2020}}</ref> The plan began on December 21, 2018, and involved closing and monitoring pipelines, particularly in the states of Puebla, Guanajuato, Jalisco, and the State of México. It soon led to fuel shortages in the west and center of the country, despite the dispatch of numerous fuel trucks to supply local gas stations.<ref>{{cite web
column22: title=Robo y desabasto de gasolina en México: claves de una estrategia que ha alarmado a la población
column26: trans-title=Theft and shortage of gasoline in Mexico: keys to a strategy that has alarmed the population
column28: author=Sonia Corona}}</ref> Tragically, it also led to the [[Tlahuelilpan pipeline explosion]] on January 18 that caused 137 deaths. A memorial for the victims was built in 2020, and each family effected was granted MXN $15,000 (US$800) in compensation.<ref>[https://www.elsegundero.com/2020/01/construiran-memorial-de-victimas-de.html A memorial of explosion victims in Tlahuelilpan will be built] {{in lang

column1: Andrés Manuel López Obrador was a leading voice against privatization of [[Pemex]] throughout the 2010s,<ref>[https://mvsnoticias.com/noticias/nacionales/amlo-anuncia-que-morena-va-solo-contra-la-privatizacion-del-petroleo-549/ AMLO announces that Morena will go alone against the privatization of oil]  [https://lopezobrador.org.mx/temas/privatizacion-del-petroleo/ oil privatization]  [https://www.proceso.com.mx/349790/un-gran-golpe-un-atraco-privatizar-el-petroleo-amlo A big blow and a robbery to privatize oil: AMLO] {{in lang
column2: es}} retrieved 15 Feb 2020</ref> and he emphasized that point once elected.<ref>[https://aristeguinoticias.com/2409/mexico/hemos-encontrado-crudo-en-aguas-someras-gobiernos-neoliberales-querian-privatizar-esos-campos-amlo/ We have found oil in shallow waters, neoliberal governments wanted to privatize those fields: AMLO]  [https://politico.mx/minuta-politica/minuta-politica-gobierno-federal/amlo-gente-sin-experiencia-se-les-dieron-contratos-petroleros/ AMLO: people without experience were given oil contracts] {{in lang
column3: es}} retrieved 15 Feb 2020</ref> As president he canceled contracts with private companies.<ref>[https://www.df.cl/noticias/internacional/economia/analisis-del-editor-amlo-le-puso-la-lapida-a-la-privatizacion-petrolera/2020-01-15/141650.html Editor's analysis: AMLO put the tombstone to oil privatization in Mexico] Diario Financiero, 15 Jan 2020, retrieved 15 Feb 2020 {{in lang

column1: In a speech in [[Merida, Yucatan]] in February 2020, Lopez Obrador said that his policies had saved [[Pemex]] from bankruptcy. He promised to review the pensions for retired employees of the [[Comisión Federal de Electricidad
column2: Federal Electricity Commission (CFE)]], inaugurated construction of gas pipelines (''Cuxtal II'' and the ''Central Ciclo Combinado Mérida''), and promised to build thermoelectric plants in Merida and [[Cancun]]. He also reminded his audience about the oil refinery that is being built in Dos Bocas, Tabasco, the first new refinery in forty years.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=\"Ya rescatamos a Pemex del fracaso de la bancarrota\", dice López Obrador
column8: trans-title=\"We have already rescued Pemex from bankruptcy failure,\" says López Obrador

column1: On February 28, 2020, Pemex released figures showing an increase in production and a decrease in debt. They say ''huachicol'' has decreased by 90%.<ref>[https://regeneracion.mx/pemex-huachicol-cae-90-se-producen-100-mil-barriles-diarios-mas/?fbclid=IwAR09MBaSRmW5YXTK4ztwtncnkjotHj2zK-Q-Fm6MV12ei992mLg_fQoeXL0 Pemex: huachicol falls 90%, 100 thousand barrels per day more are produced] {{in lang

61% of the population say that the government of Andrés Manuel López Obrador is acting \"well\" or \"very well\" against corruption, according to the [[Global Corruption Barometer]] 2019, compared to 24% who considered that of [[Enrique Peña Nieto
column2: Enrique Peña Nieto's]] government in 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=10 datos que revelan qué tan grave es la corrupción en México
column6: trans-title=10 facts that reveal how serious corruption is in Mexico
column8: url=https://politica.expansion.mx/mexico/2019/12/09/10-datos-que-revelan-que-tan-grave-es-la-corrupcion-en-mexico}}  [https://www.gob.mx/sfp/es/articulos/historico-salto-de-la-confianza-ciudadana-en-la-lucha-contra-la-corrupcion-con-el-gobierno-de-amlo?idiom=es Histórico salto de la confianza ciudadana en la lucha contra la corrupción con el gobierno de AMLO] Secretaria de la Función Pública, Gobierno de México, 23 Sep 2019</ref> However, Eduardo Bohórquez, director of the watchdog group ''Transparencia Mexicana'' warns of \"hyperpolitization\" of corruption and compares the treatment of [[Rosario Robles]] with that of [[Carlos Lomelí Bolaños]] and their alleged roles in the [[Estafa Maestra]] (Master Scam).<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Hiperpolitización de la lucha contra la corrupción, una tendencia mundial que incluye a México
column12: trans-title=Hyperpolitization of the fight against corruption, a global trend that includes Mexico

column1: As a candidate, Andrés Manuel López Obrador offered to remove the military from the streets; two weeks before taking office he released his ''Plan Nacional de Paz y Seguridad'' (\"National Plan for Peace and Security\"), calling for legalization of some drugs, an eventual disarming of criminal gangs, and the creation of a [[National Guard (Mexico)
column2: National Guard]] under the control of the [[Secretariat of National Defense (Mexico)
column3: Secretariat of National Defense (SEDENA)]].<ref name=bbc_guard>{{cite web
column6: title=AMLO: las críticas al controvertido plan de seguridad en México presentado por López Obrador
column7: trans-title=AMLO: criticisms of the controversial security plan in Mexico presented by López Obrador
column9: url=https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-46270997}}</ref> The National Guard was officially launched in July 2019,<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2019/07/13/741391138/a-look-at-mexicos-new-national-guard A Look At Mexico's New National Guard] By James Fredrick, NPR, 13 July 2019</ref> despite the opposition of groups such as [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref name=bbc_guard />

column1: One part of the plan proposes special laws for transitional justice [[Truth Commission for El Salvador
column2: similar to those found in countries that have been at war]]. Another strategy is to treat drug use as a health problem and to legalize the cultivation and use of marijuana. An [[Amnesty law]] for minor drug offenders continues to be a priority for the [[LXIV Legislature of the Mexican Congress
column5: title=Las 7 prioridades legislativas de AMLO para el próximo periodo de sesiones
column7: trans-title=AMLO's 7 legislative priorities for the next session
column11: url=https://www.unotv.com/noticias/portal/nacional/detalle/las-prioridades-legislativas-amlo-proximo-periodo-sesiones-104561//}}</ref> ''La Unión Nacional de Padres de Familia'' (\"The National Union of Parents of Families\") insists this would be counterproductive.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Presidencia de AMLO en México: 5 puntos clave del Plan Nacional de Paz y Seguridad de López Obrador para combatir la violencia y pacificar el país
column15: trans-title=AMLO Presidency in Mexico: 5 key points of the López Obrador National Peace and Security Plan to combat violence and pacify the country
column20: title=México: la polémica \"pacificación\" que propone López Obrador para terminar con la cruel guerra del narco en su país
column24: trans-title=Mexico: the controversial \"pacification\" proposed by López Obrador to end the cruel war of the narco in his country

column1: Ten months into 2019, the results do not look promising. 28,741 [[List of countries by intentional homicide rate
column2: intentional homicides]] and 833 [[femicide]]s were committed in the first ten months of the year, (average 95 per day) 706 more than in January–October 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Asesinan a un promedio de 95 personas al día en México: 2019 podría ser el año más violento de su historia
column6: trans-title=An average of 95 people a day are killed in Mexico: 2019 could be the most violent year in its history

column1: Among the most notorious cases was the ambush-murder of 13 police officers in [[Michoacán
column2: El Aguaje, Michoacán]] by the [[Jalisco New Generation Cartel]] on October 15, 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Mexico: Army deployed after police killed in ambush
column6: url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-50064542}}</ref> Two days later, on October 17, the police and National Guard botched an attempted arrest and extradition of [[Ovidio Guzmán López]] of the [[Sinaloa Cartel]] in [[Culiacán]]. Heavily armed men attacked various parts of the city, including an apartment complex housing the relatives of military personnel and the local airport, killing fourteen people before Guzmán López was released by the police.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=How the Sinaloa Cartel Bested the Mexican Army
column11: url=https://time.com/5705358/sinaloa-cartel-mexico-culiacan/}} [https://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/preacceso/articulo/default.aspx?urlredirect=https://www.reforma.com/suman-14-muertos-por-balaceras-en-culiacan/ar1796322?__rval=1 Suman 14 muertos por balaceras en Culiacán] By Marcos Vizcarra, Reforma, 21 Oct 2019</ref> AMLO said he supported the release of Guzmán López, saying \"This decision was taken to protect citizens... We do not want deaths. We do not want war.\"<ref>{{cite web
column13: title='We do not want war': Mexico president defends release of El Chapo’s son
column16: url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/oct/18/el-chapo-son-ovidio-guzman-lopez-release-amlo}}</ref> Three weeks after that, three women and six children, members of the [[LeBarón and Langford families massacre
column17: LeBarón family]], were massacred en route to a wedding in Le Barón, [[Galeana, Chihuahua]], 70 miles south of the U.S.-Mexico border.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=3 detained in connection to massacre that left 9 family members dead in Mexico
column21: url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/lebaron-family-massacre-3-detained-mexico-today-2019-12-01/}}</ref> All nine victims were dual [[American immigration to Mexico
column22: Mexican-American citizens]], prompting U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] to threaten to declare Mexican drug cartels \"terrorists\" which would give him the authorization to attack them, violating Mexico's sovereignty.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title=Trump to designate Mexican drug cartels as terrorists
column26: url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-50568812}}</ref> Trump backed off after U.S. Attorney General [[William Barr]] spoke to Lopez Obrador,<ref>{{cite web
column29: title=Trump says he will hold off designating Mexican drug cartels as terrorist groups

column1: [[Femicide]] (Spanish: ''feminicidio''), [[rape]], and other forms of violence against women becomes a source of contention for the government in late [[2019 in Mexico
column3: 2020]]. Several highly publicized murders<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-51469528 Ingrid Escamilla's Feminicide: Indignation in Mexico over the brutal murder of the young woman and the dissemination of photos of her body] {{in lang
column4: es}}  [https://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2020/01/14/alerta-mexicano-culpable-de-abuso-sexual-a-menores-seguira-en-los-legionarios-de-cristo/ Mexican guilty of sexual abuse of minors will remain in the Legionaries of Christ {{in lang
column5: es}}]  [https://netnoticias.mx/juarez/lamentan-muerte-de-isabel-cabanillas-convocan-a-homenaje/ They lament the death of Isabel Cabanillas; summon tribute {{in lang
column6: es}}]  [https://www.radioformula.com.mx/noticias/20190714/hallan-cuerpo-de-nina-de-12-anos-en-atizapan-feminicidas-la-incendiaron/ Body of a 12-year-old girl found in Atizapán; feminicides set her on fire {{in lang
column7: es}}]  [https://www.milenio.com/policia/feminicidio-iztapalapa-hallan-muerta-guadalupe-hernandez-perez Lupita denounced her ex-partner for violence; she appears dead in Edomex {{in lang
column8: es}}] Retrieved 14 Feb 2020</ref> lead to demonstrations in Mexico City and elsewhere, as well as a four-month strike in the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico
column9: UNAM]].<ref>[http://wradio.com.mx/radio/2020/02/10/nacional/1581294604_563593.html Strike at five schools and faculties of the UNAM lifted {{in lang
column10: es}}] Retrieved 14 Feb 2020</ref> Femicides are at an all-time high<ref>[https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/femicide-cases-have-doubled-in-4-years/ Femicide cases have doubled in 4 years; 890 recorded in first 11 months] Mexico News Daily, 27 Dec 2019, Retrieved 14 Feb 2020</ref> and López Obrador seems incapable of addressing women's concerns.<ref>[https://actualidad.rt.com/opinion/cecilia-gonzalez/343438-lopez-obrador-presidente-entiende-feminismo López Obrador, the president who does not understand (and unworthy) feminism] by cecilia gonzalez, RT, 18 Feb 2020</ref> 100,000 women marched across Mexico on March 8, 2020,<ref>[https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mujeres/marchan-m%C3%A1s-de-15-mil-en-monterrey/ar-BB10Wwwk More than 15,000 march in Monterrey] {{in lang
column11: es}} by Caroline Leon, Milenio, 9 Mar 2020  [https://politica.expansion.mx/mexico/2020/03/08/miles-mujeres-marchan-cdmx-consignas-pintas-reclamos-justicia Thousands of women march on CDMX between slogans, graffiti, and claims for justice] {{in lang
column12: es}} Expansion Politica, 8 Mar 2020  [https://www.agendatlaxcala.com/2020/galeria/mujeres-de-tlaxcala-unen-sus-voces-marchan-de-manera-organizada-y-ordenada?fbclid=IwAR3PTyOLGEGA8OfUKG6xfOL1tX-lVZb0czb79wsM3M_vpAeRG_cbduZuQr8 Tlaxcala women unite their voices, march in an organized and orderly manner] Agenda Tlaxcala, 8 Mar 2020</ref> The following day, women went on strike across the country, demanding an end to [[violence against women in Mexico
column13: violence against women]], while closing schools, businesses, and banks.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-51736957 Fury fuels historic women's strike in Mexico] By Will Grant, BBC News, 9 Mar 2020  [https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mexico/hoy-ellas-no-llegaron-as%C3%AD-luce-m%C3%A9xico-por-el-el9nadiesemueve/ar-BB10WyzH \"Today, they did not arrive\": This is how Mexico looks for # El9NadieSeMueve] {{in lang
column14: es}} by Gustavo Álvarez, 24 Horas, 9 Mar 2020  [https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mexico/paro-de-mujeres-paraliza-la-c%c3%a1mara-de-diputados/ar-BB10XzHs Women's strike paralyzes the Chamber of Deputies] by Fernando Damián, Milenio, 9 Mar 2020  [https://www.msn.com/es-mx/video/noticias/cierran-sucursales-bancarias-ante-paro-de-mujeres/vi-BB10X1gh Bank branches closed in response to women's strike] {{in lang
column15: es}} La Jornada, 9 Mar 2020</ref> The [[CONCANACO]] estimates that the strike cost MXN $30 trillion (US$13.5 billion), 15% more than the original estimate.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com.mx/30000-mdp-razones-no-undiasinnosotras/?fbclid=IwAR0RgwxlLcSM0D7q6kZ_RkjpdDWaT3mrvHb2mAQI0IjsXH2QCM0SXheCsHM # UnDíaSinNosotras was reflected in 30,000 million pesos] {{in lang

column1: President Lopez Obrador wants to change the emphasis of the health care system for non-insured individuals from curation to prevention. He promises that obesity will be combatted by a nutrition campaign, not through new taxes.<ref>[https://www.proceso.com.mx/613540/obesidad-se-combatira-con-campana-amlo Obesidad se combatirá con campaña de nutrición no con aumento a impuestos: AMLO] Proceso, Jan 9, 2020 {{in lang
column2: es}}</ref> AMLO pushed for his new health care program, [[Insabi]].<ref>[https://www.msn.com/es-mx/noticias/mexico/se-suman-al-insabi-18-gobiernos-estatales-amlo/ar-BBZbihv Se suman al Insabi 18 gobiernos estatales: AMLO] La Jornada, 21 Jan 2020 {{in lang
column3: es}}</ref> The old system, ''Seguro Popular,'' (Popular Insurance) provided medical care through grants to the states, but Insabi is centralized; some procedures are more expensive as a result; the system is not free as many people were led to believe. Medicine was formally purchased through drug distributors, but AMLO cut out the middle-man and bought directly from manufacturers. As transportation costs were not included, this often led to higher prices and shortages. Corruption was common with ‘‘Seguro Popular,’’ but many health providers found themselves without work.<ref name=vox>[https://www.vox.com/2020/3/26/21193823/coronavirus-mexico-andres-manuel-lopez-obrador-health-care Mexico’s coronavirus-skeptical president is setting up his country for a health crisis] By Alex Ward, ''[[Vox (website)

column1: Parents of children with cancer protested the lack of medicine in January 2020.<ref>[https://cnnespanol.cnn.com/video/protesta-padres-menores-cancer-desabasto-medicamentos-amlo-salud-perspectivas-mexico/ Madres de niños con cáncer reclaman a AMLO que termine con la falta medicamentos] Mario Gonzalez, CNN en Español, 24 Jan 2020 {{in lang

The first alerts about the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Mexico]] were announced on January 9, 2020,<ref>[https://www.reporteindigo.com/piensa/el-nuevo-virus-coronavirus-no-representa-un-peligro-para-mexico/ The New Coronavirus Does Not Represent a Danger for Mexico] {{in lang
column2: es}} Reporte de Indigo, 22 Jan 2020, retrieved 14 Mar 2020</ref> but the first three confirmed cases in the country were at the end of February.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Mexico Confirms Its First 2 Coronavirus Cases
column14: title=Van 3 casos confirmados de coronavirus en México
column17: access-date=2020-02-29}}</ref> In March, the [[World Health Organization]] declared that [[COVID-19]] had become a pandemic, but that all of the confirmed cases in Mexico were related to people who had traveled overseas, so it was not considered an emergency. Nonetheless, Mexico began preparing for Phase 2, canceling or postponing massive entertainment events and classes in universities but without instituting travel restrictions.<ref>[https://politica.expansion.mx/mexico/2020/03/13/la-cercania-de-la-fase-2-de-coronavirus-moviliza-a-mexico-y-su-gobierno The proximity of phase 2 of coronavirus mobilizes Mexico and its government] {{in lang
column18: es}} Expansión Politica, 13 Mar 2020</ref> Mexico entered Phase 2 on March 24, 2020, stepping up restrictions by closing movie theaters, bars, nightclubs, museums, and other entertainment centers. The government banned some large gatherings but allowed others to continue. It encouraged social distancing, but AMLO was widely criticized for not practicing it himself. With 60% of the population in the “informal economy” and not protected by sick leave or unemployment insurance, ALMO refused to take strict efforts to close the economy down.<ref name=vox></ref> A poll by ''Gabinete de Comunicación Estratégica'' on March 27, 2020, showed that 68.5% of Mexicans felt the government was not prepared for the health crisis. AMLO's overall approval rating fell to 37.4% from 80% at the time of his inauguration.<ref>[https://www.20minutos.es/noticia/4206691/0/la-popularidad-de-lopez-obrador-cae-a-su-nivel-mas-bajo-por-su-gestion-de-la-crisis-del-coronavirus/ López Obrador's popularity falls to its lowest level for his management of the coronavirus crisis] {{in lang

column1: ===Human rights and freedom of the press===
The [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
column2: Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in Mexico]] condemned the consultation process for construction of the [[Mayan Train
column7: title=ONU critica consulta del Tren Maya: no cumplió con estándares

column4: trans-title=UN criticizes Mayan Train consultation: did not meet standards}}</ref> and in January 2020, a judge in [[Campeche]] issued a temporary injunction against construction of the railway because was approved in a \"simulated consultation.\"<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Otorgan suspensión provisional contra el Tren Maya por \"consulta simulada\"
column8: trans-title=Provisional injunction granted against the Mayan Train for \"simulated consultation\"

column1: Lopez Obrador said on January 29, 2020, that he would oppose any efforts to bring back defamation laws or other efforts to limit [[freedom of the press]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Mexican president promises no return of criminal defamation
column6: url=https://apnews.com/48d5a9be6c525bf8ced1c774a9fd03fc}}</ref> Several changes in the administration of justice are among AMLO's legislative priorities in 2020.<ref name=prioridades />

column1: Although there have been a number of well-publicized efforts to end corruption, such as the resignation of [[Secretariat of Environment and Natural Resources (Mexico)
column2: Secretary of the Environment]] [[Josefa González-Blanco Ortiz-Mena]] and arrest warrants for [[Emilio Lozoya Austin]], former CEO of [[Pemex]], a January 2020 ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' survey of 20,000 citizens shows that Mexico is seen as the second-most corrupt country in the world.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=México es señalado como el segundo país más corrupto del mundo, a pesar del discurso de López Obrador
column6: trans-title=Mexico is designated as the second most corrupt country in the world, despite López Obrador's speech

column1: 93% of the 100,940 people who voted in the referendum on the [[Mayan Train
column2: Maya Train]] supported the project, but they represent only 2.86% of the 3,526,000 registered voters.<ref name=\"contra\"/>

column1: AMLO's security plan has been severely criticized, especially by the [[National Action Party (Mexico)
column2: National Action Party (PAN)]], which filed a complaint with the [[Attorney General of Mexico
column3: Attorney General of Mexico (FGR)]] against López Obrador and the [[Secretariat of Security and Civilian Protection (Mexico)
column4: Secretariat of Security and Civilian Protection]], [[Alfonso Durazo]] after the October 2019 liberation of [[Ovidio Guzmán López]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=PAN presentó denuncia contra AMLO ante la FGR por liberación de Ovidio Guzmán
column9: trans-title=PAN filed a complaint against AMLO before the FGR for the release of Ovidio Guzmán
column10: url=https://www.diariodemexico.com/pan-present%C3%B3-denuncia-contra-amlo-ante-la-fgr-por-liberaci%C3%B3n-de-ovidio-guzm%C3%A1n}}</ref> A few hundred members of the [[Church of the Firstborn (LeBaron family)
column11: LeBaron family]], [[Margarita Zavala]] (wife of former president [[Felipe Calderón]] and [[2018 Mexican general election
column12: unsuccessful candidate for president in 2018]]), and members of PAN marched in Mexico City against Lopez Obrador's security policies on December 1, 2019.<ref>[https://www.infobae.com/america/mexico/2019/12/01/la-familia-lebaron-marko-cortes-y-margarita-zavala-los-tres-frentes-de-la-marcha-antiamlo/ La familia LeBarón, Marko Cortés y Margarita Zavala: los tres frentes de la marcha anti-AMLO] Infobae, 1 Dec 2019</ref>

column1: The president won praise when he opened the archives on police political activities in February 2019, but cutting off public access a year later was not seen in a positive light. The archives were opened in 1998, allowing access to information about the [[Mexican Movement of 1968
column2: 1968 student movement]], but historians worry about a new age of secrecy regarding wrongdoing by [[Miguel Nazar Haro]], [[Jorge Carrillo Olea]], and [[Marcial Maciel]], among others.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=La 4T cierra archivos históricos que antes \"abrió\"
column9: trans-title=The 4T closes historical archives that before were \"opened\"

column1: Representatives from Canada, the United States, and six European countries met in Mexico City in March 2020 to discuss possible negative effects of AMLO's energy policies and his rejection of contracts signed by President Enrique Peña Nieto's government.<ref>[https://www.elsegundero.com/2020/03/canada-eu-y-ue-discuten-preocupaciones.html?fbclid=IwAR3I2dOLQ3y4PhSir2UavsIXc25blhUCEpDEm-OdtJqU9bCfj86BFrENDHs Canada, U.S., and EU discuss concerns over AMLO energy policy] {{in lang
