column4: title=Rowan Atkinson is set to become a father for the third time at the age of 62
filename= Rowan Atkinson BBC Radio4 Front Row 8 Jan 2012 b018zvm9.flac
column7: description= from the BBC programme ''Front Row Interviews'', 8 January 2012.<ref>{{Cite episode

column3: CBE}} (born 6 January 1955) is an English actor, comedian and writer. He is best known for his work on the [[sitcom]]s ''[[Blackadder]]'' (1983–1989) and ''[[Mr. Bean]]'' (1990–1995). Atkinson first came to prominence in the BBC's [[sketch comedy]] show ''[[Not the Nine O'Clock News]]'' (1979–1982), receiving the 1981 [[British Academy Television Award for Best Entertainment Performance
column4: BAFTA for Best Entertainment Performance]], and via his participation in ''[[The Secret Policeman's Ball]]'' (1979). His other work includes the James Bond film ''[[Never Say Never Again]]'' (1983), playing a bumbling vicar in ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'' (1994), voicing the [[red-billed hornbill]] [[List of The Lion King characters#Zazu
column5: Zazu]] in ''[[The Lion King]]'' (1994), and playing jewellery salesman Rufus in ''[[Love Actually]]'' (2003). He also featured in the BBC sitcom ''[[The Thin Blue Line (TV series)
column6: The Thin Blue Line]]'' (1995–1996). His work in theatre includes the 2009 [[West End theatre
column7: West End]] revival of the musical ''[[Oliver!]]''.

column1: Atkinson was listed in ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the 50 funniest actors in British comedy in 2007,<ref>[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/review/story/0,,1101477,00.html \"The A-Z of laughter (part one)\", ''The Observer''], 7 December 2003. Retrieved 7 January 2007.</ref> and among the top 50 comedians ever, in a 2005 poll of fellow comedians.<ref>{{cite news
column5: date=2 January 2005}}</ref> Throughout his career he has collaborated with screenwriter [[Richard Curtis]] and composer [[Howard Goodall]], both of whom he met at the [[Oxford University Dramatic Society]] during the 1970s. In addition to his 1981 BAFTA, he received an [[Laurence Olivier Award
column6: Olivier Award]] for his 1981 [[West End theatre]] performance in ''Rowan Atkinson in Revue''. He has also had cinematic success with his performances in the Mr. Bean movie adaptations ''[[Bean (film)
column7: Bean]]'' (1997) and ''[[Mr. Bean's Holiday]]'' (2007), and also in the ''[[Johnny English (film series)
column8: Johnny English]]'' film series (2003–2018). He also appears as the [[Jules Maigret

column1: Atkinson was born in [[Consett]], [[County Durham]], England, on 6 January 1955.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= UPI Almanac for Sunday, Jan. 6, 2019
column10: quote= actor Rowan Atkinson in 1955 (age 64)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web

column1: The youngest of four brothers, his parents were Eric Atkinson, a farmer and [[Board of directors
column2: company director]], and Ella May (née Bainbridge), who married on 29 June 1945.<ref name=\"FamilyDetective\" /> His three older brothers are Paul, who died as an infant; [[Rodney Atkinson
column4: Eurosceptic]] [[economist]] who narrowly lost the [[UK Independence Party]] leadership election in 2000; and Rupert.<ref>

column1: [http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/stories/s374382.htm Foreign Correspondent — 22 July 1997: Interview with Rodney Atkinson] {{Webarchive
column3: date=7 August 2009 }} , [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]. Retrieved 27 January 2007.

column1: </ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/uk_politics/5221824.stm Profile: UK Independence Party], [[BBC News]], 28 July 2006. Retrieved 27 January 2007.</ref>

column5: title=For Rowan Atkinson, comedy can be frightening
column12: url-status=dead}}</ref> and was educated at [[Chorister School, Durham
column13: Durham Choristers School]], a preparatory school.  After receiving top-grades in science [[A levels]],<ref>{{Cite book
column14: title=The True History of the Black Adder: At Last, the Cunning Plan, in All Its Hideous Hilarity
column21: pages=20}}</ref> he secured a place at [[Newcastle University]], where he received a degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering.<ref name=\"comedyguidebio\">{{cite web
column28: archivedate=4 December 2004}}</ref> In 1975, he continued for the degree of MSc in Electrical Engineering at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]], the same college where his father matriculated in 1935,<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=page 6: \"The donation was given in memory of Rowan Atkinson's father, Eric Atkinson, who graduated at Queens in 1935.\"
column35: archivedate=11 July 2011}}</ref> and which made Atkinson an [[Honorary title (academic)
column43: archivedate=18 October 2012}}</ref>  His MSc thesis, published in 1978, considered the application of self-tuning control.<ref>{{Cite book
column44: title=Adaptive Methods for Control System Design
column47: publisher=Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers

column1: Atkinson briefly embarked in doctoral work before devoting his full attention to acting.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: access-date=}}</ref> First winning national attention in [[The Oxford Revue]] at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in August 1976,<ref name=\"comedyguidebio\" /> he had already written and performed sketches for shows in Oxford by the Etceteras — the revue group of the [[Experimental Theatre Club]] (ETC) — and for the [[Oxford University Dramatic Society]] (OUDS), meeting writer [[Richard Curtis]],<ref name=\"comedyguidebio\" /> and composer [[Howard Goodall]], with whom he would continue to collaborate during his career.

column1: Atkinson starred in a series of comedy shows for [[BBC Radio 3]] in 1979 called ''[[The Atkinson People]]''. It consisted of a series of satirical interviews with fictional great men, who were played by Atkinson himself. The series was written by Atkinson and [[Richard Curtis]], and produced by [[Griff Rhys Jones]].<ref name=\"Atkinson people\">\"[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jan/31/tvandradio Pick of the Day]\", ''The Guardian'', 31 January 2007.</ref>
After university, Atkinson did a one-off pilot for [[London Weekend Television]] in 1979 called [[Canned Laughter (sitcom)
column2: ''Canned Laughter'']]. Atkinson then went on to do [[Not the Nine O'Clock News
column3: ''Not the Nine O'Clock News'']] for the [[BBC]], produced by his friend [[John Lloyd (producer)
column4: John Lloyd]]. He featured in the show with [[Pamela Stephenson]], [[Griff Rhys Jones]] and [[Mel Smith]], and was one of the main sketch writers.

column1: The success of ''Not the Nine O'Clock News'' led to him taking the lead role of [[Edmund Blackadder]] in ''[[Blackadder]]''. The first series [[The Black Adder
column2: ''The Black Adder'']] (1983), set in the medieval period, Atkinson co-wrote with [[Richard Curtis]]. After a three-year gap, in part due to budgetary concerns, a second series was broadcast, written by Curtis and [[Ben Elton]]. [[Blackadder II
column3: ''Blackadder II'']] (1986) followed the fortunes of one of the descendants of Atkinson's original character, this time in the [[Elizabethan era]]. The same pattern was repeated in the two more sequels [[Blackadder the Third
column4: ''Blackadder the Third'']] (1987), set in the [[Regency era]], and [[Blackadder Goes Forth
column5: ''Blackadder Goes Forth'']] (1989), set in World War I. The ''Blackadder'' series became one of the most successful of all [[BBC]] situation comedies, spawning television specials including [[Blackadder's Christmas Carol
column7: ''Blackadder: The Cavalier Years'']] (1988), and later [[Blackadder: Back & Forth
column8: ''Blackadder: Back & Forth'']] (1999), which was set at the turn of the Millennium. The final scene of \"Blackadder Goes Forth\" (when Blackadder and his men go \"over the top\" and charge into No-Man's-Land) has been described as \"bold and highly poignant\". Possessing an [[acerbic wit]] and armed with numerous quick put-downs (which are often wasted on those at whom they are directed), in a 2001 [[Channel 4]] poll Edmund Blackadder was ranked third (behind [[Homer Simpson]] from [[The Simpsons
column10: ''Fawlty Towers'']]) on their list of the [[100 Greatest (TV series)
column11: 100 Greatest TV Characters]]. During the 2014 [[centennial of the start of World War I]], Conservative Party politician [[Michael Gove]] and war historian [[Max Hastings]] complained about the so-called \"Blackadder version of history\".

column1: Atkinson in 1997, promoting ''Bean''. In 2014, young adults from abroad named Mr. Bean among a group of people they most associated with British culture.
Atkinson's other creation, the hapless [[Mr. Bean
column2: ''Mr. Bean'']], first appeared on New Year's Day in 1990 in a half-hour special for [[Thames Television]]. The character of Mr. Bean has been likened to a modern-day [[Buster Keaton]], but Atkinson himself has stated that [[Jacques Tati]]'s character [[Monsieur Hulot]] was the main inspiration.

column1: Several sequels to ''Mr. Bean'' appeared on television until 1995, and the character later appeared in a feature film. [[Bean (film)
column2: ''Bean'']] (1997) was directed by Mel Smith, Atkinson's colleague in ''Not the Nine O'Clock News''. A second film, [[Mr. Bean's Holiday
column3: ''Mr. Bean's Holiday'']], was released in 2007. Atkinson portrayed Inspector Raymond Fowler in [[The Thin Blue Line (TV series)
column4: ''The Thin Blue Line'']] (1995–96), a television sitcom written by Ben Elton, which takes place in a police station located in fictitious Gasforth.

column1: Atkinson has fronted campaigns for [[Kronenbourg Brewery
column3: Give Blood]]. Atkinson appeared as a hapless and error-prone espionage agent named Richard Lathum in a long-running series of adverts for [[Barclaycard]], on which character his title role in [[Johnny English
column5: ''Johnny English Reborn'']] and [[Johnny English Strikes Again
column6: ''Johnny English Strikes Again'']] was based. In 1999, he played [[The Doctor (Doctor Who)
column7: the Doctor]] in [[Doctor Who: The Curse of Fatal Death
column8: ''The Curse of Fatal Death'']], a special [[Doctor Who
column9: ''Doctor Who'']] serial produced for the charity telethon [[Comic Relief]]. Atkinson appeared as the ''Star in a Reasonably Priced Car'' on the BBC's [[Top Gear (2002 TV series)
column10: ''Top Gear'']] in July 2011, driving the [[Kia Cee'd]] around the track in 1:42.2. Placing him at the top of the leaderboard, his lap time was significantly quicker than the previous high-profile record holder [[Tom Cruise]], whose time was a 1:44.2.

column1: Atkinson appeared at the [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony]] in London as Mr. Bean in a comedy sketch during a performance of \"[[Chariots of Fire (instrumental)
column2: Chariots of Fire]]\", playing a repeated single note on [[synthesizer]]. He then lapsed into a dream sequence in which he joined the runners from the [[Chariots of Fire
column3: film of the same name]] (about the [[1924 Summer Olympics]]), beating them in their iconic run along West Sands at St. Andrews, by riding in a [[minicab]] and tripping the front runner. Atkinson starred as [[Jules Maigret]] in [[Maigret (2016 TV series)
column4: ''Maigret'']], a series of television films from ITV.

column1: In November 2012, it emerged that Rowan Atkinson intended to retire Mr. Bean. \"The stuff that has been most commercially successful for me — basically quite physical, quite childish — I increasingly feel I'm going to do a lot less of,\" Atkinson told [[The Daily Telegraph
column2: ''The Daily Telegraph'']]'s Review. \"Apart from the fact that your physical ability starts to decline, I also think someone in their 50s being childlike becomes a little sad. You've got to be careful.\" He has also said that the role [[Typecasting (acting)
column3: typecast]] him to a degree. Despite these comments, Atkinson said in 2016 that he would never retire the character of Mr. Bean.

column1: In October 2014, Atkinson also appeared as Mr. Bean in a TV advert for [[Snickers]]. In 2015, he starred alongside [[Ben Miller]] and [[Rebecca Front]] in a sketch for BBC [[Red Nose Day]] in which Mr. Bean attends a funeral.
In 2017, he appeared as Mr. Bean in the Chinese film ''Huan Le Xi Ju Ren''. In October 2018, Atkinson (as Mr. Bean) received [[YouTube Play Buttons
column2: YouTube's Diamond Play Button]] for his channel surpassing 10 million subscribers on the video platform. Among the most-watched channels in the world, in 2017 it had more than 4.5 billion views.

column1: In January 2014, ITV announced a new animated series featuring Mr. Bean with Rowan Atkinson returning to the role. It was expected to be released online as a Web-series later in 2014, as a television broadcast followed shortly after.
On 6 February 2018, Regular Capital announced that there would be a Season 5 of the Animated Mr Bean in 2019 (voiced by Atkinson). The first episode, Teddy's King, aired in February 2019.
Following yet another 3-year hiatus, a fifth season consisting of 26 episodes is scheduled to premiere in 2019 on CITV as well as on [[Turner Broadcasting System
Atkinson's film career began with a supporting part in the \"unofficial\" [[James Bond]] movie [[Never Say Never Again
column2: ''Never Say Never Again'']] (1983) and a leading role in [[Dead on Time (1983 film)
column3: ''Dead on Time'']] (also 1983) with [[Nigel Hawthorne]]. He was in the 1988 Oscar-winning short film [[The Appointments of Dennis Jennings
column4: ''The Appointments of Dennis Jennings'']]. He appeared in Mel Smith's directorial debut [[The Tall Guy
column5: ''The Tall Guy'']] (1989) and appeared alongside [[Anjelica Huston]] and [[Mai Zetterling]] in [[The Witches (1990 film)
column6: ''The Witches'']] (1990), a film adaptation of the [[Roald Dahl]] [[The Witches (novel)
column7: children's novel]]. He played the part of Dexter Hayman in [[Hot Shots! Part Deux
column8: ''Hot Shots! Part Deux'']] (1993), a parody of [[Rambo III

column1: Atkinson gained further recognition with his turn as a verbally bumbling vicar in [[Four Weddings and a Funeral
column2: ''Four Weddings and a Funeral'']] (1994, written and directed by his long time collaborator [[Richard Curtis]]), and featured in [[The Walt Disney Company
column4: ''The Lion King'']] (also 1994) as the voice of Zazu the [[red-billed hornbill]]. He also sang the song “[[I Just Can't Wait to Be King]]” in ''The Lion King''. Atkinson continued to appear in supporting roles in comedies, including [[Rat Race (film)
column6: ''Scooby-Doo'']] (2002), jewellery salesman Rufus in another Richard Curtis British-set romantic comedy, [[Love Actually
column7: ''Love Actually'']] (2003), and the crime comedy [[Keeping Mum
column8: ''Keeping Mum'']] (2005), which also starred [[Kristin Scott Thomas]], [[Maggie Smith]], and [[Patrick Swayze]].

column1: In addition to his supporting roles, Atkinson has also had success as a leading man. His television character Mr. Bean debuted on the big screen with [[Bean (film)
column2: ''Bean'']] (1997) to international success. A sequel, [[Mr. Bean's Holiday
column3: ''Mr. Bean's Holiday'']] (2007), (again inspired to some extent by Jacques Tati in his film ‘Les Vacances de M. Hulot’), also became an international success. He has also starred in the James Bond parody [[Johnny English (film series)

column1: Rowan Atkinson performed live on-stage skits — also appearing with members of [[Monty Python]] — in [[The Secret Policeman's Ball (1979)
column2: ''The Secret Policeman's Ball'']] (1979) in London for [[Amnesty International]]. Atkinson undertook a four-month tour of the UK in 1980. A recording of the stage performance was subsequently released as [[Live in Belfast

column1: In 1984, Atkinson appeared in a [[West End theatre
column2: West End]] version of the comedy play [[The Nerd (play)
column3: ''The Nerd'']] alongside a 10-year-old [[Christian Bale]]. ''The Sneeze and Other Stories'', seven short [[Anton Chekhov]] plays, translated and adapted by [[Michael Frayn]], were performed by Rowan Atkinson, [[Timothy West]] and [[Cheryl Campbell]] at the [[Aldwych Theatre]], London in 1988 and early 1989.

column1: ''Oliver!'' billboard at the West End's [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] in 2009.
In 2009, during the West End revival of the musical ''[[Oliver!]]'' based on [[Charles Dickens]]' novel [[Oliver Twist
column2: ''Oliver Twist'']], Atkinson played the role of [[Fagin]]. His portrayal and singing of Fagin at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] in London gained favourable reviews and he was nominated for an [[Laurence Olivier Award
column3: Olivier Award]] for best actor in a musical or entertainment.

column1: On 28 November 2012, Rowan Atkinson reprised the role of Blackadder at the \"We Are Most Amused\" comedy gala for [[The Prince's Trust]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London. He was joined by Tony Robinson as Baldrick. The sketch involved the first new Blackadder material for 10 years, with Blackadder as CEO of Melchett, Melchett and Darling bank facing an enquiry over the banking crisis.
In February 2013, Atkinson took on the titular role in a 12-week production (directed by [[Richard Eyre]]) of the [[Simon Gray]] play [[Quartermaine's Terms
column2: ''Quartermaine's Terms'']] at [[Wyndham's Theatre]] in London with costars [[Conleth Hill]] ([[Game of Thrones
column3: ''Game of Thrones'']]) and [[Felicity Montagu]] ([[I'm Alan Partridge
column4: ''I'm Alan Partridge'']]). In December 2013, he revived his schoolmaster sketch for Royal Free Hospital's Rocks with Laughter at the Adelphi Theatre. A few days prior, he performed a selection of sketches in a small coffee venue in front of only 30 people.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Best known for his use of [[physical comedy]] in his Mr. Bean persona, Atkinson's other characters rely more on language. Atkinson often plays authority figures (especially priests or vicars) speaking absurd lines with a completely [[deadpan]] delivery.

column2: comic devices]] is over-articulation of the \"B\" sound, such as his pronunciation of \"[[Bob (Blackadder character)
column10: date=23 August 2007}}</ref> and the over-articulation is a technique to overcome problematic consonants.

column1: Atkinson's often visually based style, which has been compared to that of [[Buster Keaton]],<ref name=\"Museum.tv\">{{cite web
column8: access-date=21 June 2011}}</ref> sets him apart from most modern television and film comics, who rely heavily on dialogue, as well as stand-up comedy which is mostly based on monologues. This talent for visual comedy has led to Atkinson being called \"the man with the rubber face\"; comedic reference was made to this in an episode of ''[[Blackadder the Third]]'' (\"[[Sense and Senility]]\"), in which [[Baldrick]] ([[Tony Robinson]]) refers to his master, [[Edmund Blackadder
column9: Mr. E. Blackadder]], as a \"lazy, big-nosed, rubber-faced bastard\".

column1: Atkinson's early comedy influences were the sketch comedy troupe ''[[Beyond the Fringe]]'', made up of [[Peter Cook]], [[Dudley Moore]], [[Jonathan Miller]] and [[Alan Bennett]], major figures of the 1960s British [[satire boom]], and then [[Monty Python]]. Atkinson states, “I remember watching them avidly as students at university.”<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> He continued to be influenced by the work of [[John Cleese]] following his Monty Python days, regarding Cleese as being “a major, major inspiration”, adding, “I think that he and I are quite different in our style and our approach, but certainly it was comedy I liked to watch. He was very physical. Yes, very physical and very angry.”<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> He was also influenced by [[Peter Sellers]], whose characters [[Hrundi Bakshi]] from ''[[The Party (1968 film)
column2: The Party]]'' (1968) and [[Inspector Clouseau]] from ''[[The Pink Panther]]'' films influenced Atkinson's characters Mr. Bean and Johnny English.<ref>{{cite news

column1: On [[Barry Humphries]]' [[Dame Edna Everage]], he states, “I loved that character – again, it's the veneer of respectability disguising suburban prejudice of a really quite vicious and dismissive nature.”<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> Of visual comedians, Atkinson regards [[Charlie Chaplin]], Buster Keaton and [[Harold Lloyd]] as influential.<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> He was also inspired by French comedian [[Jacques Tati]], stating, “''[[Mr. Hulot's Holiday]]'' I remember seeing when I was 17 – that was a major inspiration. He opened a window to a world that I'd never looked out on before, and I thought, \"God, that's interesting,\" how a comic situation can be developed as purely visual and yet it's not under-cranked, it's not speeded-up, it's more deliberate; it takes its time. And I enjoyed that.”<ref name=\"LA Times\">{{cite news
column2: title = Before and after 'Bean': A talk with Rowan Atkinson, continued

column5: Rowan Atkinson at the ''[[Mr. Bean's Holiday]]'' premiere at [[Leicester Square]] in London (2007)]]

column1: In March 2001, while Atkinson was on a holiday trip to [[Kenya]], the pilot of his private plane [[Syncope (medicine)
column2: fainted]]. Atkinson managed to maintain the plane in the air until the pilot recovered and was able to land the plane at [[Nairobi]]'s [[Wilson Airport]].<ref>{{cite news

column1: Rowan Atkinson married Sunetra Sastry in February 1990. They have two children, Ben and Lily.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Rowan Atkinson: Mr Bean star known for satire and love of fast cars
column9: date=5 August 2011}}</ref> The couple first met in the late 1980s, when she was working as a makeup artist with the [[BBC]].<ref>{{cite news
column15: separated]] in 2014 and were [[divorce]]d on 10 November 2015.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Rowan Atkinson divorced in 65 seconds on grounds of his 'unreasonable behaviour'
column20: access-date=11 November 2015}}</ref> Atkinson has been in a relationship with comedian [[Louise Ford]] since 2014; she gave birth to Atkinson's third child in December 2017.<ref name=\"duncan1\"/>

column1: In June 2005, Atkinson led a coalition of the United Kingdom's most prominent actors and writers, including [[Nicholas Hytner]], [[Stephen Fry]], and [[Ian McEwan]], to the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom
column2: British Parliament]] in an attempt to force a review of the controversial [[Racial and Religious Hatred Act 2006
column3: Racial and Religious Hatred Bill]], which they felt would give overwhelming power to religious groups to impose censorship on the arts.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Rowan Atkinson leads crusade against religious hatred Bill

column2: homophobic]] speech legislation, saying that the [[House of Lords]] must vote against a government attempt to remove a free speech clause in an anti-gay hate law.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Rowan Atkinson attacks gay hate law
column12: url-status=dead}}</ref> Atkinson opposed the [[Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005]] to outlaw inciting religious hatred, arguing that, \"freedom to criticise ideas — any ideas even if they are sincerely held beliefs — is one of the fundamental freedoms of society. And the law which attempts to say you can criticise or ridicule ideas as long as they are not religious ideas is a very peculiar law indeed.\"<ref>{{cite news

column1: In October 2012, he voiced his support for the [[Hate speech laws in the United Kingdom#Reform Section 5 campaign
column4: title=Rowan Atkinson: we must be allowed to insult each other
column8: location=London}}</ref> which aims to reform or repeal Section 5 of the [[Public Order Act 1986]], particularly its statement that an [[Harassment, alarm or distress
column9: insult]] can be grounds for arrest and punishment. It is a reaction to several recent high-profile arrests, which Atkinson sees as a restriction of freedom of expression.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Rowan Atkinson's address to the Reform Section 5 parliamentary reception
column14: access-date=21 October 2012}}</ref> In February 2014 Parliament passed a redaction of the [[statute]] which removed the word insulting following pressure from citizens.<ref>The [[Crime and Courts Act 2013]], [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2013/22/section/57 section 57(2)]</ref><ref>SI 2013/2981, [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2013/2981/article/3/made art 3]</ref>

column2: lorry]] [[Driving licence in the United Kingdom
column3: driving licence]], gained in 1981, because lorries held a fascination for him, and to ensure employment as a young actor. He has also used this skill when filming comedy material. In 1991, he starred in the self-penned ''The Driven Man'', a series of sketches featuring Atkinson driving around London trying to solve his obsession with cars, and discussing it with taxi drivers, policemen, used-car salesmen and psychotherapists.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Rowan Atkinson: The Driven Man — Trailer — Cast — Showtimes
column9: date=7 February 2005}}</ref> A lover of and participant in car racing, he appeared as racing driver [[Tim Birkin
column10: Henry Birkin]] in the television play ''Full Throttle'' in 1995.

column4: Atkinson racing in a [[Jaguar Mark VII]] M at the [[Goodwood Revival]] motor racing festival in England in 2009]]

column1: Atkinson has raced in other cars, including a [[Renault 5 GT Turbo]] for two seasons for its [[Renault Clio Cup
column2: one make series]]. From 1997 to 2015, he owned a rare [[McLaren F1]], which was involved in an accident in Cabus, near [[Garstang]], Lancashire, with an [[Austin Metro]] in October 1999.<ref>{{cite news
column6: date=27 October 1999}}</ref> It was damaged again in a serious crash in August 2011 when it caught fire after Atkinson reportedly lost control and hit a tree.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Mr Bean and Blackadder star Rowan Atkinson in hospital after McLaren F1 supercar crash
column15: title= Update: TV star Rowan Atkinson in hospital following Cambridgeshire crash
column16: work= Evening Star}}</ref> That accident caused significant damage to the vehicle, taking over a year to be repaired and leading to the largest insurance payout in Britain, at £910,000.<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Rowan Atkinson crash forces insurers to pay out record £910,000 to repair supercar
column24: location=London}}</ref> He has previously owned a [[Honda NSX]],<ref name=tgs16>Top Gear Series 17, episode 4</ref> an [[Audi A8]],<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=The cars of the stars: Rowan Atkinson
column28: access-date=30 April 2014}}</ref> a [[Škoda Superb]], and a [[Honda Civic Hybrid]].<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web

column2: Conservative Party]] politician [[Alan Clark]], a devotee of classic motor cars, recorded in his published ''[[Alan Clark Diaries
column3: Diaries]]'' a chance meeting with a man he later realized was Atkinson while driving through [[Oxfordshire]] in May 1984: \"Just after leaving the motorway at Thame I noticed a dark red [[Aston Martin DBS
column4: DBS V8]] Aston Martin on the slip road with the bonnet up, a man unhappily bending over it. I told Jane to pull in and walked back. A DV8 in trouble is always good for a gloat.\" Clark writes that he gave Atkinson a lift in his [[List of Rolls-Royce motor cars
column5: Rolls-Royce]] to the nearest telephone box, but was disappointed in his bland reaction to being recognised, noting that: \"he didn't sparkle, was rather disappointing and [[wikt:chétif

column1: In July 2001, Atkinson crashed an [[Aston Martin V8 Zagato]] at an enthusiasts' meeting, but walked away unhurt. This was while he was competing in the ''[[Aston Martin Owners Club]]'' event, at the [[Croft Circuit

One car Atkinson has said he will not own is a [[Porsche]]: \"I have a problem with Porsches. They're wonderful cars, but I know I could never live with one. Somehow, the typical Porsche people — and I wish them no ill — are not, I feel, my kind of people.\"<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=\"awardref\">{{cite web
In July 2011, Atkinson appeared as the \"[[Star in a Reasonably Priced Car]]\" on ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)
column2: Top Gear]]'', driving the Kia Cee'd around the track in 1:42.2, which at the time granted him first place on the leaderboard, with only [[Matt LeBlanc]] having set a faster time in the Cee'd.<ref name=\"tgs16\" />

column3: CBE}} (born 6 January 1955) is an English actor, comedian and writer. He is best known for his work on the [[sitcom]]s ''[[Blackadder]]'' (1983–1989) and ''[[Mr. Bean]]'' (1990–1995). Atkinson first came to prominence in the BBC's [[sketch comedy]] show ''[[Not the Nine O'Clock News]]'' (1979–1982), receiving the 1981 [[British Academy Television Award for Best Entertainment Performance
column4: BAFTA for Best Entertainment Performance]], and via his participation in ''[[The Secret Policeman's Ball]]'' (1979). His other work includes the James Bond film ''[[Never Say Never Again]]'' (1983), playing a bumbling vicar in ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'' (1994), voicing the [[red-billed hornbill]] [[List of The Lion King characters#Zazu
column5: Zazu]] in ''[[The Lion King]]'' (1994), and playing jewellery salesman Rufus in ''[[Love Actually]]'' (2003). He also featured in the BBC sitcom ''[[The Thin Blue Line (TV series)
column6: The Thin Blue Line]]'' (1995–1996). His work in theatre includes the 2009 [[West End theatre
column7: West End]] revival of the musical ''[[Oliver!]]''.

column1: Atkinson was listed in ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the 50 funniest actors in British comedy in 2007,<ref>[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/review/story/0,,1101477,00.html \"The A-Z of laughter (part one)\", ''The Observer''], 7 December 2003. Retrieved 7 January 2007.</ref> and among the top 50 comedians ever, in a 2005 poll of fellow comedians.<ref>{{cite news
column5: date=2 January 2005}}</ref> Throughout his career he has collaborated with screenwriter [[Richard Curtis]] and composer [[Howard Goodall]], both of whom he met at the [[Oxford University Dramatic Society]] during the 1970s. In addition to his 1981 BAFTA, he received an [[Laurence Olivier Award
column6: Olivier Award]] for his 1981 [[West End theatre]] performance in ''Rowan Atkinson in Revue''. He has also had cinematic success with his performances in the Mr. Bean movie adaptations ''[[Bean (film)
column7: Bean]]'' (1997) and ''[[Mr. Bean's Holiday]]'' (2007), and also in the ''[[Johnny English (film series)
column8: Johnny English]]'' film series (2003–2018). He also appears as the [[Jules Maigret

column1: Atkinson was born in [[Consett]], [[County Durham]], England, on 6 January 1955.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= UPI Almanac for Sunday, Jan. 6, 2019
column10: quote= actor Rowan Atkinson in 1955 (age 64)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web

column1: The youngest of four brothers, his parents were Eric Atkinson, a farmer and [[Board of directors
column2: company director]], and Ella May (née Bainbridge), who married on 29 June 1945.<ref name=\"FamilyDetective\" /> His three older brothers are Paul, who died as an infant; [[Rodney Atkinson
column4: Eurosceptic]] [[economist]] who narrowly lost the [[UK Independence Party]] leadership election in 2000; and Rupert.<ref>

column1: [http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/stories/s374382.htm Foreign Correspondent — 22 July 1997: Interview with Rodney Atkinson] {{Webarchive
column3: date=7 August 2009 }} , [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]. Retrieved 27 January 2007.

column1: </ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/uk_politics/5221824.stm Profile: UK Independence Party], [[BBC News]], 28 July 2006. Retrieved 27 January 2007.</ref>

column5: title=For Rowan Atkinson, comedy can be frightening
column12: url-status=dead}}</ref> and was educated at [[Chorister School, Durham
column13: Durham Choristers School]], a preparatory school.  After receiving top-grades in science [[A levels]],<ref>{{Cite book
column14: title=The True History of the Black Adder: At Last, the Cunning Plan, in All Its Hideous Hilarity
column21: pages=20}}</ref> he secured a place at [[Newcastle University]], where he received a degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering.<ref name=\"comedyguidebio\">{{cite web
column28: archivedate=4 December 2004}}</ref> In 1975, he continued for the degree of MSc in Electrical Engineering at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]], the same college where his father matriculated in 1935,<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=page 6: \"The donation was given in memory of Rowan Atkinson's father, Eric Atkinson, who graduated at Queens in 1935.\"
column35: archivedate=11 July 2011}}</ref> and which made Atkinson an [[Honorary title (academic)
column43: archivedate=18 October 2012}}</ref>  His MSc thesis, published in 1978, considered the application of self-tuning control.<ref>{{Cite book
column44: title=Adaptive Methods for Control System Design
column47: publisher=Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers

column1: Atkinson briefly embarked in doctoral work before devoting his full attention to acting.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: access-date=}}</ref> First winning national attention in [[The Oxford Revue]] at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in August 1976,<ref name=\"comedyguidebio\" /> he had already written and performed sketches for shows in Oxford by the Etceteras — the revue group of the [[Experimental Theatre Club]] (ETC) — and for the [[Oxford University Dramatic Society]] (OUDS), meeting writer [[Richard Curtis]],<ref name=\"comedyguidebio\" /> and composer [[Howard Goodall]], with whom he would continue to collaborate during his career.

column1: Atkinson starred in a series of comedy shows for [[BBC Radio 3]] in 1979 called ''[[The Atkinson People]]''. It consisted of a series of satirical interviews with fictional great men, who were played by Atkinson himself. The series was written by Atkinson and [[Richard Curtis]], and produced by [[Griff Rhys Jones]].<ref name=\"Atkinson people\">\"[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jan/31/tvandradio Pick of the Day]\", ''The Guardian'', 31 January 2007.</ref>
After university, Atkinson did a one-off pilot for [[London Weekend Television]] in 1979 called ''[[Canned Laughter (sitcom)
column2: Canned Laughter]]''. Atkinson then went on to do ''[[Not the Nine O'Clock News]]'' for the [[BBC]], produced by his friend [[John Lloyd (producer)
column3: John Lloyd]]. He featured in the show with [[Pamela Stephenson]], [[Griff Rhys Jones]] and [[Mel Smith]], and was one of the main sketch writers.

column1: The success of ''Not the Nine O'Clock News'' led to him taking the lead role of [[Edmund Blackadder]] in ''[[Blackadder]]''. The first series ''[[The Black Adder]]'' (1983), set in medieval period, Atkinson co-wrote with [[Richard Curtis]]. After a three-year gap, in part due to budgetary concerns, a second series was broadcast, written by Curtis and [[Ben Elton]]. ''[[Blackadder II]]'' (1986) followed the fortunes of one of the descendants of Atkinson's original character, this time in the [[Elizabethan era]]. The same pattern was repeated in the two more sequels ''[[Blackadder the Third]]'' (1987), set in the [[Regency era]], and ''[[Blackadder Goes Forth]]'' (1989), set in World War I. The ''Blackadder'' series became one of the most successful of all [[BBC]] situation comedies, spawning television specials including ''[[Blackadder's Christmas Carol]]'' (1988), ''[[Blackadder: The Cavalier Years]]'' (1988), and later ''[[Blackadder: Back & Forth]]'' (1999), which was set at the turn of the Millennium. The final scene of \"Blackadder Goes Forth\" (when Blackadder and his men go \"over the top\" and charge into No-Man's-Land) has been described as \"bold and highly poignant\".<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Possessing an [[acerbic wit]] and armed with numerous quick put-downs (which are often wasted on those at whom they are directed), in a 2001 [[Channel 4]] poll Edmund Blackadder was ranked third (behind [[Homer Simpson]] from ''[[The Simpsons]]'' and [[Basil Fawlty]] from ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'') on their list of the [[100 Greatest (TV series)
column18: accessdate=13 May 2019}}</ref> During the 2014 [[centennial of the start of World War I]], Conservative Party politician [[Michael Gove]] and war historian [[Max Hastings]] complained about the so-called \"Blackadder version of history\".<ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=Is Blackadder bad for First World War history?
column23: title=BBC News Blackadder star Sir Tony Robinson in Michael Gove WW1 row
column27: title=RUSI — Dealing With the Blackadder View of the First World War: The Need for an Inclusive, Bi-Partisan Centenary

column4: Atkinson in 1997, promoting ''Bean''. In 2014, young adults from abroad named Mr. Bean among a group of people they most associated with British culture.<ref>{{cite news

column1: Atkinson's other creation, the hapless ''[[Mr. Bean]]'', first appeared on New Year's Day in 1990 in a half-hour special for [[Thames Television]]. The character of Mr. Bean has been likened to a modern-day [[Buster Keaton]],<ref name=\"Museum.tv\">{{cite web
column8: url-status=dead  }}</ref> but Atkinson himself has stated that [[Jacques Tati]]'s character [[Monsieur Hulot]] was the main inspiration.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-mr-bean-rowan-atkinson-20150326-column.html Los Angeles Times, March 27, 2015: ''Before and after 'Bean': A talk with Rowan Atkinson, continued''] Linked 22 December 2016</ref>

column1: Several sequels to ''Mr. Bean'' appeared on television until 1995, and the character later appeared in a feature film. ''[[Bean (film)
column2: Bean]]'' (1997) was directed by Mel Smith, Atkinson's colleague in ''Not the Nine O'Clock News''. A second film, ''[[Mr. Bean's Holiday]]'', was released in 2007. Atkinson portrayed Inspector Raymond Fowler in ''[[The Thin Blue Line (TV series)
column3: The Thin Blue Line]]'' (1995–96), a television sitcom written by Ben Elton, which takes place in a police station located in fictitious Gasforth.

column1: Atkinson has fronted campaigns for [[Kronenbourg Brewery
column2: Kronenbourg]],<ref name=\"Rowan Atkinson in Kronenbourg commercial\">{{cite web
column11: Give Blood]]. Atkinson appeared as a hapless and error-prone espionage agent named Richard Lathum in a long-running series of adverts for [[Barclaycard]], on which character his title role in ''[[Johnny English]]'', ''[[Johnny English Reborn]]'' and ''[[Johnny English Strikes Again]]'' was based. In 1999, he played [[The Doctor (Doctor Who)
column12: the Doctor]] in ''[[Doctor Who: The Curse of Fatal Death
column13: The Curse of Fatal Death]]'', a special ''[[Doctor Who]]'' serial produced for the charity telethon [[Comic Relief]].<ref>{{cite journal
column16: title=DWM Archive Extra: The Curse of Fatal Death
column24: access-date= }}</ref> Atkinson appeared as the ''Star in a Reasonably Priced Car'' on the BBC's ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)
column25: Top Gear]]'' in July 2011, driving the [[Kia Cee'd]] around the track in 1:42.2. Placing him at the top of the leaderboard, his lap time was significantly quicker than the previous high-profile record holder [[Tom Cruise]], whose time was a 1:44.2.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=Mr Bean blitzes Top Gear track

column1: Atkinson appeared at the [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony]] in London as Mr. Bean in a comedy sketch during a performance of \"[[Chariots of Fire (instrumental)
column2: Chariots of Fire]]\", playing a repeated single note on [[synthesizer]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Mr. Bean's Hilarious 'Chariots of Fire' Skit at Olympics
column7: access-date=27 July 2012}}</ref> He then lapsed into a dream sequence in which he joined the runners from the [[Chariots of Fire
column8: film of the same name]] (about the [[1924 Summer Olympics]]), beating them in their iconic run along West Sands at St. Andrews, by riding in a [[minicab]] and tripping the front runner.<ref>{{cite news
column13: access-date=28 July 2012}}</ref> Atkinson starred as [[Jules Maigret]] in ''[[Maigret (2016 TV series)
column14: Maigret]]'', a series of television films from ITV.<ref>[https://www.itv.com/presscentre/press-releases/rowan-atkinson-starts-filming-itv-drama-maigret Rowan Atkinson starts filming ITV drama Maigret], ITV, 8 September 2015</ref>

column1: In November 2012, it emerged that Rowan Atkinson intended to retire Mr. Bean. \"The stuff that has been most commercially successful for me — basically quite physical, quite childish — I increasingly feel I'm going to do a lot less of,\" Atkinson told ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''{{'}}s Review. \"Apart from the fact that your physical ability starts to decline, I also think someone in their 50s being childlike becomes a little sad. You've got to be careful.\"<ref>Victoria Ward [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/9684184/Rowan-Atkinson-suggests-end-is-in-sight-for-Mr-Bean.html \"Rowan Atkinson suggests end is in sight for Mr Bean\"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 17 November 2012</ref> He has also said that the role [[Typecasting (acting)
column2: typecast]] him to a degree.<ref>{{cite news
column9: location=London}}</ref> Despite these comments, Atkinson said in 2016 that he would never retire the character of Mr. Bean.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Mr Bean: Rowan Atkinson will never \"retire\" from playing the character

column1: In October 2014, Atkinson also appeared as Mr. Bean in a TV advert for [[Snickers]]. In 2015, he starred alongside [[Ben Miller]] and [[Rebecca Front]] in a sketch for BBC [[Red Nose Day]] in which Mr. Bean attends a funeral.
In 2017, he appeared as Mr. Bean in the Chinese film ''Huan Le Xi Ju Ren''.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Rowan Atkinson reprises Mr Bean role for Chinese film Top Funny Comedian: The Movie
column8: access-date=30 March 2017}}</ref> In October 2018, Atkinson (as Mr. Bean) received [[YouTube Play Buttons
column9: YouTube's Diamond Play Button]] for his channel surpassing 10 million subscribers on the video platform. Among the most-watched channels in the world, in 2017 it had more than 4.5 billion views.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Mr Bean now has over 10 million YouTube subscribers

column1: In January 2014, ITV announced a new animated series featuring Mr. Bean with Rowan Atkinson returning to the role. It was expected to be released online as a Web-series later in 2014, as a television broadcast followed shortly after.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Rowan Atkinson working on new animated Mr. Bean series

column1: On 6 February 2018, Regular Capital announced that there would be a Season 5 of the Animated Mr Bean in 2019 (voiced by Atkinson). The first episode, Teddy's King, aired in February 2019.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Rowan Atkinson voicing the himself on the animated Mr. Bean series

column1: Following yet another 3-year hiatus, a fifth season consisting of 26 episodes is scheduled to premiere in 2019 on CITV as well as on [[Turner Broadcasting System
column5: title=Mr Bean toon to return next year
column10: title=Happy New Year 2019: Cartoon Network Year 2018 In Review

column1: Atkinson's film career began with a supporting part in the \"unofficial\" [[James Bond]] movie ''[[Never Say Never Again]]'' (1983) and a leading role in ''[[Dead on Time (1983 film)
column2: Dead on Time]]'' (also 1983) with [[Nigel Hawthorne]]. He was in the 1988 Oscar-winning short film ''[[The Appointments of Dennis Jennings]]''. He appeared in Mel Smith's directorial debut ''[[The Tall Guy]]'' (1989) and appeared alongside [[Anjelica Huston]] and [[Mai Zetterling]] in ''[[The Witches (1990 film)
column3: The Witches]]'' (1990), a film adaptation of the [[Roald Dahl]] [[The Witches (novel)
column4: children's novel]]. He played the part of Dexter Hayman in ''[[Hot Shots! Part Deux]]'' (1993), a parody of ''[[Rambo III]]'', starring [[Charlie Sheen]].

column1: Atkinson gained further recognition with his turn as a verbally bumbling vicar in ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'' (1994, written and directed by his long time collaborator [[Richard Curtis]]), and featured in [[The Walt Disney Company
column2: Disney's]] ''[[The Lion King]]'' (also 1994) as the voice of Zazu the [[red-billed hornbill]]. He also sang the song “[[I Just Can't Wait to Be King]]” in ''The Lion King''. Atkinson continued to appear in supporting roles in comedies, including ''[[Rat Race (film)
column4: Scooby-Doo]]'' (2002), jewellery salesman Rufus in another Richard Curtis British-set romantic comedy, ''[[Love Actually]]'' (2003), and the crime comedy ''[[Keeping Mum]]'' (2005), which also starred [[Kristin Scott Thomas]], [[Maggie Smith]], and [[Patrick Swayze]].

column1: In addition to his supporting roles, Atkinson has also had success as a leading man. His television character Mr. Bean debuted on the big screen with ''[[Bean (film)
column2: Bean]]'' (1997) to international success. A sequel, ''[[Mr. Bean's Holiday]]'' (2007), (again inspired to some extent by Jacques Tati in his film ‘Les Vacances de M. Hulot’), also became an international success. He has also starred in the James Bond parody ''[[Johnny English (film series)

column1: Rowan Atkinson performed live on-stage skits — also appearing with members of [[Monty Python]] — in ''[[The Secret Policeman's Ball (1979)
column2: The Secret Policeman's Ball]]'' (1979) in London for [[Amnesty International]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title= Rowan Atkinson: Mr Bean shows his serious side
column10: last=Gilbey}}</ref> Atkinson undertook a four-month tour of the UK in 1980. A recording of the stage performance was subsequently released as ''[[Live in Belfast]].''

column1: In 1984, Atkinson appeared in a [[West End theatre
column2: West End]] version of the comedy play ''[[The Nerd (play)
column3: The Nerd]]'' alongside a 10-year-old [[Christian Bale]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = Christian Bale — Screenshots and Info for Actor Christian Bale}}</ref> ''The Sneeze and Other Stories'', seven short [[Anton Chekhov]] plays, translated and adapted by [[Michael Frayn]], were performed by Rowan Atkinson, [[Timothy West]] and [[Cheryl Campbell]] at the [[Aldwych Theatre]], London in 1988 and early 1989.<ref>{{cite book
''Oliver!'' billboard at the West End's [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] in 2009.]]

column1: In 2009, during the West End revival of the musical ''[[Oliver!]]'' based on [[Charles Dickens]]' novel ''[[Oliver Twist]]'', Atkinson played the role of [[Fagin]].<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Review of Oliver! opening night
column9: last=Spencer}}</ref> His portrayal and singing of Fagin at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] in London gained favourable reviews and he was nominated for an [[Laurence Olivier Award
column10: Olivier Award]] for best actor in a musical or entertainment.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On 28 November 2012, Rowan Atkinson reprised the role of Blackadder at the \"We are Most Amused\" comedy gala for [[The Prince's Trust]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London. He was joined by Tony Robinson as Baldrick. The sketch involved the first new Blackadder material for 10 years, with Blackadder as CEO of Melchett, Melchett and Darling bank facing an enquiry over the banking crisis.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Review of 'We are most amused' (2012)

column1: In February 2013, Atkinson took on the titular role in a 12-week production (directed by [[Richard Eyre]]) of the [[Simon Gray]] play ''[[Quartermaine's Terms]]'' at [[Wyndham's Theatre]] in London with costars [[Conleth Hill]] (''[[Game of Thrones]]'') and [[Felicity Montagu]] (''[[I'm Alan Partridge]]'').<ref>{{cite news
column6: access-date=27 January 2015}}</ref> In December 2013, he revived his schoolmaster sketch for Royal Free Hospital's Rocks with Laughter at the Adelphi Theatre.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Royal Free Rocks with Laughter — review
column12: access-date=21 November 2015}}</ref> A few days prior, he performed a selection of sketches in a small coffee venue in front of only 30 people.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Best known for his use of [[physical comedy]] in his Mr. Bean persona, Atkinson's other characters rely more on language. Atkinson often plays authority figures (especially priests or vicars) speaking absurd lines with a completely [[deadpan]] delivery.

column2: comic devices]] is over-articulation of the \"B\" sound, such as his pronunciation of \"[[Bob (Blackadder character)
column10: date=23 August 2007}}</ref> and the over-articulation is a technique to overcome problematic consonants.

column1: Atkinson's often visually based style, which has been compared to that of [[Buster Keaton]],<ref name=\"Museum.tv\" /> sets him apart from most modern television and film comics, who rely heavily on dialogue, as well as stand-up comedy which is mostly based on monologues. This talent for visual comedy has led to Atkinson being called \"the man with the rubber face\"; comedic reference was made to this in an episode of ''[[Blackadder the Third]]'' (\"[[Sense and Senility]]\"), in which [[Baldrick]] ([[Tony Robinson]]) refers to his master, [[Edmund Blackadder
column2: Mr. E. Blackadder]], as a \"lazy, big-nosed, rubber-faced bastard\".

column1: Atkinson's early comedy influences were the sketch comedy troupe ''[[Beyond the Fringe]]'', made up of [[Peter Cook]], [[Dudley Moore]], [[Jonathan Miller]] and [[Alan Bennett]], major figures of the 1960s British [[satire boom]], and then [[Monty Python]]. Atkinson states, “I remember watching them avidly as students at university.”<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> He continued to be influenced by the work of [[John Cleese]] following his Monty Python days, regarding Cleese as being “a major, major inspiration”, adding, “I think that he and I are quite different in our style and our approach, but certainly it was comedy I liked to watch. He was very physical. Yes, very physical and very angry.”<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> He was also influenced by [[Peter Sellers]], whose characters [[Hrundi Bakshi]] from ''[[The Party (1968 film)
column2: The Party]]'' (1968) and [[Inspector Clouseau]] from ''[[The Pink Panther]]'' films influenced Atkinson's characters Mr. Bean and Johnny English.<ref>{{cite news

column1: On [[Barry Humphries]]' [[Dame Edna Everage]], he states, “I loved that character – again, it's the veneer of respectability disguising suburban prejudice of a really quite vicious and dismissive nature.”<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> Of visual comedians, Atkinson regards [[Charlie Chaplin]], Buster Keaton and [[Harold Lloyd]] as influential.<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> He was also inspired by French comedian [[Jacques Tati]], stating, “''[[Mr. Hulot's Holiday]]'' I remember seeing when I was 17 – that was a major inspiration. He opened a window to a world that I'd never looked out on before, and I thought, \"God, that's interesting,\" how a comic situation can be developed as purely visual and yet it's not under-cranked, it's not speeded-up, it's more deliberate; it takes its time. And I enjoyed that.”<ref name=\"LA Times\">{{cite news
column2: title = Before and after 'Bean': A talk with Rowan Atkinson, continued

column5: Rowan Atkinson at the ''[[Mr. Bean's Holiday]]'' premiere at [[Leicester Square]] in London (2007)]]

column1: In March 2001, while Atkinson was on a holiday trip to [[Kenya]], the pilot of his private plane [[Syncope (medicine)
column2: fainted]]. Atkinson managed to maintain the plane in the air until the pilot recovered and was able to land the plane at [[Nairobi]]'s [[Wilson Airport]].<ref>{{cite news

column1: Rowan Atkinson married Sunetra Sastry in February 1990. They have two children, Ben and Lily.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Rowan Atkinson: Mr Bean star known for satire and love of fast cars
column9: date=5 August 2011}}</ref> The couple first met in the late 1980s, when she was working as a makeup artist with the [[BBC]].<ref>{{cite news
column15: separated]] in 2014 and were [[divorce]]d on 10 November 2015.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Rowan Atkinson divorced in 65 seconds on grounds of his 'unreasonable behaviour'
column20: access-date=11 November 2015}}</ref> Atkinson has been in a relationship with comedian [[Louise Ford]] since 2014; she gave birth to Atkinson's third child in December 2017.<ref name=\"duncan1\"/>

column1: In June 2005, Atkinson led a coalition of the United Kingdom's most prominent actors and writers, including [[Nicholas Hytner]], [[Stephen Fry]], and [[Ian McEwan]], to the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom
column2: British Parliament]] in an attempt to force a review of the controversial [[Racial and Religious Hatred Act 2006
column3: Racial and Religious Hatred Bill]], which they felt would give overwhelming power to religious groups to impose censorship on the arts.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Rowan Atkinson leads crusade against religious hatred Bill

column2: homophobic]] speech legislation, saying that the [[House of Lords]] must vote against a government attempt to remove a free speech clause in an anti-gay hate law.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Rowan Atkinson attacks gay hate law
column12: url-status=dead}}</ref> Atkinson opposed the [[Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005]] to outlaw inciting religious hatred, arguing that, \"freedom to criticise ideas — any ideas even if they are sincerely held beliefs — is one of the fundamental freedoms of society. And the law which attempts to say you can criticise or ridicule ideas as long as they are not religious ideas is a very peculiar law indeed.\"<ref>{{cite news

column1: In October 2012, he voiced his support for the [[Hate speech laws in the United Kingdom#Reform Section 5 campaign
column4: title=Rowan Atkinson: we must be allowed to insult each other
column8: location=London}}</ref> which aims to reform or repeal Section 5 of the [[Public Order Act 1986]], particularly its statement that an [[Harassment, alarm or distress
column9: insult]] can be grounds for arrest and punishment. It is a reaction to several recent high-profile arrests, which Atkinson sees as a restriction of freedom of expression.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Rowan Atkinson's address to the Reform Section 5 parliamentary reception
column14: access-date=21 October 2012}}</ref> In February 2014 Parliament passed a redaction of the [[statute]] which removed the word insulting following pressure from citizens.<ref>The [[Crime and Courts Act 2013]], [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2013/22/section/57 section 57(2)]</ref><ref>SI 2013/2981, [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2013/2981/article/3/made art 3]</ref>

column2: lorry]] [[Driving licence in the United Kingdom
column3: driving licence]], gained in 1981, because lorries held a fascination for him, and to ensure employment as a young actor. He has also used this skill when filming comedy material. In 1991, he starred in the self-penned ''The Driven Man'', a series of sketches featuring Atkinson driving around London trying to solve his obsession with cars, and discussing it with taxi drivers, policemen, used-car salesmen and psychotherapists.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Rowan Atkinson: The Driven Man — Trailer — Cast — Showtimes
column9: date=7 February 2005}}</ref> A lover of and participant in car racing, he appeared as racing driver [[Tim Birkin
column10: Henry Birkin]] in the television play ''Full Throttle'' in 1995.

column4: Atkinson racing in a [[Jaguar Mark VII]] M at the [[Goodwood Revival]] motor racing festival in England in 2009]]

column1: Atkinson has raced in other cars, including a [[Renault 5 GT Turbo]] for two seasons for its [[Renault Clio Cup
column2: one make series]]. From 1997 to 2015, he owned a rare [[McLaren F1]], which was involved in an accident in Cabus, near [[Garstang]], Lancashire, with an [[Austin Metro]] in October 1999.<ref>{{cite news
column6: date=27 October 1999}}</ref> It was damaged again in a serious crash in August 2011 when it caught fire after Atkinson reportedly lost control and hit a tree.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Mr Bean and Blackadder star Rowan Atkinson in hospital after McLaren F1 supercar crash
column15: title= Update: TV star Rowan Atkinson in hospital following Cambridgeshire crash
column16: work= Evening Star}}</ref> That accident caused significant damage to the vehicle, taking over a year to be repaired and leading to the largest insurance payout in Britain, at £910,000.<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Rowan Atkinson crash forces insurers to pay out record £910,000 to repair supercar
column24: location=London}}</ref> He has previously owned a [[Honda NSX]],<ref name=tgs16>Top Gear Series 17, episode 4</ref> an [[Audi A8]],<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=The cars of the stars: Rowan Atkinson
column28: access-date=30 April 2014}}</ref> a [[Škoda Superb]], and a [[Honda Civic Hybrid]].<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web

column2: Conservative Party]] politician [[Alan Clark]], a devotee of classic motor cars, recorded in his published ''[[Alan Clark Diaries
column3: Diaries]]'' a chance meeting with a man he later realized was Atkinson while driving through [[Oxfordshire]] in May 1984: \"Just after leaving the motorway at Thame I noticed a dark red [[Aston Martin DBS
column4: DBS V8]] Aston Martin on the slip road with the bonnet up, a man unhappily bending over it. I told Jane to pull in and walked back. A DV8 in trouble is always good for a gloat.\" Clark writes that he gave Atkinson a lift in his [[List of Rolls-Royce motor cars
column5: Rolls-Royce]] to the nearest telephone box, but was disappointed in his bland reaction to being recognised, noting that: \"he didn't sparkle, was rather disappointing and [[wikt:chétif

column1: In July 2001, Atkinson crashed an [[Aston Martin V8 Zagato]] at an enthusiasts' meeting, but walked away unhurt. This was while he was competing in the ''[[Aston Martin Owners Club]]'' event, at the [[Croft Circuit

One car Atkinson has said he will not own is a [[Porsche]]: \"I have a problem with Porsches. They're wonderful cars, but I know I could never live with one. Somehow, the typical Porsche people — and I wish them no ill — are not, I feel, my kind of people.\"<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=\"awardref\">{{cite web
In July 2011, Atkinson appeared as the \"[[Star in a Reasonably Priced Car]]\" on ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)
column2: Top Gear]]'', driving the Kia Cee'd around the track in 1:42.2, which at the time granted him first place on the leaderboard, with only [[Matt LeBlanc]] having set a faster time in the Cee'd.<ref name=\"tgs16\" />
