column1: * [https://history.nasa.gov/SP-424/sp424.htm ''The Voyage of Mariner 10: Mission to Venus and Mercury'' (NASA SP-424) 1978] Entire book about ''Mariner 10'', with all pictures and diagrams, on-line. Scroll down to click on the \"Table of Contents\" link. [https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19780019203_1978019203.pdf PDF version]

* [https://web.archive.org/web/20071209090055/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/profile.cfm?MCode=Mariner_10 ''Mariner 10'' Mission Profile] by [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov NASA's Solar System Exploration]
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20060316104119/http://www.astrosurf.com/nunes/explor/explor_m10.htm Calibrated images from the ''Mariner 10'' mission to Mercury and Venus]
* [https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1973-085A Master Catalog entry for ''Mariner 10''] at the [[National Space Science Data Center]]

'''Absolute pitch''' ('''AP'''), often called '''''perfect pitch''''', is a rare ability of a person to identify or re-create a given [[musical note]] without the benefit of a reference tone.<ref name=\"phil-494\">{{cite book
column20: isbn=0-12-213564-4}}</ref> AP can be demonstrated via linguistic labeling (\"naming\" a note), associating mental imagery with the note, or sensorimotor responses. For example, an AP possessor can accurately reproduce a heard tone on a musical instrument without \"hunting\" for the correct pitch.<ref name=\"Zatorre, 1989\">{{cite journal
column24: title=Multiple coding strategies in the retention of musical tones by possessors of absolute pitch
column36: title=Absolute pitch: a model for understanding the influence of genes and development on neural and cognitive function

column1: The frequency of AP in the general population is not known. The assumed occurrence of less than 1:10,000 is widely reported, but it is not supported by evidence.<ref name=\"Bachem, 1955\">{{cite journal
column5: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column11: bibcode=1955ASAJ...27.1180B }}</ref> However, a 2019 review of more recent and international studies indicates prevalence of at least 4% amongst music students.<ref>{{Cite journal
column17: title=Absolute pitch: Myths, evidence and relevance to music education and performance

column1: Generally, absolute pitch implies some or all of the following abilities, achieved without a reference tone:<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians

column3: sharp}}, A, G, C) played on various instruments.

column2: key]] of a given piece of tonal music.

column1: * Identify and name all the tones of a given [[chord (music)
* Name the pitches of common everyday sounds such as [[vehicle horn

People may have absolute pitch along with the ability of [[relative pitch]], and relative and absolute pitch work together in actual musical listening and practice, but strategies in using each skill vary.<ref name=\"Miyazaki, 2004\">{{cite journal
column5: title=How well do we understand absolute pitch?

column1: Adults who possess relative pitch but do not already have absolute pitch can learn \"pseudo-absolute pitch\" and become able to identify notes in a way that superficially resembles absolute pitch.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Music Meets Medicine, Proceedings of the Signe and Ane Gyllenberg Foundation
column5: chapter=Absolute pitch: Both a curse and a blessing
column10: location=Helsinki, Finland}}</ref> Certain people who train to name notes may indeed become able to identify all 12 notes of the scale with 90% accuracy or above,<ref>{{cite biorxiv
column11: title=Is it impossible to acquire absolute pitch in adulthood?
column21: biorxiv=355933}}</ref> and [[valproate]], a medication used to treat epilepsy and severe depression, may re-open the \"critical period\" of learning, making the acquisition of absolute pitch, as well as languages, potentially as efficient for adults as for children.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Acquiring 'perfect' pitch may be possible for some adults
column27: title= Valproate reopens critical-period learning of absolute pitch
column28: author=Gervain J, Vines BW, Chen LM, Seo RJ, Hensch TK, Werker JF, Young AH
column36: doi=10.3389/fnsys.2013.00102 }}</ref> Even so, pitch training can require considerable motivation, time, and effort, and learning is not retained without constant practice and reinforcement.<ref>{{cite journal
column39: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

column1: Scientific study of absolute pitch appears to have commenced in the 19th century, focusing on the phenomenon of musical pitch and methods of measuring it.<ref name=Ellis1876>{{Cite journal
column4: title=On the Sensitiveness of the Ear to Pitch and Change of Pitch in Music
column11: access-date=24 August 2010 }}</ref> It would have been difficult for any notion of absolute pitch to have formed earlier because pitch references were not consistent. For example, the note now known as 'A' varied in different local or national musical traditions between what would now be considered as G sharp and B flat before the standardisation of the late 19th century. While the term ''absolute pitch'', or ''absolute ear'', was in use by the late 19th century by both British<ref name=Bosanquet1876>{{Cite journal
column14: title=An Elementary Treaties on Musical Intervals and Temperament
column15: series=with an Account of an Enharmonic Harmonium Exhibited in the Loan Collection of Scientific Instruments
column20: access-date=24 August 2010 }}</ref> and German researchers,<ref name=vonKries>{{Cite journal
column30: access-date=24 August 2010 }} [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/kreis92e.htm Translation by Christopher Aruffo, www.acousticlearning.com]</ref> its application was not universal; other terms such as ''musical ear'',<ref name=Ellis1876/> ''absolute tone consciousness'',<ref name=Otto07>{{Cite journal
column33: title=Das absolute Tonbewußtsein und die Musik
column40: access-date=25 August 2010 }} [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/abraham07e.htm Translation by Christopher Aruffo, www.acousticlearning.com]</ref> or ''positive pitch''<ref name=\"Copp 1916\">{{cite journal
column49: doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.jhered.a110728 }}</ref> were also used to refer to the ability. The skill is not exclusively musical, or limited to human perception; absolute pitch has been demonstrated in animals such as bats, wolves, gerbils, and birds, for whom specific pitches facilitate identification of mates or meals.<ref name=Brown1999>{{Cite journal

column1: Physically and functionally, the auditory system of an absolute listener does not appear to be different from that of a non-absolute listener.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: journal=Journal of Research in Music Education
column10: publisher=Journal of Research in Music Education, Vol. 17, No. 1
column11: jstor=3344200}}</ref> Rather, \"it reflects a particular ability to analyze frequency information, presumably involving high-level cortical processing.\"<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Instant Recognition: The Genetics of Pitch Perception
column14: journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics
column21: pmc=1376907}}</ref> Absolute pitch is an act of cognition, needing memory of the frequency, a label for the frequency (such as \"B-flat\"), and exposure to the range of sound encompassed by that categorical label. Absolute pitch may be directly analogous to recognizing [[color]]s, [[phoneme]]s (speech sounds), or other categorical perception of sensory stimuli. Just as most people have learned to recognize and name the color ''blue'' by the range of frequencies of the electromagnetic radiation that are perceived as [[light]], it is possible that those who have been exposed to musical notes together with their names early in life will be more likely to identify, for example, the note C.<ref name=\"Ref-1\">{{cite journal
column31: issue=2}}</ref> Although it was once thought that it \"might be nothing more than a general human capacity whose expression is strongly biased by the level and type of exposure to music that people experience in a given culture\",<ref name=\"google\">{{cite book
column41: access-date=16 August 2015}}</ref> absolute pitch may have contributions from genetic variations, possibly an [[autosomal]] [[dominant gene]]tic trait.<ref>{{cite journal
column58: title=Absolute pitch: An approach for identification of genetic and nongenetic components
column59: journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics
column67: url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/AJHG/journal/issues/v62n2/970244/970244.web.pdf}}</ref><ref name=\"Theusch, E. et al.\"/><ref name=\"Drayna, D. et al.\"/><ref name=\"gregersen_2013\"/>

column1: Absolute pitch sense appears to be influenced by cultural exposure to music, especially in the familiarization of the [[Equal temperament
column3: C-major scale]]. Most of the absolute listeners that were tested in this respect identified the C-major tones more reliably and, except for B, more quickly than the five \"black key\" tones,<ref>{{cite journal
column5: title=The speed of musical pitch identification by absolute-pitch possessors
column12: jstor=40285495 }}</ref> which corresponds to the higher prevalence of these tones in ordinary musical experience. One study of Dutch non-musicians also demonstrated a bias toward using C-major tones in ordinary speech, especially on syllables related to emphasis.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: Absolute pitch is more common among speakers of [[tonal language]]s, such as most dialects of [[Chinese language
column3: Vietnamese]], which often depend on pitch variation as the means of distinguishing words that otherwise sound the same—e.g., [[Standard Mandarin
column4: Mandarin]] with four possible tonal variations, [[Cantonese]] with six, [[Southern Min]] with seven or eight (depending on dialect), and Vietnamese with six.<ref name=jasa138th>{{cite journal
column11: title = Tone Language Speakers Possess Absolute Pitch
column12: journal = Acoustical Society of America Journal
column29: title = Perfect Pitch in Tone Language Speakers Carries Over to Music
column30: journal = Acoustical Society of America Journal
column38: bibcode = 2004ASAJ..116.2580D}}</ref> Speakers of [[Sino-Tibetan languages]] have been reported to speak a word in the same absolute pitch (within a quarter-tone) on different days; it has therefore been suggested that absolute pitch may be acquired by infants when they learn to speak a tonal language<ref name=\"deu-2004\">{{cite journal
column42: title=Absolute pitch, speech, and tone language: Some experiments and a proposed framework
column49: url=http://philomel.com/pdf/MP-2004-21_339-356.pdf }}</ref> (and possibly also by infants when they learn to speak a [[Pitch accent
column50: pitch-accent language]]). However, the brains of tonal-language speakers do not naturally process musical sound as language;<ref>{{cite journal
column55: title=Pitch processing in the human brain is influenced by language experience
column66: archive-date=2006-09-12 }}</ref> perhaps such speakers are more likely to acquire absolute pitch for musical tones when they later receive musical training. Many native speakers of a tone language, even those with little musical training, are observed to sing a given song consistently with regard to pitch. Among music students of East Asian ethnic heritage, those who speak a tone language very fluently have a much higher prevalence of absolute pitch than those who do not speak a tone language.<ref name=\"phil-jasa-2006\">{{cite journal
column72: title=Absolute pitch among American and Chinese conservatory students: Prevalence differences, and evidence for a speech-related critical period
column73: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column86: title=Absolute pitch among students in an American music conservatory: Association with tone language fluency
column87: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column100: title=Absolute pitch among students at the Shanghai Conservatory of Music: A large-scale direct-test study
column101: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

column1: It is possible that African level-tone languages—such as [[Yoruba language
column5: title=Aspects of pitch realization in Yoruba
column10: doi=10.1017/S095267570000110X}}</ref> with three pitch levels, and [[Mambila language
column13: title=The perception of lexical tone in Mambila
column20: issue= 2}}</ref> with four—may be better suited to study the role of absolute pitch in speech than the pitch and contour tone languages of East Asia.

column1: Speakers of European languages have been found to make subconscious use of an absolute pitch memory when speaking.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title=Speech mirrors norm-tones: Absolute pitch as a normal but precognitive trait

column1: Absolute pitch is the ability to perceive [[pitch class]] and to mentally categorize sounds according to perceived pitch class.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title= Categorical perception in absolute pitch
column7: pages=515–523}}</ref> A [[pitch class]] is the set of all pitches that are a whole number of octaves apart. While the boundaries of musical pitch categories vary among human cultures, the recognition of octave relationships is a natural characteristic of the mammalian auditory system.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: title=The laminar structure of the medial geniculate body of the cat
column21: title=Dendritic orientation and laminar architecture in the rabbit auditory thalamus
column31: title=Tonotopic organization in ventral nucleus of medial geniculate body in the cat
column44: title=Frequency organization and cellular lamination in the medial geniculate body of the rabbit
column57: title=Music perception and octave generalization in rhesus monkeys
column68: title=Carbamazepine induced pitch shift and octave space representation
column75: issue=1–2}}</ref> Accordingly, absolute pitch is not the ability to estimate a pitch value from the dimension of pitch-evoking frequency (30–5000 Hz),<ref name=\"Ref-1\"/> but to identify a pitch class category within the dimension of pitch class (e.g., C-C{{music

column1: An absolute listener's sense of hearing is typically no keener than that of a non-absolute (\"normal\") listener.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=The basic hearing abilities of absolute pitch possessors
column14: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Absolute pitch does not depend upon a refined ability to perceive and discriminate gradations of sound frequencies,<ref>{{cite journal
column16: title=An experimental study of pitch naming and pitch discrimination reactions
column23: doi=10.1080/00221325.1955.10532197}}</ref> but upon detecting and categorizing a subjective perceptual quality typically referred to as \"chroma\".<ref>{{cite journal
column26: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column33: reason=The introduction of a subjective \"sound color\" element here is potentially very confusing. It is a matter of pitch isn't it?
column34: date=October 2016}} The two tasks— of identification (recognizing and naming a pitch) and discrimination (detecting changes or differences in rate of vibration)— are accomplished with different brain mechanisms.<ref>{{cite journal
column41: title=Absolute pitch and event-related brain potentials

column1: The prevalence of absolute pitch is higher among those who are blind from birth as a result of [[optic nerve hypoplasia]].
Absolute pitch is considerably more common among those whose early childhood was spent in [[East Asia]].<ref name=\"greg\">{{cite journal
column6: title=Early childhood music education and predisposition to absolute pitch
column18: title=  Absolute pitch among American and Chinese conservatory students: Prevalence differences, and evidence for a speech-related critical period
column19: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column40: title=Ethnicity versus Early Environment: Comment on 'Early childhood music education and predisposition to absolute pitch: Teasing apart genes and environment' by Peter K. Gregersen, Elena Kowalsky, Nina Kohn, and Elizabeth West Marvin (2000)
column41: journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics Part A
column48: url=http://philomel.com/pdf/AJMG_2007.pdf}}</ref> This might seem to be a genetic difference;<ref name=\"zlab\">{{cite journal
column50: title=Absolute Pitch: A model for understanding the influence of genes and development on neural and cognitive function
column62: doi=10.1038/nn1085 }}</ref> however, people of East Asian ancestry who are reared in North America are significantly less likely to develop absolute pitch than those raised in East Asia,<ref name=\"deu_2007\"/> so the difference is more probably explained by experience. The language that is spoken may be an important factor; many East Asians speak tonal languages such as Mandarin and Cantonese, while others (such as those in Japan and certain provinces of Korea) speak pitch-accent languages, and the prevalence of absolute pitch may be partly explained by exposure to pitches together with meaningful musical labels very early in life.<ref name=\"deu_2006\"/><ref name=\"deu_2006b\"/><ref name=\"deu_2007\"/><ref name=deu_2004>{{cite journal
column67: title=Absolute pitch, speech, and tone language: Some experiments and a proposed framework

column1: Absolute pitch ability has higher prevalence among those with [[Williams syndrome]]<ref name=\"lenhoff\">{{cite journal
column12: issue=4}}</ref> and those with an [[autism spectrum disorder]], with rates as high as 30% claimed, stating that the rate among musicians in general is far lower.{{Clarify
column18: title=Autism and pitch processing: A precursor for savant musical ability
column25: jstor=40285769}}</ref><ref>Frith, U. How Cognitive Theories Can Help Us Explain Autism. Speech. UC Davis Mind Institute. Video available, 4/5 down the list: http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/mindinstitute/videos/video_autism.html {{Webarchive
column27: date=2011-11-04 }}</ref> A non-verbal piano-matching method resulted in a correlation of 97% between{{Clarify
column28: reason=In which direction? 97% of persons with ASD having absolute pitch or 97% of persons with absolute pitch being on the autism spectrum? Or was there a score on a pitch-matching test and a score on an autism-detection test (e.g., Asperger Questionnaire), and was the test geared toward specificity or sensitivity?
column29: date=April 2016}} autism and absolute pitch, with a 53% correlation in non-autistic observers{{Clarify
column30: reason=Correlation between what and what? Does \"in\" mean \"between\"/\"among\" here? \"In the minds of\"? Observers of what?
column34: title=Non-Verbal Paradigm for Assessing Individuals for Absolute Pitch
column40: doi=10.1080/02604027.2014.989780}}</ref> However, the converse is not indicated by research which found no difference between those with AP and those without on measures of social and communication skills, which are core deficits in autistic spectrum disorders. Additionally, the AP group's [[autism-spectrum quotient]] was \"way below clinical thresholds\".<ref>{{Cite journal
column52: title=Do Musicians with Perfect Pitch Have More Autism Traits than Musicians without Perfect Pitch? An Empirical Study

column1: Absolute pitch might be achievable by any human being during a [[critical period]] of auditory development,<ref name=\"Sakakibara, 2004\">{{cite journal
column4: title= Why Are People Able to Acquire Absolute Pitch Only During Early Childhood?
column5: journal=The Japanese Journal of Educational Psychology
column12: title= The Development of Absolute Pitch: A Theory Concerning the Roles of Music Training at an Early Developmental Age and Individual Cognitive Style
column17: doi=10.1177/0305735603031002292}}</ref> after which period [[cognitive]] strategies favor global and relational processing. Proponents of the critical-period theory agree that the presence of absolute pitch ability is dependent on learning, but there is disagreement about whether training causes absolute skills to occur<ref name=\"Oura & Eguchi, 1982\">{{cite journal
column21: title=Absolute pitch training program for children
column27: title=A longitudinal study of a process for acquiring absolute pitch
column28: journal=The Japanese Journal of Educational Psychology
column34: title=Learning of absolute pitch by children
column44: title=The acquisition of absolute pitch for the mainstreamed, special educational needs and academically talented under Lau Chiu Kay Music Educatherapy
column45: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column53: fix-attempted=yes }} Abstract</ref> or lack of training causes absolute perception to be overwhelmed and obliterated by relative perception of [[interval (music)
column60: pages=1–86}}[http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/abraham01.htm Full text] [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/abraham01e.htm Full text (English)]</ref><ref name=\"Saffran and Griepentrog, 2001\">{{cite journal
column65: title=Absolute pitch in infant auditory learning: Evidence for developmental reorganization

column2: loci]] could affect absolute pitch ability, a predisposition for learning the ability or signal the likelihood of its spontaneous occurrence.<ref name=\"Theusch, E. et al.\">{{cite journal
column8: title=Genome-wide Study of Families with Absolute Pitch Reveals Linkage to 8q24.21 and Locus Heterogeneity
column9: journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics
column26: title=Absolute pitch exhibits phenotypic and genetic overlap with synesthesia
column34: pmc=4707203}}</ref><ref name=\"Drayna, D. et al.\">{{cite journal
column42: title=Genetic correlates of musical pitch recognition in humans

column1: Researchers have been trying to teach absolute pitch ability in laboratory settings for more than a century,<ref name=\"Meyer_1899\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Is the memory of absolute pitch capable of development by training?
column10: url=http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/meyer99.htm}}</ref> and various commercial absolute-pitch training courses have been offered to the public since the early 1900s.<ref>{{cite book
column20: url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2013, experimenters reported that adult men who took the antiseizure drug [[Valproate]] (VPA) \"learned to identify pitch significantly better than those taking placebo—evidence that VPA facilitated critical-period learning in the adult human brain\".<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: title=Valproate reopens critical-period learning of absolute pitch
column40: volume=7}}</ref> However, no adult has ever been documented to have acquired absolute listening ability,<ref>{{cite journal
column44: title=Absolute pitch: Perception, coding, and controversies
column56: url-status=dead }}</ref> because all adults who have been formally tested after AP training have failed to demonstrate \"an unqualified level of accuracy... comparable to that of AP possessors\".<ref>{{cite journal

column1: While very few people have the ability to name a pitch with no external reference, pitch memory can be activated by repeated exposure.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance
column17: access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> People who are not skilled singers will often sing popular songs in the correct key,<ref>{{cite journal
column20: title=Absolute memory for musical pitch: evidence from production of learned melodies
column30: archive-date=2011-07-06 }}</ref> and can usually recognize when TV themes have been shifted into the wrong key.<ref>{{cite journal
column35: title= Good pitch memory is widespread
column44: fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> Members of the Venda culture in South Africa also sing familiar children's songs in the key in which the songs were learned.<ref>{{cite book
column48: chapter=Music and Historical Process in Vendaland

column1: This phenomenon is apparently unrelated to musical training. The skill may be associated more closely with vocal production. Violin students learning the [[Suzuki method]] are required to memorize each composition in a fixed key and play it from memory on their instrument, but they are not required to sing. When tested, these students did not succeed in singing the memorized Suzuki songs in the original, fixed key.<ref>{{cite book
column5: chapter=Absolute memory of learned melodies in children trained by the Suzuki violin method
column6: title=Proceedings of the 8th International Conference on Music Perception and Cognition

column1: Musicians with absolute perception may experience difficulties which do not exist for other musicians. Because absolute listeners are capable of recognizing that a musical composition has been transposed from its original key, or that a pitch is being produced at a nonstandard frequency (either sharp or flat), a musician with absolute pitch may become distressed upon perceiving tones believed to be \"wrong\" or hearing a piece of music \"in the wrong key.\" This can especially apply to Baroque music that is recorded in Baroque tuning (usually A = 415 Hz as opposed to 440 Hz, ''i.e.'', roughly a half step or [[semitone]] lower than standard concert pitch).<ref name=\"Sacks, O. 2007\">{{cite book
column4: title=Musicophilia: Tales of Music and the Brain
column9: isbn=978-1-4000-4081-0}}</ref> An absolute listener may also use absolute strategies for tasks which are more efficiently accomplished with [[relative pitch
column10: relative strategies]], such as transposition<ref name=\"miy_1993\">{{cite journal
column12: title=Absolute pitch as an inability: Identification of musical intervals in a tonal context
column19: jstor=40285599}}</ref> or producing harmony for tones whose frequencies do not match standard [[equal temperament]].<ref>{{cite book
column24: location=Ontario}}</ref> It is also possible for some musicians to have displaced absolute pitch, where all notes are slightly flat or slightly sharp of their respective pitch as defined by a given convention.{{citation needed
column25: date=June 2015}} This may arise from learning the pitch names from an instrument that was tuned to a concert pitch convention other than the one in use, ''e.g.'', A = 435 Hz (the [[Paris Opera]] convention of the late 19th and early 20th centuries) as opposed to the Anglo-American modern standard A = 440 Hz. When playing in groups with other musicians, this may lead to playing in a tonality that is slightly different from that of the rest of the group.{{citation needed

column1: Absolute pitch shows a genetic overlap with music-related and non-music-related [[synesthesia]]/[[ideasthesia]].<ref name=gregersen_2013/> They may associate certain notes or keys with different colors, enabling them to tell what any note or key is. In this study, about 20% of people with perfect pitch are also synesthetes.
There is evidence of a higher rate of absolute pitch in the [[autistic]] population.<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Veridical mapping in the development of exceptional autistic abilities

column1: Absolute pitch is not a prerequisite for skilled musical performance or composition. However, musicians with absolute pitch tend to perform better on musical transcription tasks (controlling for age of onset and amount of musical training) compared to those without absolute pitch.<ref name=\"phil-446\">{{cite journal
column5: title=Absolute pitch correlates with high performance on musical dictation
column6: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column14: url=https://semanticscholar.org/paper/f75c4936a26a63195692432e86e8bbccf60c82e8 }} [http://philomel.com/pdf/JASA-2010_128_890-893.pdf PDF Document]</ref> It was previously argued that musicians with absolute pitch perform worse than those without absolute pitch on recognition of musical intervals,<ref name=\"miyazaki\">{{cite journal
column16: title=Perception of relative pitch with different references: Some absolute-pitch listeners can't tell musical interval names
column23: pmid=8532499}} [https://doi.org/10.3758%2FBF03205455 PDF Document]</ref> however experiments on which this conclusion was based contained an [[Artifact (error)
column24: artifact]], and when this artifact was removed, absolute pitch possessors were found to perform better than nonpossessors on recognition of musical intervals.<ref name=\"phil-473\">{{cite journal
column27: title=Absolute pitch correlates with high performance on interval naming tasks
column28: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

column1: Owing to uncertainty in the historical record, it is often impossible to determine whether notable composers and musicians of the past had absolute pitch. Since absolute pitch is rare in European musical culture,<ref name=\"deu_2006b\" /> claims that any particular musician possessed it are difficult to evaluate. Among composers of the [[Baroque music
column3: Classical]] eras, evidence is available only for [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
column4: Mozart]], who is documented to have demonstrated the ability at age 7.<ref name=\"phil-45\">{{cite journal
column13: url=https://semanticscholar.org/paper/386ccaf8507b4dfb6d8d92f7ccd996c4d4c93b75 }} [http://philomel.com/pdf/AT-2006_2_2.pdf PDF Document]</ref> Experts have only surmised that [[Ludwig van Beethoven
column14: Beethoven]] had it, as indicated from some excerpts from his letters. By the 19th century, it became more common for the presence of absolute pitch to be recorded, identifying the ability to be present in musicians such as [[Camille Saint-Saëns]] and [[John Philip Sousa]].<ref>Naxos. (2018). \"John Philip Sousa.\" Retrieved from https://www.naxos.com/person/John_Philip_Sousa_24864/24864.htm</ref>

column1: Notable recent musicians with absolute pitch include [[Charlie Puth]],<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Perfectly Pitched For Success – Charlie Puth {{!}} eDirectory
column17: title=Какую легенду хранит семья Димаша Кудайбергена
column22: title=Бабушка и дедушка Димаша дали эксклюзивное интервью
column32: title=5 Annoying Things People with Perfect Pitch Do

column1: * Comprehensive historical [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/phase11.htm bibliography of absolute pitch research], 1876–present
* Another [https://web.archive.org/web/20080513025334/http://www.nslij-genetics.org/apbib/ bibliography of absolute pitch], with +300 papers

'''Absolute pitch''' ('''AP'''), often called '''''perfect pitch''''', is a rare ability of a person to identify or re-create a given [[musical note]] without the benefit of a reference tone.<ref name=\"phil-494\">{{cite book
column20: isbn=0-12-213564-4}}</ref> AP can be demonstrated via linguistic labeling (\"naming\" a note), associating mental imagery with the note, or sensorimotor responses. For example, an AP possessor can accurately reproduce a heard tone on a musical instrument without \"hunting\" for the correct pitch.<ref name=\"Zatorre, 1989\">{{cite journal
column24: title=Multiple coding strategies in the retention of musical tones by possessors of absolute pitch
column36: title=Absolute pitch: a model for understanding the influence of genes and development on neural and cognitive function

column1: The frequency of AP in the general population is not known. The assumed occurrence of less than 1:10,000 is widely reported, but it is not supported by evidence.<ref name=\"Bachem, 1955\">{{cite journal
column5: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column11: bibcode=1955ASAJ...27.1180B }}</ref> However, a 2019 review of more recent and international studies indicates prevalence of at least 4% amongst music students.<ref>{{Cite journal
column17: title=Absolute pitch: Myths, evidence and relevance to music education and performance

column1: Generally, absolute pitch implies some or all of the following abilities, achieved without a reference tone:<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians

column3: sharp}}, A, G, C) played on various instruments.

column2: key]] of a given piece of tonal music.

column1: * Identify and name all the tones of a given [[chord (music)
* Name the pitches of common everyday sounds such as [[vehicle horn

People may have absolute pitch along with the ability of [[relative pitch]], and relative and absolute pitch work together in actual musical listening and practice, but strategies in using each skill vary.<ref name=\"Miyazaki, 2004\">{{cite journal
column5: title=How well do we understand absolute pitch?

column1: Adults who possess relative pitch but do not already have absolute pitch can learn \"pseudo-absolute pitch\" and become able to identify notes in a way that superficially resembles absolute pitch.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Music Meets Medicine, Proceedings of the Signe and Ane Gyllenberg Foundation
column5: chapter=Absolute pitch: Both a curse and a blessing
column10: location=Helsinki, Finland}}</ref> Certain people who train to name notes may indeed become able to identify all 12 notes of the scale with 90% accuracy or above,<ref>{{cite biorxiv
column11: title=Is it impossible to acquire absolute pitch in adulthood?
column21: biorxiv=355933}}</ref> and [[valproate]], a medication used to treat epilepsy and severe depression, may re-open the \"critical period\" of learning, making the acquisition of absolute pitch, as well as languages, potentially as efficient for adults as for children.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Acquiring 'perfect' pitch may be possible for some adults
column27: title= Valproate reopens critical-period learning of absolute pitch
column28: author=Gervain J, Vines BW, Chen LM, Seo RJ, Hensch TK, Werker JF, Young AH
column36: doi=10.3389/fnsys.2013.00102 }}</ref> Even so, pitch training can require considerable motivation, time, and effort, and learning is not retained without constant practice and reinforcement.<ref>{{cite journal
column39: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

column1: Scientific study of absolute pitch appears to have commenced in the 19th century, focusing on the phenomenon of musical pitch and methods of measuring it.<ref name=Ellis1876>{{Cite journal
column4: title=On the Sensitiveness of the Ear to Pitch and Change of Pitch in Music
column11: access-date=24 August 2010 }}</ref> It would have been difficult for any notion of absolute pitch to have formed earlier because pitch references were not consistent. For example, the note now known as 'A' varied in different local or national musical traditions between what would now be considered as G sharp and B flat before the standardisation of the late 19th century. While the term ''absolute pitch'', or ''absolute ear'', was in use by the late 19th century by both British<ref name=Bosanquet1876>{{Cite journal
column14: title=An Elementary Treaties on Musical Intervals and Temperament
column15: series=with an Account of an Enharmonic Harmonium Exhibited in the Loan Collection of Scientific Instruments
column20: access-date=24 August 2010 }}</ref> and German researchers,<ref name=vonKries>{{Cite journal
column30: access-date=24 August 2010 }} [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/kreis92e.htm Translation by Christopher Aruffo, www.acousticlearning.com]</ref> its application was not universal; other terms such as ''musical ear'',<ref name=Ellis1876/> ''absolute tone consciousness'',<ref name=Otto07>{{Cite journal
column33: title=Das absolute Tonbewußtsein und die Musik
column40: access-date=25 August 2010 }} [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/abraham07e.htm Translation by Christopher Aruffo, www.acousticlearning.com]</ref> or ''positive pitch''<ref name=\"Copp 1916\">{{cite journal
column49: doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.jhered.a110728 }}</ref> were also used to refer to the ability. The skill is not exclusively musical, or limited to human perception; absolute pitch has been demonstrated in animals such as bats, wolves, gerbils, and birds, for whom specific pitches facilitate identification of mates or meals.<ref name=Brown1999>{{Cite journal

column1: Physically and functionally, the auditory system of an absolute listener does not appear to be different from that of a non-absolute listener.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: journal=Journal of Research in Music Education
column10: publisher=Journal of Research in Music Education, Vol. 17, No. 1
column11: jstor=3344200}}</ref> Rather, \"it reflects a particular ability to analyze frequency information, presumably involving high-level cortical processing.\"<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Instant Recognition: The Genetics of Pitch Perception
column14: journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics
column21: pmc=1376907}}</ref> Absolute pitch is an act of cognition, needing memory of the frequency, a label for the frequency (such as \"B-flat\"), and exposure to the range of sound encompassed by that categorical label. Absolute pitch may be directly analogous to recognizing [[color]]s, [[phoneme]]s (speech sounds), or other categorical perception of sensory stimuli. Just as most people have learned to recognize and name the color ''blue'' by the range of frequencies of the electromagnetic radiation that are perceived as [[light]], it is possible that those who have been exposed to musical notes together with their names early in life will be more likely to identify, for example, the note C.<ref name=\"Ref-1\">{{cite journal
column31: issue=2}}</ref> Although it was once thought that it \"might be nothing more than a general human capacity whose expression is strongly biased by the level and type of exposure to music that people experience in a given culture\",<ref name=\"google\">{{cite book
column41: access-date=16 August 2015}}</ref> absolute pitch may have contributions from genetic variations, possibly an [[autosomal]] [[dominant gene]]tic trait.<ref>{{cite journal
column58: title=Absolute pitch: An approach for identification of genetic and nongenetic components
column59: journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics
column67: url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/AJHG/journal/issues/v62n2/970244/970244.web.pdf}}</ref><ref name=\"Theusch, E. et al.\"/><ref name=\"Drayna, D. et al.\"/><ref name=\"gregersen_2013\"/>

column1: Absolute pitch sense appears to be influenced by cultural exposure to music, especially in the familiarization of the [[Equal temperament
column3: C-major scale]]. Most of the absolute listeners that were tested in this respect identified the C-major tones more reliably and, except for B, more quickly than the five \"black key\" tones,<ref>{{cite journal
column5: title=The speed of musical pitch identification by absolute-pitch possessors
column12: jstor=40285495 }}</ref> which corresponds to the higher prevalence of these tones in ordinary musical experience. One study of Dutch non-musicians also demonstrated a bias toward using C-major tones in ordinary speech, especially on syllables related to emphasis.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: Absolute pitch is more common among speakers of [[tonal language]]s, such as most dialects of [[Chinese language
column3: Vietnamese]], which often depend on pitch variation as the means of distinguishing words that otherwise sound the same—e.g., [[Standard Mandarin
column4: Mandarin]] with four possible tonal variations, [[Cantonese]] with six, [[Southern Min]] with seven or eight (depending on dialect), and Vietnamese with six.<ref name=jasa138th>{{cite journal
column11: title = Tone Language Speakers Possess Absolute Pitch
column12: journal = Acoustical Society of America Journal
column29: title = Perfect Pitch in Tone Language Speakers Carries Over to Music
column30: journal = Acoustical Society of America Journal
column38: bibcode = 2004ASAJ..116.2580D}}</ref> Speakers of [[Sino-Tibetan languages]] have been reported to speak a word in the same absolute pitch (within a quarter-tone) on different days; it has therefore been suggested that absolute pitch may be acquired by infants when they learn to speak a tonal language<ref name=\"deu-2004\">{{cite journal
column42: title=Absolute pitch, speech, and tone language: Some experiments and a proposed framework
column49: url=http://philomel.com/pdf/MP-2004-21_339-356.pdf }}</ref> (and possibly also by infants when they learn to speak a [[Pitch accent
column50: pitch-accent language]]). However, the brains of tonal-language speakers do not naturally process musical sound as language;<ref>{{cite journal
column55: title=Pitch processing in the human brain is influenced by language experience
column66: archive-date=2006-09-12 }}</ref> perhaps such speakers are more likely to acquire absolute pitch for musical tones when they later receive musical training. Many native speakers of a tone language, even those with little musical training, are observed to sing a given song consistently with regard to pitch. Among music students of East Asian ethnic heritage, those who speak a tone language very fluently have a much higher prevalence of absolute pitch than those who do not speak a tone language.<ref name=\"phil-jasa-2006\">{{cite journal
column72: title=Absolute pitch among American and Chinese conservatory students: Prevalence differences, and evidence for a speech-related critical period
column73: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column86: title=Absolute pitch among students in an American music conservatory: Association with tone language fluency
column87: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column100: title=Absolute pitch among students at the Shanghai Conservatory of Music: A large-scale direct-test study
column101: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

column1: It is possible that African level-tone languages—such as [[Yoruba language
column5: title=Aspects of pitch realization in Yoruba
column10: doi=10.1017/S095267570000110X}}</ref> with three pitch levels, and [[Mambila language
column13: title=The perception of lexical tone in Mambila
column20: issue= 2}}</ref> with four—may be better suited to study the role of absolute pitch in speech than the pitch and contour tone languages of East Asia.

column1: Speakers of European languages have been found to make subconscious use of an absolute pitch memory when speaking.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title=Speech mirrors norm-tones: Absolute pitch as a normal but precognitive trait

column1: Absolute pitch is the ability to perceive [[pitch class]] and to mentally categorize sounds according to perceived pitch class.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title= Categorical perception in absolute pitch
column7: pages=515–523}}</ref> A [[pitch class]] is the set of all pitches that are a whole number of octaves apart. While the boundaries of musical pitch categories vary among human cultures, the recognition of octave relationships is a natural characteristic of the mammalian auditory system.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: title=The laminar structure of the medial geniculate body of the cat
column21: title=Dendritic orientation and laminar architecture in the rabbit auditory thalamus
column31: title=Tonotopic organization in ventral nucleus of medial geniculate body in the cat
column44: title=Frequency organization and cellular lamination in the medial geniculate body of the rabbit
column57: title=Music perception and octave generalization in rhesus monkeys
column68: title=Carbamazepine induced pitch shift and octave space representation
column75: issue=1–2}}</ref> Accordingly, absolute pitch is not the ability to estimate a pitch value from the dimension of pitch-evoking frequency (30–5000 Hz),<ref name=\"Ref-1\"/> but to identify a pitch class category within the dimension of pitch class (e.g., C-C{{music

column1: An absolute listener's sense of hearing is typically no keener than that of a non-absolute (\"normal\") listener.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=The basic hearing abilities of absolute pitch possessors
column14: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Absolute pitch does not depend upon a refined ability to perceive and discriminate gradations of sound frequencies,<ref>{{cite journal
column16: title=An experimental study of pitch naming and pitch discrimination reactions
column23: doi=10.1080/00221325.1955.10532197}}</ref> but upon detecting and categorizing a subjective perceptual quality typically referred to as \"chroma\".<ref>{{cite journal
column26: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column33: reason=The introduction of a subjective \"sound color\" element here is potentially very confusing. It is a matter of pitch isn't it?
column34: date=October 2016}} The two tasks— of identification (recognizing and naming a pitch) and discrimination (detecting changes or differences in rate of vibration)— are accomplished with different brain mechanisms.<ref>{{cite journal
column41: title=Absolute pitch and event-related brain potentials

column1: The prevalence of absolute pitch is higher among those who are blind from birth as a result of [[optic nerve hypoplasia]].
Absolute pitch is considerably more common among those whose early childhood was spent in [[East Asia]].<ref name=\"greg\">{{cite journal
column6: title=Early childhood music education and predisposition to absolute pitch
column18: title=  Absolute pitch among American and Chinese conservatory students: Prevalence differences, and evidence for a speech-related critical period
column19: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column40: title=Ethnicity versus Early Environment: Comment on 'Early childhood music education and predisposition to absolute pitch: Teasing apart genes and environment' by Peter K. Gregersen, Elena Kowalsky, Nina Kohn, and Elizabeth West Marvin (2000)
column41: journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics Part A
column48: url=http://philomel.com/pdf/AJMG_2007.pdf}}</ref> This might seem to be a genetic difference;<ref name=\"zlab\">{{cite journal
column50: title=Absolute Pitch: A model for understanding the influence of genes and development on neural and cognitive function
column62: doi=10.1038/nn1085 }}</ref> however, people of East Asian ancestry who are reared in North America are significantly less likely to develop absolute pitch than those raised in East Asia,<ref name=\"deu_2007\"/> so the difference is more probably explained by experience. The language that is spoken may be an important factor; many East Asians speak tonal languages such as Mandarin and Cantonese, while others (such as those in Japan and certain provinces of Korea) speak pitch-accent languages, and the prevalence of absolute pitch may be partly explained by exposure to pitches together with meaningful musical labels very early in life.<ref name=\"deu_2006\"/><ref name=\"deu_2006b\"/><ref name=\"deu_2007\"/><ref name=deu_2004>{{cite journal
column67: title=Absolute pitch, speech, and tone language: Some experiments and a proposed framework

column1: Absolute pitch ability has higher prevalence among those with [[Williams syndrome]]<ref name=\"lenhoff\">{{cite journal
column12: issue=4}}</ref> and those with an [[autism spectrum disorder]], with rates as high as 30% claimed, stating that the rate among musicians in general is far lower.{{Clarify
column18: title=Autism and pitch processing: A precursor for savant musical ability
column25: jstor=40285769}}</ref><ref>Frith, U. How Cognitive Theories Can Help Us Explain Autism. Speech. UC Davis Mind Institute. Video available, 4/5 down the list: http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/mindinstitute/videos/video_autism.html {{Webarchive
column27: date=2011-11-04 }}</ref> A non-verbal piano-matching method resulted in a correlation of 97% between{{Clarify
column28: reason=In which direction? 97% of persons with ASD having absolute pitch or 97% of persons with absolute pitch being on the autism spectrum? Or was there a score on a pitch-matching test and a score on an autism-detection test (e.g., Asperger Questionnaire), and was the test geared toward specificity or sensitivity?
column29: date=April 2016}} autism and absolute pitch, with a 53% correlation in non-autistic observers{{Clarify
column30: reason=Correlation between what and what? Does \"in\" mean \"between\"/\"among\" here? \"In the minds of\"? Observers of what?
column34: title=Non-Verbal Paradigm for Assessing Individuals for Absolute Pitch
column40: doi=10.1080/02604027.2014.989780}}</ref> However, the converse is not indicated by research which found no difference between those with AP and those without on measures of social and communication skills, which are core deficits in autistic spectrum disorders. Additionally, the AP group's [[autism-spectrum quotient]] was \"way below clinical thresholds\".<ref>{{Cite journal
column52: title=Do Musicians with Perfect Pitch Have More Autism Traits than Musicians without Perfect Pitch? An Empirical Study

column1: Absolute pitch might be achievable by any human being during a [[critical period]] of auditory development,<ref name=\"Sakakibara, 2004\">{{cite journal
column4: title= Why Are People Able to Acquire Absolute Pitch Only During Early Childhood?
column5: journal=The Japanese Journal of Educational Psychology
column12: title= The Development of Absolute Pitch: A Theory Concerning the Roles of Music Training at an Early Developmental Age and Individual Cognitive Style
column17: doi=10.1177/0305735603031002292}}</ref> after which period [[cognitive]] strategies favor global and relational processing. Proponents of the critical-period theory agree that the presence of absolute pitch ability is dependent on learning, but there is disagreement about whether training causes absolute skills to occur<ref name=\"Oura & Eguchi, 1982\">{{cite journal
column21: title=Absolute pitch training program for children
column27: title=A longitudinal study of a process for acquiring absolute pitch
column28: journal=The Japanese Journal of Educational Psychology
column34: title=Learning of absolute pitch by children
column44: title=The acquisition of absolute pitch for the mainstreamed, special educational needs and academically talented under Lau Chiu Kay Music Educatherapy
column45: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column53: fix-attempted=yes }} Abstract</ref> or lack of training causes absolute perception to be overwhelmed and obliterated by relative perception of [[interval (music)
column60: pages=1–86}}[http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/abraham01.htm Full text] [http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/abraham01e.htm Full text (English)]</ref><ref name=\"Saffran and Griepentrog, 2001\">{{cite journal
column65: title=Absolute pitch in infant auditory learning: Evidence for developmental reorganization

column2: loci]] could affect absolute pitch ability, a predisposition for learning the ability or signal the likelihood of its spontaneous occurrence.<ref name=\"Theusch, E. et al.\">{{cite journal
column8: title=Genome-wide Study of Families with Absolute Pitch Reveals Linkage to 8q24.21 and Locus Heterogeneity
column9: journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics
column26: title=Absolute pitch exhibits phenotypic and genetic overlap with synesthesia
column34: pmc=4707203}}</ref><ref name=\"Drayna, D. et al.\">{{cite journal
column42: title=Genetic correlates of musical pitch recognition in humans

column1: Researchers have been trying to teach absolute pitch ability in laboratory settings for more than a century,<ref name=\"Meyer_1899\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Is the memory of absolute pitch capable of development by training?
column10: url=http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/research/articles/meyer99.htm}}</ref> and various commercial absolute-pitch training courses have been offered to the public since the early 1900s.<ref>{{cite book
column20: url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2013, experimenters reported that adult men who took the antiseizure drug [[Valproate]] (VPA) \"learned to identify pitch significantly better than those taking placebo—evidence that VPA facilitated critical-period learning in the adult human brain\".<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: title=Valproate reopens critical-period learning of absolute pitch
column40: volume=7}}</ref> However, no adult has ever been documented to have acquired absolute listening ability,<ref>{{cite journal
column44: title=Absolute pitch: Perception, coding, and controversies
column56: url-status=dead }}</ref> because all adults who have been formally tested after AP training have failed to demonstrate \"an unqualified level of accuracy... comparable to that of AP possessors\".<ref>{{cite journal

column1: While very few people have the ability to name a pitch with no external reference, pitch memory can be activated by repeated exposure.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance
column17: access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> People who are not skilled singers will often sing popular songs in the correct key,<ref>{{cite journal
column20: title=Absolute memory for musical pitch: evidence from production of learned melodies
column30: archive-date=2011-07-06 }}</ref> and can usually recognize when TV themes have been shifted into the wrong key.<ref>{{cite journal
column35: title= Good pitch memory is widespread
column44: fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> Members of the Venda culture in South Africa also sing familiar children's songs in the key in which the songs were learned.<ref>{{cite book
column48: chapter=Music and Historical Process in Vendaland

column1: This phenomenon is apparently unrelated to musical training. The skill may be associated more closely with vocal production. Violin students learning the [[Suzuki method]] are required to memorize each composition in a fixed key and play it from memory on their instrument, but they are not required to sing. When tested, these students did not succeed in singing the memorized Suzuki songs in the original, fixed key.<ref>{{cite book
column5: chapter=Absolute memory of learned melodies in children trained by the Suzuki violin method
column6: title=Proceedings of the 8th International Conference on Music Perception and Cognition

column1: Musicians with absolute perception may experience difficulties which do not exist for other musicians. Because absolute listeners are capable of recognizing that a musical composition has been transposed from its original key, or that a pitch is being produced at a nonstandard frequency (either sharp or flat), a musician with absolute pitch may become distressed upon perceiving tones believed to be \"wrong\" or hearing a piece of music \"in the wrong key.\" This can especially apply to Baroque music that is recorded in Baroque tuning (usually A = 415 Hz as opposed to 440 Hz, ''i.e.'', roughly a half step or [[semitone]] lower than standard concert pitch).<ref name=\"Sacks, O. 2007\">{{cite book
column4: title=Musicophilia: Tales of Music and the Brain
column9: isbn=978-1-4000-4081-0}}</ref> An absolute listener may also use absolute strategies for tasks which are more efficiently accomplished with [[relative pitch
column10: relative strategies]], such as transposition<ref name=\"miy_1993\">{{cite journal
column12: title=Absolute pitch as an inability: Identification of musical intervals in a tonal context
column19: jstor=40285599}}</ref> or producing harmony for tones whose frequencies do not match standard [[equal temperament]].<ref>{{cite book
column24: location=Ontario}}</ref> It is also possible for some musicians to have displaced absolute pitch, where all notes are slightly flat or slightly sharp of their respective pitch as defined by a given convention.{{citation needed
column25: date=June 2015}} This may arise from learning the pitch names from an instrument that was tuned to a concert pitch convention other than the one in use, ''e.g.'', A = 435 Hz (the [[Paris Opera]] convention of the late 19th and early 20th centuries) as opposed to the Anglo-American modern standard A = 440 Hz. When playing in groups with other musicians, this may lead to playing in a tonality that is slightly different from that of the rest of the group.{{citation needed

column1: Absolute pitch shows a genetic overlap with music-related and non-music-related [[synesthesia]]/[[ideasthesia]].<ref name=gregersen_2013/> They may associate certain notes or keys with different colors, enabling them to tell what any note or key is. In this study, about 20% of people with perfect pitch are also synesthetes.
There is evidence of a higher rate of absolute pitch in the [[autistic]] population.<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Veridical mapping in the development of exceptional autistic abilities

column1: Absolute pitch is not a prerequisite for skilled musical performance or composition. However, musicians with absolute pitch tend to perform better on musical transcription tasks (controlling for age of onset and amount of musical training) compared to those without absolute pitch.<ref name=\"phil-446\">{{cite journal
column5: title=Absolute pitch correlates with high performance on musical dictation
column6: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
column14: url=https://semanticscholar.org/paper/f75c4936a26a63195692432e86e8bbccf60c82e8 }} [http://philomel.com/pdf/JASA-2010_128_890-893.pdf PDF Document]</ref> It was previously argued that musicians with absolute pitch perform worse than those without absolute pitch on recognition of musical intervals,<ref name=\"miyazaki\">{{cite journal
column16: title=Perception of relative pitch with different references: Some absolute-pitch listeners can't tell musical interval names
column23: pmid=8532499}} [https://doi.org/10.3758%2FBF03205455 PDF Document]</ref> however experiments on which this conclusion was based contained an [[Artifact (error)
column24: artifact]], and when this artifact was removed, absolute pitch possessors were found to perform better than nonpossessors on recognition of musical intervals.<ref name=\"phil-473\">{{cite journal
column27: title=Absolute pitch correlates with high performance on interval naming tasks
column28: journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

column1: Owing to uncertainty in the historical record, it is often impossible to determine whether notable composers and musicians of the past had absolute pitch. Since absolute pitch is rare in European musical culture,<ref name=\"deu_2006b\" /> claims that any particular musician possessed it are difficult to evaluate. Among composers of the [[Baroque music
column3: Classical]] eras, evidence is available only for [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
column4: Mozart]], who is documented to have demonstrated the ability at age 7.<ref name=\"phil-45\">{{cite journal
column13: url=https://semanticscholar.org/paper/386ccaf8507b4dfb6d8d92f7ccd996c4d4c93b75 }} [http://philomel.com/pdf/AT-2006_2_2.pdf PDF Document]</ref> Experts have only surmised that [[Ludwig van Beethoven
column14: Beethoven]] had it, as indicated from some excerpts from his letters. By the 19th century, it became more common for the presence of absolute pitch to be recorded, identifying the ability to be present in musicians such as [[Camille Saint-Saëns]] and [[John Philip Sousa]].<ref>Naxos. (2018). \"John Philip Sousa.\" Retrieved from https://www.naxos.com/person/John_Philip_Sousa_24864/24864.htm</ref>
